632 <path d="M19 8H5c-1.66 0-3 1.34-3 3v6h4v4h12v-4h4v-6c0-1.66-1.34-3-3-3zm-3 11H8v-5h8v5zm3-7c-.55 0-1-.45-1-1s.45-1 1-1 1 .45 1 1-.45 1-1 1zm-1-9H6v4h12V3z"/>

If you have questions or need additional information, we invite you to contact NCI's LiveHelp instant messaging service at https://livehelp.cancer.gov, or call the NCI's Contact Center 1-800-4-CANCER (1-800-422-6237) (toll-free from the United States).">

777 <h1>

778Neuroblastoma Treatment (PDQ®)–Health Professional Version</h1>

779

780 <div id="cgvBody">

781

782 <div class="summary-sections">

783

784 <nav class="on-this-page" role="navigation">

785

788

856 <div class="accordion">

857

858

859

860 <section id="_1">

861

862 <h2>

863General Information About Neuroblastoma</h2>

864

865 <div id="_section_1" class="pdq-sections">

866<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

867<h6>

868In This Section</h6>

869<ul>

870<li>

871<a href="#_534_toc">

872Incidence and Epidemiology</a>

873</li>

874<li>

875<a href="#_584_toc">

876Anatomy</a>

877</li>

878<li>

879<a href="#_445_toc">

880Neuroblastoma Screening <ul>

881<li>

882<a href="#_2471_toc">

883Familial neuroblastoma and genetic predisposition</a>

884</li>

885<li>

886<a href="#_548_toc">

887General Population</a>

888</li>

889</ul>

890</a>

891</li>

892<li>

893<a href="#_290_toc">

894Clinical Presentation<ul>

895<li>

896<a href="#_448_toc">

897Opsoclonus/myoclonus syndrome</a>

898</li>

899</ul>

900</a>

901</li>

902<li>

903<a href="#_294_toc">

904Diagnosis</a>

905</li>

906<li>

907<a href="#_554_toc">

908Observation and Spontaneous Regression of Fetal/Neonatal Neuroblastoma</a>

909</li>

910<li>

911<a href="#_297_toc">

912Prognostic Factors<ul>

913<li>

914<a href="#_1841_toc">

915Treatment era</a>

916</li>

917<li>

918<a href="#_311_toc">

919Age at diagnosis</a>

920</li>

921<li>

922<a href="#_573_toc">

923Tumor histology</a>

924</li>

925<li>

926<a href="#_1901_toc">

927Biological features</a>

928</li>

929<li>

930<a href="#_571_toc">

931Site of primary tumor</a>

932</li>

933<li>

934<a href="#_1843_toc">

935Stage of disease</a>

936</li>

937<li>

938<a href="#_577_toc">

939Response to treatment</a>

940</li>

941<li>

942<a href="#_2050_toc">

943Levels of LDH and ferritin</a>

944</li>

945</ul>

946</a>

947</li>

948</ul>

949</nav>

950<div class="pdq-hp-patient-toggle">

951<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/patient/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq">

952Go to Patient Version</a>

953</div>

954<p id="_268" tabindex="-1">

955Dramatic improvements in survival have been achieved for children and adolescents with cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9561</a>

957,<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

9582</a>

959] Between 1975 and 2020, childhood cancer mortality decreased by more than 50%.[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9601</a>

961-<a href="#cit/section_1.5">

9625</a>

963] Between 1975 and 2017, the 5-year survival rate for patients with neuroblastoma increased, from 86% to 91% for children younger than 1 year and from 34% to 83% for children aged 1 to 14 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

9642</a>

965,<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

9663</a>

967]</p>

968<p id="_2470" tabindex="-1">

969 Childhood and adolescent cancer survivors require close monitoring because cancer therapy side effects may persist or develop months or years after treatment. For specific information about the incidence, type, and monitoring of late effects in childhood and adolescent cancer survivors, see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq">

970Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer</a>

971. </p>

972<section id="_534">

973<h3 id="_534_toc">

974Incidence and Epidemiology</h3>

975<p id="_535" tabindex="-1">

976Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor in childhood. More than 650 cases are diagnosed each year in the United States.[<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

9772</a>

978,<a href="#cit/section_1.6">

9796</a>

980-<a href="#cit/section_1.8">

9818</a>

982] The prevalence is about 1 case per 7,000 live births. The incidence is 10.2 cases per 1 million per year in children younger than 15 years. About 37% of patients are diagnosed as infants, and 90% are younger than 5 years at diagnosis, with a median age at diagnosis of 17 months.[<a href="#cit/section_1.8">

9838</a>

984,<a href="#cit/section_1.9">

9859</a>

986] The data on age at diagnosis show that this is a disease of infancy, with the highest rate of diagnosis in the first month of life.[<a href="#cit/section_1.6">

9876</a>

988,<a href="#cit/section_1.9">

9899</a>

990,<a href="#cit/section_1.10">

99110</a>

992]</p>

993<p id="_732" tabindex="-1">

994Population-based studies of screening for infants with neuroblastoma have demonstrated that spontaneous regression of neuroblastoma without clinical detection in the first year of life is at least as prevalent as clinically detected neuroblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_1.11">

99511</a>

996-<a href="#cit/section_1.13">

99713</a>

998]

999</p>

1000<p id="_731" tabindex="-1">

1001The incidence of neuroblastoma is slightly lower in Black children than in White children.[<a href="#cit/section_1.14">

100214</a>

1003] There may be genetic differences between Black and White patients that account for the higher-risk disease and more fatal outcomes observed in Black patients. However, socioeconomic disparities and unequal access to medical care may also affect risk and patient outcomes. More research is needed to determine the impact of these genetic and socioeconomic factors.[<a href="#cit/section_1.15">

100415</a>

1005,<a href="#cit/section_1.16">

100616</a>

1007]</p>

1008<p id="_1117" tabindex="-1">

1009Epidemiological studies have shown that environmental or other exposures have not been unequivocally associated with increased or decreased incidences of neuroblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_1.17">

101017</a>

1011]</p>

1012</section>

1013<section id="_584">

1014<h3 id="_584_toc">

1015Anatomy</h3>

1016<p id="_585" tabindex="-1">

1017Neuroblastoma originates in the adrenal medulla and paraspinal or periaortic regions where

1018sympathetic nervous system tissue is present (see <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1017">

1019Figure 1</a>

1020).</p>

1021<p id="_1016" tabindex="-1">

1022<figure id="figure_1017" class="image-center">

1023<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/756627.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

1024Enlarge</a>

1025<img id="_1017" alt="Drawing shows parts of the body where neuroblastoma may be found, including the paraspinal nerve tissue and the adrenal glands. Also shown are the spine and right and left kidney." title="Drawing shows parts of the body where neuroblastoma may be found, including the paraspinal nerve tissue and the adrenal glands. Also shown are the spine and right and left kidney." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/756627-750.jpg">

1026<figcaption class="caption-container">

1027Figure 1. Neuroblastoma may be found in the adrenal glands and paraspinal nerve tissue from the neck to the pelvis.</figcaption>

1028</figure>

1029</p>

1030</section>

1031<section id="_445">

1032<h3 id="_445_toc">

1033Neuroblastoma Screening </h3>

1034<section id="_2471">

1035<h4 id="_2471_toc">

1036Familial neuroblastoma and genetic predisposition</h4>

1037<p id="_447" tabindex="-1">

1038Studies analyzing constitutional DNA in rare cohorts of patients with familial neuroblastoma have provided insight into the complex genetic basis for tumor initiation. About 1% to 2% of patients with neuroblastoma have a family history of the disease. These children are, on average, younger (9 months at diagnosis) than patients without a family history, and about 20% of these patients have multifocal primary neuroblastoma. </p>

1039<p id="_1146" tabindex="-1">

1040<strong>

1041Germline mutations. </strong>

1042Several germline mutations have been associated with a genetic predisposition to neuroblastoma, including the following:</p>

1043<div class="pdq-content-list">

1044<ul id="_1147">

1045<li>

1046<strong>

1047<em class="gene-name">

1048ALK</em>

1049 gene mutation.</strong>

1050 The primary cause of familial neuroblastoma (about 75% of familial cases) is aberrant activation of the germline ALK signaling pathway, which results from point mutations in the tyrosine kinase domain of the <em class="gene-name">

1051ALK</em>

1052 gene.[<a href="#cit/section_1.18">

105318</a>

1054] Somatic activating point mutations in <em class="gene-name">

1055ALK</em>

1056 are also seen in about 9% of sporadic neuroblastoma cases. In addition, in a small proportion of neuroblastoma cases with <em class="gene-name">

1057MYCN</em>

1058 amplification, <em class="gene-name">

1059ALK</em>

1060 is co-amplified (<em class="gene-name">

1061ALK</em>

1062 is near <em class="gene-name">

1063MYCN</em>

1064 on chromosome 2), which may also result in <em class="gene-name">

1065ALK</em>

1066 activation. <em class="gene-name">

1067ALK</em>

1068 is a tyrosine kinase receptor. For more information about <em class="gene-name">

1069ALK</em>

1070 mutations, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1937">

1071Genomic and Biological Features of Neuroblastoma</a>

1072 section.</li>

1073<li>

1074<strong>

1075<em class="gene-name">

1076PHOX2B</em>

1077 gene mutation.</strong>

1078 Rarely, familial neuroblastoma may be associated with congenital central hypoventilation syndrome (Ondine curse), which is caused by a germline mutation of the <em class="gene-name">

1079PHOX2B</em>

1080 gene.[<a href="#cit/section_1.19">

108119</a>

1082] Most <em class="gene-name">

1083PHOX2B</em>

1084 mutations causing Ondine curse or Hirschsprung disease are polyalanine repeats and are not associated with familial neuroblastoma. However, germline loss-of-function <em class="gene-name">

1085PHOX2B</em>

1086 mutations have been identified in rare patients with sporadic neuroblastoma and Ondine curse and/or Hirschsprung disease.[<a href="#cit/section_1.20">

108720</a>

1088] This aberration has not been seen in patients with sporadic neuroblastoma without associated Ondine curse or Hirschsprung disease. Additionally, somatic <em class="gene-name">

1089PHOX2B</em>

1090 mutations occur in about 2% of sporadic cases of neuroblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_1.21">

109121</a>

1092,<a href="#cit/section_1.22">

109322</a>

1094]</li>

1095<li>

1096<strong>

1097Deletion at the 1p36 or 11q14-23 locus.</strong>

1098 In case studies, germline deletion at the 1p36 or 11q14-23 locus has been associated with familial neuroblastoma. The same deletions are found somatically in some sporadic neuroblastoma cases.[<a href="#cit/section_1.23">

109923</a>

1100,<a href="#cit/section_1.24">

110124</a>

1102]</li>

1103</ul>

1104</div>

1105<p id="_1853" tabindex="-1">

1106<strong>

1107Other cancer predisposition syndromes.</strong>

1108 Children with gene aberrations associated with other cancer predisposition syndromes may be at increased risk of developing neuroblastoma and other malignancies. The following syndromes primarily involve genes in the canonical RAS pathway:</p>

1109<div class="pdq-content-list">

1110<ul id="_1897">

1111<li>

1112Costello syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_1.25">

111325</a>

1114] </li>

1115<li>

1116Noonan syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_1.26">

111726</a>

1118]</li>

1119<li>

1120Neurofibromatosis type 1.[<a href="#cit/section_1.27">

112127</a>

1122] </li>

1123</ul>

1124</div>

1125<p id="_1898" tabindex="-1">

1126In addition, neuroblastoma has been described in patients with the following syndromes: </p>

1127<div class="pdq-content-list">

1128<ul id="_1899">

1129<li>

1130Li-Fraumeni syndrome.</li>

1131<li>

1132Hereditary pheochromocytoma/paraganglioma syndromes.[<a href="#cit/section_1.28">

113328</a>

1134] </li>

1135<li>

1136ROHHAD syndrome (rapid-onset obesity, hypothalamic dysfunction, hypoventilation, and autonomic dysfunction).[<a href="#cit/section_1.29">

113729</a>

1138] </li>

1139<li>

1140Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_1.30">

114130</a>

1142]</li>

1143</ul>

1144</div>

1145<p id="_1164" tabindex="-1">

1146Sporadic neuroblastoma may also have an increased incidence resulting from less potent germline predispositions. Genome-wide association studies have identified several common genomic variables (single nucleotide polymorphisms) with modest effect size that are associated with increased risk of developing neuroblastoma. Most of these genomic risk variables are significantly associated with distinct neuroblastoma phenotypes (i.e., high-risk vs. low-risk disease).[<a href="#cit/section_1.31">

114731</a>

1148]</p>

1149<section id="_1931">

1150<h5 id="_1931_toc">

1151Neuroblastoma predisposition and surveillance</h5>

1152<p id="_1932" tabindex="-1">

1153

1154 Screening recommendations from the American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) emerged from the 2016 Childhood Cancer Predisposition Workshop. The AACR recommends that the following individuals undergo biochemical and radiographic surveillance for early detection of tumors in the first 10 years of life:[<a href="#cit/section_1.28">

115528</a>

1156]</p>

1157<div class="pdq-content-list">

1158<ul id="_1933">

1159<li>

1160Individuals with highly penetrant, heritable <em class="gene-name">

1161ALK</em>

1162 or <em class="gene-name">

1163PHOX2B</em>

1164 mutations (45%&#8211;50% risk of developing one or more tumors).</li>

1165<li>

1166Individuals with Li-Fraumeni syndrome and germline <em class="gene-name">

1167TP53</em>

1168 p.R337H mutations.</li>

1169<li>

1170Individuals with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome and germline <em class="gene-name">

1171CDKN1C</em>

1172 mutations.</li>

1173<li>

1174Individuals with Costello syndrome and <em class="gene-name">

1175HRAS</em>

1176 mutations.</li>

1177<li>

1178Individuals with neuroblastoma and a strong family history of neuroblastoma or clearly bilateral/multifocal neuroblastoma.</li>

1179</ul>

1180</div>

1181<p id="_1934" tabindex="-1">

1182Surveillance consists of the following:[<a href="#cit/section_1.28">

118328</a>

1184]</p>

1185<div class="pdq-content-list">

1186<ul id="_1935">

1187<li>

1188Abdominal ultrasonography.</li>

1189<li>

1190Quantitative, normalized assessment of urinary catecholamines,[<a href="#cit/section_1.32">

119132</a>

1192] such as urine vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and homovanillic acid (HVA), by gas chromatography and mass spectroscopy (can be a random urine collection normalized for urine creatinine, because this approach appears to have similar sensitivity to a 24-hour collection).</li>

1193<li>

1194Chest x-ray.</li>

1195</ul>

1196</div>

1197<p id="_1936" tabindex="-1">

1198Surveillance begins at birth or at diagnosis of neuroblastoma predisposition and continues every 3 months until age 6 years, then every 6 months until age 10 years. Patients with Costello syndrome may have elevated urinary catecholamines in the absence of a catecholamine-secreting tumor, so only high or significantly rising levels should prompt investigation beyond ultrasonography and chest x-ray.[<a href="#cit/section_1.33">

119933</a>

1200] Patients with Li-Fraumeni syndrome should not undergo chest x-rays.[<a href="#cit/section_1.28">

120128</a>

1202]</p>

1203<p id="_1893" tabindex="-1">

1204About 5% of children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome have mutations that cause decreased activity of CDKN1C. A review of all large studies of genetically subtyped Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome found 70 children with the <em class="gene-name">

1205CDKN1C</em>

1206 mutation, 4.6% of whom developed neuroblastoma. There were no cases of Wilms tumor or hepatoblastoma. There is little experience with screening these children for neuroblastoma, so there are no generally accepted guidelines. However, the authors of the study suggest screening with urinary VMA/HVA every 4 to 6 months. Patients with other genetic subtypes of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome have a prevalence of neuroblastoma of less than 1%. No neuroblastic tumors were found among 123 children with the genotype gain of methylation at imprinting control region 1.[<a href="#cit/section_1.34">

120734</a>

1208]</p>

1209</section>

1210</section>

1211<section id="_548">

1212<h4 id="_548_toc">

1213General Population</h4>

1214<p id="_549" tabindex="-1">

1215Current data do not support neuroblastoma screening in the general public. Screening at the ages of 3 weeks, 6 months, or 1 year did not lead to a reduced incidence of advanced-stage neuroblastoma with

1216unfavorable biological characteristics in older children, nor did it reduce overall mortality from neuroblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_1.12">

121712</a>

1218,<a href="#cit/section_1.13">

121913</a>

1220] No public health benefits have been shown from screening infants for neuroblastoma at these ages. For more information, see <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-screening-pdq">

1221Neuroblastoma Screening</a>

1222.</p>

1223<p id="_551" tabindex="-1">

1224Evidence (against neuroblastoma screening):</p>

1225<div class="pdq-content-list">

1226<ol id="_552">

1227<li>

1228In a large population-based North

1229American study, most infants in Quebec, Canada, were screened at the ages of 3 weeks

1230and 6 months.[<a href="#cit/section_1.11">

123111</a>

1232,<a href="#cit/section_1.12">

123312</a>

1234]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1235<ul id="_2403">

1236<li>

1237Screening detected many neuroblastomas with

1238favorable characteristics that would never have been detected

1239clinically because of spontaneous regression of the tumors.</li>

1240</ul>

1241</div>

1242</li>

1243<li>

1244Another study of infants screened at the age of 1 year showed similar results.[<a href="#cit/section_1.13">

124513</a>

1246] </li>

1247</ol>

1248</div>

1249</section>

1250</section>

1251<section id="_290">

1252<h3 id="_290_toc">

1253Clinical Presentation</h3>

1254<p id="_291" tabindex="-1">

1255The most frequent signs and symptoms of neuroblastoma in children are caused by tumor mass and metastases and include the following:</p>

1256<div class="pdq-content-list">

1257<ul id="_546">

1258<li>

1259<strong>

1260Abdominal mass:</strong>

1261 The most common presentation of neuroblastoma.</li>

1262<li>

1263<strong>

1264Proptosis and periorbital

1265ecchymosis:</strong>

1266 Common in high-risk patients; arise from retrobulbar metastasis.</li>

1267<li>

1268<strong>

1269Abdominal distention:</strong>

1270 May occur with

1271respiratory compromise in infants because of massive liver metastases.</li>

1272<li>

1273<strong>

1274Bone pain:</strong>

1275 Occurs in association with metastatic disease.</li>

1276<li>

1277<strong>

1278Pancytopenia:</strong>

1279 May result from extensive bone

1280marrow metastasis.</li>

1281<li>

1282<strong>

1283Fever, hypertension, and anemia:</strong>

1284 Occasionally found in patients without metastasis.</li>

1285<li>

1286<strong>

1287Paralysis:</strong>

1288 Neuroblastoma originating in paraspinal ganglia may invade through

1289neural foramina and compress the spinal cord extradurally. Immediate treatment is given for symptomatic spinal cord compression. For more information, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_816">

1290Treatment of Spinal Cord Compression</a>

1291 section.</li>

1292<li>

1293<strong>

1294Watery diarrhea:</strong>

1295

1296On rare occasions, children may have severe, watery diarrhea caused by the secretion of

1297vasoactive intestinal peptide by the tumor, or they may have protein-losing enteropathy with intestinal lymphangiectasia.[<a href="#cit/section_1.35">

129835</a>

1299] Vasoactive intestinal peptide secretion may occur at presentation (with diarrhea being the first symptom of neuroblastoma), may appear with the initiation of chemotherapy, or occasionally may become evident later in the course of treatment. Tumor resection reduces vasoactive intestinal peptide secretion.[<a href="#cit/section_1.36">

130036</a>

1301]</li>

1302<li>

1303<strong>

1304Presence of Horner syndrome:</strong>

1305 Characterized by miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis. It may be caused by neuroblastoma in the stellate ganglion. Children with Horner syndrome without other apparent causes are also examined for neuroblastoma and other tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_1.37">

130637</a>

1307]</li>

1308<li>

1309<strong>

1310Subcutaneous skin nodules:</strong>

1311 Subcutaneous metastases of neuroblastoma often have bluish discoloration of the overlying skin; usually seen only in infants.</li>

1312</ul>

1313</div>

1314<p id="_567" tabindex="-1">

1315The clinical presentation of neuroblastoma in adolescents is similar to that in children. The only exception is that bone marrow involvement occurs less frequently in adolescents, and there is a greater frequency of metastases in unusual sites such as lung or brain.[<a href="#cit/section_1.38">

131638</a>

1317]</p>

1318<section id="_448">

1319<h4 id="_448_toc">

1320Opsoclonus/myoclonus syndrome</h4>

1321<p id="_449" tabindex="-1">

1322Paraneoplastic neurological

1323findings, including cerebellar ataxia or opsoclonus/myoclonus, occur rarely in children with neuroblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_1.39">

132439</a>

1325]

1326 Of young children presenting with opsoclonus/myoclonus syndrome, about one-half are found to have neuroblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_1.40">

132740</a>

1328,<a href="#cit/section_1.41">

132941</a>

1330] The incidence in the United Kingdom is estimated at 0.18 cases per 1 million children per year. The average age at diagnosis is 1.5 to 2 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.42">

133142</a>

1332] </p>

1333<p id="_877" tabindex="-1">

1334The usual presentation is the onset of progressive neurological dysfunction over a few days before a neuroblastoma is discovered. However, on occasion, neurological symptoms arise long after removal of the primary tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_1.40">

133540</a>

1336,<a href="#cit/section_1.43">

133743</a>

1338,<a href="#cit/section_1.44">

133944</a>

1340] Patients with neuroblastoma who

1341present with opsoclonus/myoclonus syndrome often have neuroblastoma with favorable biological

1342features and have excellent survival rates, although tumor-related deaths have been

1343reported.[<a href="#cit/section_1.40">

134440</a>

1345]</p>

1346<p id="_450" tabindex="-1">

1347The

1348opsoclonus/myoclonus syndrome appears to be caused by an immunologic mechanism

1349that is not yet fully characterized.[<a href="#cit/section_1.40">

135040</a>

1351] The primary

1352tumor is typically diffusely infiltrated with lymphocytes.[<a href="#cit/section_1.45">

135345</a>

1354] Cerebrospinal fluid shows an increased number of B cells, and oligoclonal immunoglobulin bands are often seen. Steroid-responsive elevations of B-cell&#8211;related cytokines are also often seen.[<a href="#cit/section_1.46">

135546</a>

1356]</p>

1357<p id="_1989" tabindex="-1">

1358Genomic copy number profiles were analyzed in 44 cases of neuroblastoma associated with opsoclonus/myoclonus syndrome. Because there were no tumor relapses or disease-related deaths, the overall genomic profile was not prognostically significant.[<a href="#cit/section_1.47">

135947</a>

1360]</p>

1361<p id="_451" tabindex="-1">

1362Some patients may rapidly respond

1363neurologically to immune interventions or simply to removal of the neuroblastoma, but in many cases, improvement may be slow and partial. The improvement in acutely presenting motor deficits and ataxia seen with immunological therapy is not clearly associated with improvement in long-term neuropsychological disability, which primarily consists of cognitive and behavioral deficits. The long-term benefits of rapid improvement resulting from treatment, whether of symptoms or of the underlying neuroblastoma, are unclear, but rapid improvement appears to be worthwhile.[<a href="#cit/section_1.44">

136444</a>

1365,<a href="#cit/section_1.48">

136648</a>

1367]</p>

1368<p id="_1840" tabindex="-1">

1369 Treatment with adrenocorticotropic hormones or corticosteroids can be effective for acute symptoms, but some patients do not respond to

1370corticosteroids.[<a href="#cit/section_1.43">

137143</a>

1372,<a href="#cit/section_1.49">

137349</a>

1374] Other therapy with various immunomodulatory drugs, plasmapheresis, intravenous gamma globulin, and rituximab have

1375been reported to be effective in select cases.[<a href="#cit/section_1.43">

137643</a>

1377,<a href="#cit/section_1.50">

137850</a>

1379-<a href="#cit/section_1.53">

138053</a>

1381] Combination immunosuppressive therapy has been explored, with improved short-term results.[<a href="#cit/section_1.54">

138254</a>

1383] The short-term neurological outcomes may be superior in patients treated with chemotherapy, possibly because of its immunosuppressive effects.[<a href="#cit/section_1.39">

138439</a>

1385]</p>

1386<p id="_1882" tabindex="-1">

1387 The Children&#8217;s Oncology Group (COG) has completed the first randomized, open-label, phase III study of patients with opsoclonus/myoclonus ataxia syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_1.55">

138855</a>

1389] Patients with newly diagnosed neuroblastoma and opsoclonus/myoclonus ataxia syndrome who were younger than 8 years were randomly assigned to receive either intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) or no IVIG in addition to prednisone and risk-adapted treatment of the tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_1.55">

139055</a>

1391] </p>

1392<div class="pdq-content-list">

1393<ul id="_2472">

1394<li>

1395 Of the 53 patients who participated, 21 of 26 patients (81%) in the IVIG group had an opsoclonus/myoclonus ataxia syndrome response over a period of weeks to months, compared with 11 of 27 patients (41%) in the non-IVIG group (odds ratio [OR], 6.1; <em>

1396P</em>

1397 = .0029). </li>

1398<li>

1399This study demonstrates that short-term neurological response is improved in patients treated with chemotherapy, corticosteroids, and immunoglobulin, compared with patients treated with chemotherapy and corticosteroids without immunoglobulin.</li>

1400<li>

1401Additional follow-up is needed to assess long-term neurodevelopmental and learning problems in this population.</li>

1402</ul>

1403</div>

1404</section>

1405</section>

1406<section id="_294">

1407<h3 id="_294_toc">

1408Diagnosis</h3>

1409<p id="_616" tabindex="-1">

1410Diagnostic evaluation of neuroblastoma includes the following:</p>

1411<div class="pdq-content-list">

1412<ul id="_617">

1413<li>

1414<strong>

1415Tumor imaging:</strong>

1416 Imaging of the primary tumor mass is generally accomplished by computed tomography or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with contrast. Paraspinal tumors that might threaten spinal cord compression are imaged using MRI. <p id="_1900" tabindex="-1">

1417Metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) scanning is a critical part of the standard diagnostic evaluation of neuroblastoma, for both the primary tumor and sites of metastases.[<a href="#cit/section_1.56">

141856</a>

1419,<a href="#cit/section_1.57">

142057</a>

1421] MIBG scanning is also critical to assess response to therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_1.57">

142257</a>

1423] About 90% of neuroblastoma cases are MIBG avid. Fluorine F 18-fludeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (PET) scans are used to evaluate extent of disease in patients with tumors that are not MIBG avid.[<a href="#cit/section_1.58">

142458</a>

1425] For more information about imaging of neuroblastoma, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_14">

1426Stage Information for Neuroblastoma</a>

1427 section.</p>

1428</li>

1429<li>

1430<strong>

1431Urine catecholamine metabolites:</strong>

1432 Urinary excretion of the catecholamine metabolites VMA and HVA per milligram of excreted creatinine is measured before therapy. Collection of urine for 24 hours is not needed. If they remain elevated, these markers can be used to suggest the persistence of disease.<p id="_825" tabindex="-1">

1433In contrast to urine, serum catecholamines are not routinely used in the diagnosis of neuroblastoma except in unusual circumstances.</p>

1434</li>

1435<li>

1436<strong>

1437Biopsy:</strong>

1438 Tumor tissue is

1439often needed to obtain all the biological data required for risk-group assignment and subsequent treatment stratification in current COG clinical trials. There is an absolute requirement for tissue biopsy to determine the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1149">

1440International Neuroblastoma Pathology Classification</a>

1441 (INPC). Additionally, a significant number of tumor cells are needed to determine <em class="gene-name">

1442MYCN</em>

1443 copy number, DNA index, and the presence of segmental chromosomal aberrations. Tissue from several core biopsies, or approximately 1 cm<span class="sup">

14443</span>

1445 of tissue from an open biopsy, is needed for adequate biological staging. <p id="_1148" tabindex="-1">

1446For patients older than 18 months with stage 4 disease, bone marrow with extensive tumor involvement combined with elevated catecholamine metabolites may be adequate for diagnosis and assigning risk/treatment group. However, INPC cannot be determined from tumor metastatic to bone marrow. Testing for <em class="gene-name">

1447MYCN</em>

1448 amplification may be successfully performed on involved bone marrow if there is at least 30% tumor involvement. However, every attempt should be made to obtain an adequate biopsy from the primary tumor.</p>

1449<p id="_2473" tabindex="-1">

1450For information about the use of biopsy in patients younger than 1 year, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_554">

1451Observation and Spontaneous Regression of Fetal/Neonatal Neuroblastoma</a>

1452 section.</p>

1453</li>

1454</ul>

1455</div>

1456<p id="_295" tabindex="-1">

1457The diagnosis of neuroblastoma requires the involvement of pathologists who are

1458familiar with childhood tumors. Some neuroblastomas cannot be differentiated morphologically,

1459via conventional light microscopy with hematoxylin and eosin staining alone, from other small round blue cell tumors of childhood, such as lymphomas,

1460Ewing sarcoma, and rhabdomyosarcomas. In such cases, immunohistochemical and cytogenetic analysis may be needed to diagnose a specific small round blue cell tumor.</p>

1461<p id="_559" tabindex="-1">

1462The minimum criterion for a diagnosis of neuroblastoma, as established by international agreement, is that diagnosis must be based on <strong>

1463one</strong>

1464 of the following:</p>

1465<div class="pdq-content-list">

1466<ol id="_371">

1467<li>

1468An

1469unequivocal pathological diagnosis made from tumor tissue by light microscopy

1470(with or without immunohistology or electron microscopy).[<a href="#cit/section_1.59">

147159</a>

1472]</li>

1473<li>

1474The combination

1475of bone marrow aspirate or trephine biopsy containing unequivocal tumor cells

1476(e.g., syncytia or immunocytologically positive clumps of cells) <strong>

1477and</strong>

1478 increased

1479levels of urinary catecholamine metabolites.[<a href="#cit/section_1.59">

148059</a>

1481]</li>

1482</ol>

1483</div>

1484</section>

1485<section id="_554">

1486<h3 id="_554_toc">

1487Observation and Spontaneous Regression of Fetal/Neonatal Neuroblastoma</h3>

1488<p id="_555" tabindex="-1">

1489The phenomenon of spontaneous regression has been well described in infants with neuroblastoma, especially in infants with the INSS 4S/INRG MS pattern of metastatic spread.[<a href="#cit/section_1.60">

149060</a>

1491] In rare cases, neuroblastoma may be discovered prenatally by fetal ultrasonography.[<a href="#cit/section_1.61">

149261</a>

1493] Management recommendations are evolving regarding the need for immediate diagnostic biopsy in infants aged 6 months and younger with suspected neuroblastoma tumors that are likely to spontaneous regress. For more information about INSS 4S/INRG MS disease, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_14">

1494Stage Information for Neuroblastoma</a>

1495 section.</p>

1496<p id="_879" tabindex="-1">

1497Spontaneous regression generally occurs in tumors with the following features:[<a href="#cit/section_1.62">

149862</a>

1499-<a href="#cit/section_1.64">

150064</a>

1501] </p>

1502<div class="pdq-content-list">

1503<ul id="_880">

1504<li>

1505Near triploid number of chromosomes.</li>

1506<li>

1507No <em class="gene-name">

1508MYCN</em>

1509 amplification.</li>

1510<li>

1511No loss of chromosome 1p. </li>

1512</ul>

1513</div>

1514<p id="_881" tabindex="-1">

1515Additional features associated with spontaneous regression include the lack of telomerase expression,[<a href="#cit/section_1.62">

151662</a>

1517,<a href="#cit/section_1.65">

151865</a>

1519] the expression of the H-Ras protein,[<a href="#cit/section_1.66">

152066</a>

1521] and the expression of the neurotrophin receptor TrkA, a nerve growth factor receptor.[<a href="#cit/section_1.67">

152267</a>

1523]</p>

1524<p id="_556" tabindex="-1">

1525Studies have suggested that selected infants who appear to have asymptomatic, small, low-stage adrenal neuroblastoma detected by screening or during prenatal or incidental ultrasonography often have tumors that spontaneously regress. These patients may be observed safely without surgical intervention or tissue diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_1.68">

152668</a>

1527-<a href="#cit/section_1.70">

152870</a>

1529]</p>

1530<p id="_882" tabindex="-1">

1531Evidence (observation [spontaneous regression]):</p>

1532<div class="pdq-content-list">

1533<ol id="_883">

1534<li>

1535 In a COG study, 83 highly selected infants younger than 6 months with stage 1 small adrenal masses (3.1 cm or less), as defined by imaging studies, were observed without biopsy. Surgical intervention was reserved for those with growth or progression of the mass or increasing concentrations of urinary catecholamine metabolites.[<a href="#cit/section_1.71">

153671</a>

1537]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1538<ul id="_884">

1539<li>

1540 Eighty-one percent of patients did not undergo surgery, and all patients were alive after 2 years of follow-up. For more information, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_604">

1541Surgery</a>

1542 section.</li>

1543<li>

1544Therefore, prenatally identified adrenal masses approximately 3.1 cm or less can be safely observed if no metastatic disease is identified and there is no involvement of large vessels or organs.</li>

1545</ul>

1546</div>

1547</li>

1548<li>

1549A German clinical trial reported on 340 infants with localized neuroblastoma without <em class="gene-name">

1550MYCN</em>

1551 amplification. Of these patients, 190 underwent resection, 57 were treated with chemotherapy, and 93 were observed with gross residual tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_1.72">

155272</a>

1553]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1554<ul id="_2404">

1555<li>

1556 Spontaneous regression and/or lack of progression occurred in 44 of 93 asymptomatic infants aged 12 months or younger with stage 1, 2, or 3 tumors without <em class="gene-name">

1557MYCN</em>

1558 amplification. </li>

1559<li>

1560All patients were observed after biopsy and partial or no resection.</li>

1561<li>

1562 In some cases, regression did not occur until more than 1 year after diagnosis.</li>

1563</ul>

1564</div>

1565</li>

1566<li>

1567In neuroblastoma screening trials in Quebec, Canada, and Germany, the incidence of neuroblastoma was twice that reported without screening, suggesting that many neuroblastomas are never diagnosed clinically and spontaneously regress.[<a href="#cit/section_1.11">

156811</a>

1569-<a href="#cit/section_1.13">

157013</a>

1571]</li>

1572</ol>

1573</div>

1574</section>

1575<section id="_297">

1576<h3 id="_297_toc">

1577Prognostic Factors</h3>

1578<p id="_730" tabindex="-1">

1579The prognosis for patients with neuroblastoma is related to the following: </p>

1580<div class="pdq-content-list">

1581<ul id="_560">

1582<li>

1583<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1841">

1584Treatment era</a>

1585.</li>

1586<li>

1587<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_311">

1588Age at diagnosis</a>

1589.</li>

1590<li>

1591<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_573">

1592Tumor histology</a>

1593.</li>

1594<li>

1595<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1901">

1596Biological features</a>

1597.</li>

1598<li>

1599<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_571">

1600Site of primary tumor</a>

1601.</li>

1602<li>

1603<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1843">

1604Stage of disease</a>

1605.</li>

1606<li>

1607<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_577">

1608Response to treatment</a>

1609.</li>

1610<li>

1611<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_2050">

1612Levels of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and ferritin</a>

1613.</li>

1614</ul>

1615</div>

1616<p id="_840" tabindex="-1">

1617Some of these prognostic factors have been combined to create risk groups to help define treatment. For more information, see the sections on <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_834">

1618International Neuroblastoma Risk Group Staging System (INRGSS)</a>

1619 and <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_17">

1620Children&#8217;s Oncology Group (COG) Neuroblastoma Risk Grouping</a>

1621.</p>

1622<section id="_1841">

1623<h4 id="_1841_toc">

1624Treatment era</h4>

1625<p id="_1842" tabindex="-1">

1626Between 1975 and 2017, the 5-year survival rate for neuroblastoma in the United States increased from 86% to 91% for children younger than 1 year and from 34% to 83% for children aged 1 to 14 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

16272</a>

1628,<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

16293</a>

1630] The 5-year relative survival rate for all infants and children with neuroblastoma increased from 46% when diagnosed between 1974 and 1989 to 71% when diagnosed between 1999 and 2005.[<a href="#cit/section_1.73">

163173</a>

1632] More recent estimates from 2011 to 2017 show an even higher survival rate of approximately 85% for infants and children younger than 15 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

16332</a>

1634] These statistics can be misleading because of the extremely heterogeneous prognosis based on the patient's age, stage, and biology. However, studies demonstrate a significant improvement in survival for high-risk patients diagnosed and treated between 2000 and 2010, compared with patients diagnosed from 1990 to 1999.[<a href="#cit/section_1.74">

163574</a>

1636] For more information, see <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1154">

1637Table 1</a>

1638. Similarly, the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00499616">

1639ANBL0531 (NCT00499616)</a>

1640 study found equivalent outcomes for many subsets of intermediate-risk children who were treated with substantially reduced chemotherapy, compared with the earlier <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003093">

1641COG-A3961 (NCT00003093)</a>

1642 study.[<a href="#cit/section_1.75">

164375</a>

1644]</p>

1645</section>

1646<section id="_311">

1647<h4 id="_311_toc">

1648Age at diagnosis</h4>

1649<section id="_1903">

1650<h5 id="_1903_toc">

1651Infants and children</h5>

1652<p id="_312" tabindex="-1">

1653The effect of age at diagnosis on 5-year survival is profound. In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00904241">

1654ANBL00B1 (NCT00904241)</a>

1655 study of 4,832 patients with newly diagnosed neuroblastoma, those younger than 18 months had a 5-year EFS rate of 82% and an OS rate of 91%. In comparison, patients aged 18 months or older had a 5-year EFS rate of 64% and an OS rate of 74%.[<a href="#cit/section_1.76">

165676</a>

1657] </p>

1658<p id="_2428" tabindex="-1">

1659According to the National Childhood Cancer Registry (NCCR), the

16605-year relative survival rates from 2011 to 2017 were as follows:[<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

16612</a>

1662]</p>

1663<div class="pdq-content-list">

1664<ul id="_591">

1665<li>

1666Aged younger than 1 year: 91%.</li>

1667<li>

1668Aged 1 to 4 years: 79%.</li>

1669<li>

1670Aged 5 to 9 years: 79%.</li>

1671<li>

1672Aged 10 to 14 years: 91%.</li>

1673</ul>

1674</div>

1675<p id="_1119" tabindex="-1">

1676The effect of patient age on prognosis is strongly influenced by clinical and pathobiological factors, as evidenced by the following:</p>

1677<div class="pdq-content-list">

1678<ul id="_1175">

1679<li>

1680Since 2000, nonrandomized studies of low-risk and intermediate-risk patients have demonstrated that patient age has no effect on outcome of INSS stage 1 or stage 2A disease. However, stage 2B patients younger than 18 months had a 5-year OS rate of 99% (&#177; 1%) versus 90% (&#177; 4%) for children aged 18 months and older.[<a href="#cit/section_1.77">

168177</a>

1682]</li>

1683<li>

1684In the COG intermediate-risk study <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003093">

1685A3961 (NCT00003093)</a>

1686 that included only <em class="gene-name">

1687MYCN</em>

1688-nonamplified tumors, infants with INSS stage 3 tumors were compared with children with INSS stage 3 favorable-histology tumors. When INSS stage 3 infants with any histology were compared with stage 3 children with favorable histology, only EFS rates, not OS rates, were significantly different (3-year EFS rate, 95% &#177; 2% vs. 87% &#177; 3%; OS rate, 98% &#177; 1% vs. 99% &#177; 1%).[<a href="#cit/section_1.78">

168978</a>

1690]</li>

1691<li>

1692Infants younger than 12 months with INSS stage 4 disease and <em class="gene-name">

1693MYCN</em>

1694 amplification are categorized as high risk and have a 5-year EFS rate of 37% and an OS rate of 45%.[<a href="#cit/section_1.76">

169576</a>

1696] Toddlers aged 12 months to younger than 18 months with stage 4 disease and <em class="gene-name">

1697MYCN</em>

1698-amplified tumors had a 5-year EFS rate of 53% and an OS rate of 54%.[<a href="#cit/section_1.76">

169976</a>

1700]</li>

1701</ul>

1702</div>

1703</section>

1704<section id="_925">

1705<h5 id="_925_toc">

1706Adolescents and young adults</h5>

1707<p id="_926" tabindex="-1">

1708Adolescents and adults rarely develop neuroblastoma, accounting for less than 5% of all cases. When neuroblastoma occurs in this age range, it shows a more indolent clinical course than neuroblastoma in younger patients, and it shows de novo chemotherapy resistance.[<a href="#cit/section_1.79">

170979</a>

1710] Neuroblastoma in adolescents and young adults may also exhibit unusual clinicopathological characteristics such as large tumors, bilateral adrenal disease, and pheochromocytoma-like features.[<a href="#cit/section_1.80">

171180</a>

1712][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1713Level of evidence C1</a>

1714] Neuroblastoma has a worse long-term prognosis in adolescents older than 10 years or in adults, regardless of stage or site. </p>

1715<p id="_1100" tabindex="-1">

1716Although adolescent and young adult patients have infrequent <em class="gene-name">

1717MYCN</em>

1718 amplification (9% in patients aged 10&#8211;21 years), older children with advanced disease have a poor rate of survival. Tumors from the adolescent and young adult population commonly have segmental chromosomal aberrations, and <em class="gene-name">

1719ALK</em>

1720 and <em class="gene-name">

1721ATRX</em>

1722 mutations are much more frequent.[<a href="#cit/section_1.81">

172381</a>

1724-<a href="#cit/section_1.83">

172583</a>

1726] In adolescents, approximately 40% of the tumors have loss-of-function mutations in <em class="gene-name">

1727ATRX</em>

1728, compared with less than 20% in younger children and 0% in infants younger than 1 year.[<a href="#cit/section_1.79">

172979</a>

1730] Complex DNA microarray findings and novel mutations have been reported in some patients.[<a href="#cit/section_1.80">

173180</a>

1732][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1733Level of evidence C1</a>

1734] </p>

1735<p id="_1101" tabindex="-1">

1736The 5-year OS rate for adolescent and young adult patients (aged 15&#8211;39 years) is 38%.[<a href="#cit/section_1.84">

173784</a>

1738][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1739Level of evidence C1</a>

1740] The 5-year EFS rate is 32% for patients between the ages of 10 years and 21 years, and the OS rate is 46%. For patients with stage 4 disease, the 10-year EFS rate is 3%, and the OS rate is 5%.[<a href="#cit/section_1.85">

174185</a>

1742] Aggressive chemotherapy and surgery have been shown to achieve a minimal disease state in more than 50% of these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_1.38">

174338</a>

1744,<a href="#cit/section_1.86">

174586</a>

1746] Other modalities, such as local radiation therapy, autologous stem cell transplant, and the use of agents with confirmed activity, may improve the poor prognosis for adolescents and adults.[<a href="#cit/section_1.85">

174785</a>

1748,<a href="#cit/section_1.86">

174986</a>

1750]</p>

1751</section>

1752<section id="_1904">

1753<h5 id="_1904_toc">

1754Adults</h5>

1755<p id="_1891" tabindex="-1">

1756The biology of adult-onset neuroblastoma appears to differ from the biology of pediatric or adolescent neuroblastoma based on a single-institution series of 44 patients (aged 18&#8211;71 years).[<a href="#cit/section_1.87">

175787</a>

1758] </p>

1759<div class="pdq-content-list">

1760<ul id="_2474">

1761<li>

1762Genetic abnormalities in adult patients included somatic <em class="gene-name">

1763ATRX</em>

1764 (58%) and <em class="gene-name">

1765ALK</em>

1766 mutations (42%) but no <em class="gene-name">

1767MYCN</em>

1768 amplification. </li>

1769<li>

1770Germline testing was performed in four patients, two of whom had aberrations (one patient with a <em class="gene-name">

1771BRCA1</em>

1772 mutation, the other patient with <em class="gene-name">

1773TP53</em>

1774 and <em class="gene-name">

1775NF1</em>

1776 mutations). </li>

1777<li>

1778In the 11 patients with locoregional disease, the 10-year progression-free survival (PFS) rate was 35%, and the OS rate was 61%. </li>

1779<li>

1780Among 33 adults with stage 4 neuroblastoma, 7 patients (21%) achieved a complete response (CR) after induction chemotherapy and/or surgery. In patients with stage 4 disease at diagnosis, the 5-year PFS rate was 10%, and most patients who were alive with disease at 5 years died of neuroblastoma over the next 5 years. The 10-year OS rate was 19%. CR after induction was the only prognostic factor for PFS and OS. </li>

1781<li>

1782Anti-GD2 immunotherapy (m3F8 or hu3F8) was well tolerated in adults.</li>

1783</ul>

1784</div>

1785</section>

1786</section>

1787<section id="_573">

1788<h4 id="_573_toc">

1789Tumor histology</h4>

1790<p id="_574" tabindex="-1">

1791Neuroblastoma tumor histology has a significant impact on prognosis and risk group assignment. For more information, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_12">

1792Classification of Neuroblastic Tumors</a>

1793 section and <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_780">

1794Table 3</a>

1795.</p>

1796<p id="_2429" tabindex="-1">

1797In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00904241">

1798ANBL00B1 (NCT00904241)</a>

1799 study of 4,832 patients with newly diagnosed neuroblastoma, 52% of patients were classified as favorable and 48% as unfavorable, according to the International Neuroblastoma Pathology Classification (INPC). For patients with tumors classified as favorable, the 5-year EFS rate was 88%, and the 5-year OS rate was 96%. For patients with tumors classified as unfavorable, the 5-year EFS rate was 55%, and the 5-year OS rate was 66% (<em>

1800P</em>

1801 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_1.76">

180276</a>

1803]</p>

1804<p id="_842" tabindex="-1">

1805Histological characteristics considered prognostically favorable include the following: </p>

1806<div class="pdq-content-list">

1807<ul id="_843">

1808<li>

1809Cellular differentiation/maturation. Higher degrees of neuroblastic maturation confer improved prognosis for stage 4 patients with segmental chromosome changes without <em class="gene-name">

1810MYCN</em>

1811 amplification. Neuroblastoma tumors containing many

1812differentiating cells, termed ganglioneuroblastoma, can have diffuse differentiation conferring a very favorable prognosis or can have nodules of undifferentiated cells, termed nodular ganglioneuroblastoma, whose histology, along with <em class="gene-name">

1813MYCN</em>

1814 status, determine prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_1.88">

181588</a>

1816,<a href="#cit/section_1.89">

181789</a>

1818]</li>

1819<li>

1820Schwannian stroma. </li>

1821<li>

1822Cystic neuroblastoma. About 25% of reported neuroblastomas diagnosed in the fetus and neonate are cystic. Patients with cystic neuroblastomas have tumors with lower disease stages and a higher incidence of favorable biology.[<a href="#cit/section_1.90">

182390</a>

1824]</li>

1825</ul>

1826</div>

1827<p id="_844" tabindex="-1">

1828High mitosis/karyorrhexis index and undifferentiated tumor cells are considered prognostically unfavorable histological characteristics, but the prognostic value is age dependent.[<a href="#cit/section_1.91">

182991</a>

1830,<a href="#cit/section_1.92">

183192</a>

1832]</p>

1833<p id="_956" tabindex="-1">

1834A COG study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003119">

1835P9641 [NCT00003119]</a>

1836) investigated the effect of histology, among other factors, on outcome. Of 915 children with stage 1 and stage 2 neuroblastoma without <em class="gene-name">

1837MYCN</em>

1838 amplification, 87% were treated with initial surgery and observation. Patients (13%) who had or were at risk of developing symptomatic disease, or who had less than 50% tumor resection at diagnosis, or who had unresectable progressive disease after surgery alone, were treated with chemotherapy and surgery. Those with favorable histological features reported a 5-year EFS rate of 90% to 94% and an OS rate of 99% to 100%. Those with unfavorable histology had an EFS rate of 80% to 86% and an OS rate of 89% to 93%.[<a href="#cit/section_1.77">

183977</a>

1840] </p>

1841<div class="pdq-content-list">

1842<ul id="_2512">

1843<li>

1844In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00499616">

1845ANBL0531 (NCT00499616)</a>

1846 study for intermediate-risk patients with neuroblastoma, treatment was assigned using a biology-based and response-based algorithm, which included allelic status of 1p36 and 11q23. Patients with <em class="gene-name">

1847MYCN</em>

1848-amplified tumors were excluded.[<a href="#cit/section_1.75">

184975</a>

1850]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1851<ul id="_1991">

1852<li>

1853EFS was statistically significantly better for infants with stage 4 disease with favorable tumor biology (n = 61) (3-year EFS rate, 86.9%; 95% CI, 78.3%&#8211;95.4%), compared with those with confirmed unfavorable tumor biology (n = 47) (3-year EFS rate, 66.8%; 95% CI, 53.1%&#8211;80.6%; <em>

1854P</em>

1855 = .02). </li>

1856<li>

1857OS for infants with stage 4 disease and favorable tumor biology showed a trend toward OS advantage (3-year OS rate, 95.0%; 95% CI, 89.5%&#8211;100% vs. 86.7%; 95% CI, 76.6%&#8211;96.7%; <em>

1858P</em>

1859 = .08). </li>

1860<li>

1861Among the group 4 infants (n = 24) with stage 4 disease with confirmed diploid or unfavorable histology tumors, with or without 1p36/11q23 loss of heterozygosity, the 3-year EFS rate estimate was 63.9% (95% CI, 43.8%&#8211;84.0%), and the 3-year OS rate estimate was 77.3% (95% CI, 59.2%&#8211;95.3%).</li>

1862<li>

1863For infants with stage 4 hyperdiploid favorable histology tumors assigned to group 4 because of 1p36/11q23 loss of heterozygosity or unknown allelic status (n = 32), the 3-year EFS and OS rate estimates were 68.6% (95% CI, 52.2%&#8211;85.1%) and 93.8% (95% CI, 85.2%&#8211;100%), respectively.</li>

1864<li>

1865The EFS and OS rate estimates for the eight toddlers (aged 12&#8211;18 months) with stage 4 hyperdiploid favorable histology tumors were 62.5% (95% CI, 28.9%&#8211;96.1%) and 100%, respectively.</li>

1866<li>

1867Patients with favorable biology and localized disease had a 100% survival rate.</li>

1868</ul>

1869</div>

1870</li>

1871</ul>

1872</div>

1873<p id="_2080" tabindex="-1">

1874A study using data from the INRG Data Commons evaluated the prognostic strength of the underlying INPC histological criteria. The independent prognostic ability of age, histological category, mitosis-karyorrhexis index (MKI), and grade was demonstrated. Four age-related, histological prognostic groups were identified (aged &lt;18 months with low vs. high MKI, and aged &#8805;18 months with differentiated vs. undifferentiated/poorly differentiated tumors). Compared with survival trees generated with established COG risk criteria, an additional prognostic subgroup was identified and validated when individual histological features were analyzed in lieu of INPC. Thus, replacing INPC with individual histological features in the future COG risk classification may eliminate the duplication of the prognostic contribution of age, facilitate international harmonization of risk classification, and provide a schema for more precise prognostication and refined therapeutic approaches.[<a href="#cit/section_1.93">

187593</a>

1876] The INPC is described in the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_12">

1877Classification of Neuroblastic Tumors</a>

1878 section.</p>

1879</section>

1880<section id="_1901">

1881<h4 id="_1901_toc">

1882Biological features</h4>

1883<p id="_1902" tabindex="-1">

1884For more information, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1937">

1885Genomic and Biological Features of Neuroblastoma</a>

1886 section.</p>

1887</section>

1888<section id="_571">

1889<h4 id="_571_toc">

1890Site of primary tumor</h4>

1891<p id="_1080" tabindex="-1">

1892 Clinical and biological features of neuroblastoma differ by primary tumor site. In a study of data on 8,389 patients in clinical trials and compiled by the International Risk Group Project, the following results were observed, confirming the results from much smaller, previous studies with less complete clinical and biological data:[<a href="#cit/section_1.94">

189394</a>

1894]</p>

1895<div class="pdq-content-list">

1896<ul id="_1176">

1897<li>

1898<strong>

1899Adrenal tumors. </strong>

1900Adrenal primary tumors were more likely than tumors originating in other sites to be associated with unfavorable prognostic features, including <em class="gene-name">

1901MYCN</em>

1902 amplification, even after researchers controlled for age, stage, and histological grade. Adrenal neuroblastomas were also associated with a higher incidence of stage 4 tumors, segmental chromosomal aberrations, diploidy, unfavorable INPC histology, age younger than 18 months, and elevated levels of LDH and ferritin. The relative risk of <em class="gene-name">

1903MYCN</em>

1904 amplification compared with adrenal tumors was 0.7 in abdominal nonadrenal tumors and about 0.1 in nonabdominal paraspinal tumors.</li>

1905<li>

1906<strong>

1907Thoracic tumors.</strong>

1908 Thoracic tumors were compared with nonthoracic tumors. After researchers controlled for age, stage, and histological grade, results showed patients with thoracic tumors had fewer deaths and recurrences (HR, 0.79; 95% CI, 0.67&#8211;0.92), and thoracic tumors had a lower incidence of <em class="gene-name">

1909MYCN</em>

1910 amplification (adjusted OR, 0.20; 95% CI, 0.11&#8211;0.39).</li>

1911</ul>

1912</div>

1913<p id="_1938" tabindex="-1">

1914Using the Therapeutically Applicable Research to Generate Effect Treatments (TARGET) and genome-wide association study data sets, a study compared the genomic and epigenomic data of primary diagnostic neuroblastomas originating in the adrenal gland (n = 646) with that of neuroblastomas originating in the thoracic sympathetic ganglia (n = 118). Neuroblastomas arising in the adrenal gland were more likely to harbor structural DNA aberrations such as <em class="gene-name">

1915MYCN</em>

1916 amplification, whereas thoracic tumors showed defects in mitotic checkpoints resulting in hyperdiploidy. Thoracic tumors were more likely to harbor gain-of-function <em class="gene-name">

1917ALK</em>

1918 aberrations than were adrenal tumors among all cases (OR, 1.89; <em>

1919P</em>

1920 = .04), and among cases without <em class="gene-name">

1921MYCN</em>

1922 amplification (OR, 2.86; <em>

1923P</em>

1924 = .003). Because 16% of thoracic tumors harbor <em class="gene-name">

1925ALK</em>

1926 mutations, routine sequencing for these mutations in this setting should be considered.[<a href="#cit/section_1.95">

192795</a>

1928]</p>

1929<p id="_1988" tabindex="-1">

1930In the TARGET cohort, 70% of patients with adrenal primary tumors and 51% of patients with thoracic primary tumors were stage 4. In the genome-wide association study without <em class="gene-name">

1931MYCN</em>

1932 amplification, 43% of patients with adrenal primary tumors and 17% of patients with thoracic primary tumors were stage 4. By multivariate analysis, adrenal site was an independent predictor of worse outcome in the genome-wide association study cohort but not in the TARGET cohort after adjusting for <em class="gene-name">

1933MYCN</em>

1934 amplification status, disease stage, and age of at least 18 months. Adrenal neuroblastoma was not an independent predictor of worse EFS by similar multivariable analysis for either the genome-wide association study or TARGET cohorts.[<a href="#cit/section_1.95">

193595</a>

1936]</p>

1937<p id="_1845" tabindex="-1">

1938It is not clear whether the effect of primary neuroblastoma tumor site on prognosis is entirely dependent on the differences in tumor biology associated with tumor site.</p>

1939<p id="_1165" tabindex="-1">

1940Multifocal neuroblastoma occurs rarely, usually in infants, and generally has a good prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_1.96">

194196</a>

1942] Familial neuroblastoma and germline <em class="gene-name">

1943ALK</em>

1944 gene mutation should be considered in patients with multiple primary neuroblastomas.</p>

1945</section>

1946<section id="_1843">

1947<h4 id="_1843_toc">

1948Stage of disease</h4>

1949<p id="_1844" tabindex="-1">

1950Several imaged-based and surgery-based systems were used for assigning disease stage before the 1990s. In an effort to compare results obtained throughout the world, a surgical pathological staging system, termed the International Neuroblastoma Staging System (INSS), was developed.[<a href="#cit/section_1.59">

195159</a>

1952] The INSS predicted outcome on the basis of stage at diagnosis, although important interactions with biological variables were also found.[<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

19533</a>

1954,<a href="#cit/section_1.4">

19554</a>

1956,<a href="#cit/section_1.10">

195710</a>

1958,<a href="#cit/section_1.14">

195914</a>

1960,<a href="#cit/section_1.59">

196159</a>

1962,<a href="#cit/section_1.77">

196377</a>

1964,<a href="#cit/section_1.78">

196578</a>

1966,<a href="#cit/section_1.97">

196797</a>

1968,<a href="#cit/section_1.98">

196998</a>

1970] However, because surgical approaches differ from one institution to another, INSS stage for patients with locoregional disease may also vary considerably. To define extent of disease at diagnosis in a uniform manner, a presurgical International Neuroblastoma Risk Group staging system (INRGSS) was developed for the International Neuroblastoma Risk Group Classification System.[<a href="#cit/section_1.99">

197199</a>

1972,<a href="#cit/section_1.100">

1973100</a>

1974] The INRGSS is currently used in North American and European cooperative group studies. This staging system is not affected by locoregional lymph node involvement.</p>

1975<p id="_2430" tabindex="-1">

1976For the patients with newly diagnosed neuroblastoma enrolled in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00904241">

1977ANBL00B1 (NCT00904241)</a>

1978 study, the 5-years EFS and OS rates, according to INRGSS stage, were the following:[<a href="#cit/section_1.76">

197976</a>

1980]</p>

1981<div class="pdq-content-list">

1982<ul id="_2448">

1983<li>

198490% and 98% for patients with stage L1 disease.</li>

1985<li>

198684% and 95% for patients with stage L2 disease.</li>

1987<li>

198852% and 64% for patients with stage M disease.</li>

1989<li>

199086% and 92% for patients with stage MS disease.</li>

1991</ul>

1992</div>

1993<p id="_2028" tabindex="-1">

1994For more information, see the following sections:</p>

1995<div class="pdq-content-list">

1996<ul id="_2029">

1997<li>

1998<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_830">

1999International Neuroblastoma Staging System (INSS)</a>

2000.</li>

2001<li>

2002<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_834">

2003International Neuroblastoma Risk Group Staging System (INRGSS)</a>

2004.</li>

2005<li>

2006<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_761">

2007Treatment Options for Low-Risk Neuroblastoma, Evidence (for removal of chemotherapy)</a>

2008.</li>

2009<li>

2010<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_645">

2011Treatment Options for Intermediate-Risk Neuroblastoma, Evidence (chemotherapy with or without surgery)</a>

2012.</li>

2013<li>

2014<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_656">

2015Treatment Options for Intermediate-Risk Neuroblastoma, Radiation therapy</a>

2016.</li>

2017<li>

2018<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_707">

2019Treatment Options for High-Risk Neuroblastoma</a>

2020.</li>

2021<li>

2022<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_937">

2023Treatment Options for Stage 4S/MS Neuroblastoma</a>

2024.</li>

2025</ul>

2026</div>

2027</section>

2028<section id="_577">

2029<h4 id="_577_toc">

2030Response to treatment</h4>

2031<p id="_578" tabindex="-1">

2032Response to treatment has been associated with outcome. In patients with intermediate-risk disease who had a poor response to initial therapy in the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00499616">

2033ANBL0531 (NCT00499616)</a>

2034 study, 6 of 20 patients subsequently developed progressive or recurrent disease, and one patient died.[<a href="#cit/section_1.75">

203575</a>

2036] </p>

2037<p id="_2475" tabindex="-1">

2038In patients with high-risk disease, the persistence of neuroblastoma cells in bone marrow after induction chemotherapy, for example, is associated with a poor prognosis. Sensitive techniques that detect minimal residual disease may be used to assess prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_1.101">

2039101</a>

2040-<a href="#cit/section_1.103">

2041103</a>

2042] Similarly, the persistence of MIBG-avid tumor measured as Curie score greater than 2 after completion of induction therapy predicts a poor prognosis for patients with <em class="gene-name">

2043MYCN</em>

2044-nonamplified high-risk tumors. A Curie score greater than 0 after induction therapy is associated with a worse outcome for high-risk patients with <em class="gene-name">

2045MYCN</em>

2046-amplified disease.[<a href="#cit/section_1.104">

2047104</a>

2048,<a href="#cit/section_1.105">

2049105</a>

2050] An analysis of North American patients who went on to receive tandem transplants showed that patients with Curie scores greater than 0 at the end of induction therapy had inferior EFS rates.[<a href="#cit/section_1.106">

2051106</a>

2052] For more information about Curie scoring, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_890">

2053Curie and SIOPEN scoring methods</a>

2054 section.</p>

2055<p id="_2081" tabindex="-1">

2056In an analysis of patients from four consecutive COG high-risk trials, an end-induction response of partial response (PR) or better, according to the 1993 International Neuroblastoma Response Criteria,[<a href="#cit/section_1.59">

205759</a>

2058] was significantly associated with higher EFS and OS. On multivariable analysis (n = 407), the absence of 11q loss of heterozygosity (LOH) was the only factor that remained significantly associated with PR or better (OR, 1.962 vs. 11q LOH; 95% CI, 1.104&#8211;3.487; <em>

2059P</em>

2060 = .0216).[<a href="#cit/section_1.107">

2061107</a>

2062]</p>

2063<p id="_1846" tabindex="-1">

2064A treatment-associated decrease in mitosis and an increase in histological differentiation of the primary tumor are also prognostic of response.[<a href="#cit/section_1.108">

2065108</a>

2066]</p>

2067<p id="_1166" tabindex="-1">

2068The accuracy of prognostication based on decrease in primary tumor size is less clear. In a study conducted by seven large international centers, 229 high-risk patients were treated in a variety of ways. Treatment included chemotherapy, surgical removal of the primary tumor, radiation to the tumor bed, high-dose myeloablative therapy plus stem cell transplant, and, in most cases, isotretinoin and anti-GD2 antibody immunotherapy enhanced by cytokines. Primary tumor response was measured after induction chemotherapy in three ways: as 30% or greater reduction in the longest dimension, 50% or greater reduction in tumor volume, or 65% or greater reduction in tumor volume (calculated from three tumor dimensions, a conventional radiological technique). The measurements were performed at diagnosis and after induction chemotherapy before primary tumor resection. None of the methods of measuring primary tumor response at end of induction chemotherapy predicted survival.[<a href="#cit/section_1.109">

2069109</a>

2070]</p>

2071</section>

2072<section id="_2050">

2073<h4 id="_2050_toc">

2074Levels of LDH and ferritin</h4>

2075<p id="_2051" tabindex="-1">

2076Higher serum LDH and ferritin values conferred worse 5-year EFS and OS rates in a large international cohort of patients diagnosed with neuroblastoma (n &gt; 8,575) from 1990 to 2016. Higher serum values for LDH and ferritin also conferred worse 3-year EFS and OS rates in patients with high-risk neuroblastoma after 2009. In a multivariate analysis that adjusted for age at diagnosis, <em class="gene-name">

2077MYCN</em>

2078 status, and INSS stage 4 disease, LDH and ferritin maintained independent prognostic ability (<em>

2079P</em>

2080 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_1.110">

2081110</a>

2082][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2083Level of evidence C1</a>

2084]</p>

2085<p id="_2044" tabindex="-1">

2086Although not critically evaluated in the original INRG classification system, subsequent analysis of the INRG Data Commons has clearly demonstrated independent statistical significance of the levels of serum ferritin and LDH on prognosis in all patients and in high-risk patients, including in the time period between 2010 and 2016. Therefore, it was suggested that these two easily obtainable lab values be incorporated into the prognostic classification system of the INRG.[<a href="#cit/section_1.110">

2087110</a>

2088]</p>

2089</section>

2090</section>
