2539

2540

2541 <section id="_1937">

2542

2543 <h2>

2544Genomic and Biological Features of Neuroblastoma</h2>

2545

2546 <div id="_section_1937" class="pdq-sections">

2547<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

2548<h6>

2549In This Section</h6>

2550<ul>

2551<li>

2552<a href="#_sm_CDR0000777852_1_toc">

2553Molecular features of neuroblastoma<ul>

2554<li>

2555<a href="#_sm_CDR0000777852_1124_toc">

2556Segmental chromosomal aberrations</a>

2557</li>

2558<li>

2559<a href="#_sm_CDR0000777852_1171_toc">

2560<em class="gene-name">

2561MYCN</em>

2562 gene amplification</a>

2563</li>

2564<li>

2565<a href="#_sm_CDR0000777852_1191_toc">

2566 <em class="gene-name">

2567FOXR2</em>

2568 activation</a>

2569</li>

2570<li>

2571<a href="#_sm_CDR0000777852_1129_toc">

2572Exonic mutations in neuroblastoma (including <em class="gene-name">

2573ALK</em>

2574 mutations and amplification)</a>

2575</li>

2576<li>

2577<a href="#_sm_CDR0000777852_1137_toc">

2578Genomic alterations promoting telomere maintenance</a>

2579</li>

2580<li>

2581<a href="#_sm_CDR0000777852_1148_toc">

2582Additional biological factors associated with prognosis</a>

2583</li>

2584</ul>

2585</a>

2586</li>

2587</ul>

2588</nav>

2589<section id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1">

2590<h3 id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1_toc">

2591Molecular features of neuroblastoma</h3>

2592<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_3" tabindex="-1">

2593Children with neuroblastoma can be divided into subsets with different predicted risks of relapse on the basis of clinical factors and biological markers at the time of diagnosis. </p>

2594<div class="pdq-content-list">

2595<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1176">

2596<li>

2597<strong>

2598Low-risk or intermediate-risk neuroblastoma patients.</strong>

2599 Patients classified as low risk or intermediate risk have a favorable prognosis, with survival rates exceeding 95%. Low-risk and intermediate-risk neuroblastoma usually occur in children younger than 18 months. These tumors commonly have gains of whole chromosomes and are hyperdiploid when examined by flow cytometry.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

26001</a>

2601,<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

26022</a>

2603]</li>

2604<li>

2605<strong>

2606High-risk neuroblastoma patients.</strong>

2607 The prognosis is more guarded for patients with high-risk neuroblastoma, with a long-term survival rate of less than 50%. High-risk neuroblastoma generally occurs in children older than 18 months and is often metastatic to bone and bone marrow. Segmental chromosome abnormalities (gains or losses) and/or <em class="gene-name">

2608MYCN</em>

2609 gene amplification are usually detected in these tumors. They are near diploid or near tetraploid by flow cytometric measurement.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

26101</a>

2611-<a href="#cit/section_2.7">

26127</a>

2613] High-risk tumors may rarely harbor exonic mutations, but most high-risk tumors lack such gene mutations. For more information, see the Exonic Mutations in Neuroblastoma section. </li>

2614</ul>

2615</div>

2616<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1122" tabindex="-1">

2617Key genomic characteristics of high-risk neuroblastoma that are discussed below include the following:</p>

2618<div class="pdq-content-list">

2619<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1123">

2620<li>

2621Segmental chromosomal aberrations.</li>

2622<li>

2623<em class="gene-name">

2624MYCN</em>

2625 gene amplifications.</li>

2626<li>

2627<em class="gene-name">

2628FOXR2</em>

2629 activation.</li>

2630<li>

2631Low rates of exonic mutations, with activating mutations in <em class="gene-name">

2632ALK</em>

2633 being the most common recurring alteration.</li>

2634<li>

2635Genomic alterations that promote telomere maintenance.</li>

2636</ul>

2637</div>

2638<section id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1124">

2639<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1124_toc">

2640Segmental chromosomal aberrations</h4>

2641<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1125" tabindex="-1">

2642Segmental chromosomal aberrations, found most frequently in 1p, 2p, 1q, 3p, 11q, 14q, and 17p, are best detected by comparative genomic hybridization. These aberrations are seen in most high-risk and/or stage 4 neuroblastoma tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.3">

26433</a>

2644,<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

26454</a>

2646,<a href="#cit/section_2.6">

26476</a>

2648-<a href="#cit/section_2.8">

26498</a>

2650] Among all patients with neuroblastoma, a higher number of chromosome breakpoints (i.e., a higher number of segmental chromosome aberrations) correlated with the following:[<a href="#cit/section_2.3">

26513</a>

2652-<a href="#cit/section_2.7">

26537</a>

2654][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2655Level of evidence C2</a>

2656]</p>

2657<div class="pdq-content-list">

2658<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1152">

2659<li>

2660Advanced age at diagnosis.</li>

2661<li>

2662Advanced stage of disease.</li>

2663<li>

2664Higher risk of relapse.</li>

2665<li>

2666Poorer outcome. </li>

2667</ul>

2668</div>

2669<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1187" tabindex="-1">

2670In an analysis of localized, resectable, non-<em class="gene-name">

2671MYCN</em>

2672 amplified neuroblastoma, cases from two consecutive European studies and a North American cohort (including INSS stages 1, 2A, and 2B) were analyzed for segmental chromosome aberrations (namely gain of 1q, 2p, and 17q and loss of 1p, 3p, 4p, and 11q). The study revealed a different prognostic impact of tumor genomics depending on patient age (&lt;18 months or &gt;18 months). Patients were treated with surgery alone regardless of a tumor residuum.[<a href="#cit/section_2.9">

26739</a>

2674][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2675Level of evidence C1</a>

2676]</p>

2677<div class="pdq-content-list">

2678<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1188">

2679<li>

2680The presence of segmental chromosome aberrations, especially 11q loss, significantly reduced survival in patients older than 18 months with stage 2 neuroblastoma but not in the cohort of patients younger than 18 months.</li>

2681<li>

2682Chromosome 1p loss is a risk factor for relapse but not for diminished overall survival (OS) in patients younger than 18 months. The 5-year event-free survival (EFS) rate was 62% for patients with 1p loss and 87% for patients with no 1p loss (<em>

2683P</em>

2684 = .019). The 5-year OS rate was 92% for patients with 1p loss and 97% for patients with no 1p loss.</li>

2685<li>

2686Segmental chromosome aberrations (especially 11q loss) are risk factors for reduced EFS and OS in patients older than 18 months. In patients younger than 18 months, only segmental chromosome aberrations led to relapse and death, with 11q loss as the strongest marker (11q loss: 5-year EFS rate, 48%; no 11q loss: 5-year EFS rate, 85%; <em>

2687P</em>

2688 = .033; 11q loss: 5-year OS rate, 46%; no 11q loss: 5-year OS rate, 92%; <em>

2689P</em>

2690 = .038).</li>

2691</ul>

2692</div>

2693<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1153" tabindex="-1">

2694In a study of children older than 12 months who had unresectable primary neuroblastomas without metastases, segmental chromosomal aberrations were found in most patients. Older children were more likely to have them and to have more of them per tumor cell. In children aged 12 to 18 months, the presence of segmental chromosomal aberrations had a significant effect on EFS but not on OS. However, in children older than 18 months, there was a significant difference in OS between children with segmental chromosomal aberrations (67%) and children without segmental chromosomal aberrations (100%), regardless of tumor histology.[<a href="#cit/section_2.7">

26957</a>

2696]</p>

2697<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1126" tabindex="-1">

2698Segmental chromosomal aberrations are also predictive of recurrence in infants with localized unresectable or metastatic neuroblastoma without <em class="gene-name">

2699MYCN</em>

2700 gene amplification.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

27011</a>

2702,<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

27032</a>

2704] An analysis of 133 patients (aged &#8805;18 months) with INSS stage 3 tumors without <em class="gene-name">

2705MYCN</em>

2706 amplification demonstrated that segmental chromosomal aberrations were associated with inferior EFS, and 11q loss was independently associated with worse OS.[<a href="#cit/section_2.10">

270710</a>

2708]</p>

2709<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1198" tabindex="-1">

2710In an analysis of intermediate-risk patients in a Children's Oncology Group (COG) study, 11q loss, but not 1p loss, was associated with reduced EFS but not OS (11q loss and no 11q loss: 3-year EFS rates, 68% and 85%, respectively; <em>

2711P</em>

2712 = .022; 3-year OS rates, 88% and 94%, respectively; <em>

2713P</em>

2714 = .09).[<a href="#cit/section_2.11">

271511</a>

2716][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2717Level of evidence B4</a>

2718]</p>

2719<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1206" tabindex="-1">

2720In a multivariable analysis of 407 patients from four consecutive COG high-risk trials, 11q loss of heterozygosity was shown to be a significant predictor of progressive disease, and lack of 11q loss of heterozygosity was associated with both higher rates of end-induction complete response and end-induction partial response.[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

272112</a>

2722][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2723Level of evidence C1</a>

2724]</p>

2725<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1164" tabindex="-1">

2726An international collaboration studied 556 patients with high-risk neuroblastoma and identified two types of segmental copy number aberrations that were associated with extremely poor outcome. Distal 6q losses were found in 6% of patients and were associated with a 10-year survival rate of only 3.4%. Amplifications of regions not encompassing the <em class="gene-name">

2727MYCN</em>

2728 locus, in addition to <em class="gene-name">

2729MYCN</em>

2730 amplification, were detected in 18% of the patients and were associated with a 10-year survival rate of 5.8%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

273113</a>

2732]</p>

2733</section>

2734<section id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1171">

2735<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1171_toc">

2736<em class="gene-name">

2737MYCN</em>

2738 gene amplification</h4>

2739<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1172" tabindex="-1">

2740<em class="gene-name">

2741MYCN</em>

2742 amplification is detected in 16% to 25% of neuroblastoma tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.14">

274314</a>

2744] Among patients with high-risk neuroblastoma, 40% to 50% of cases show <em class="gene-name">

2745MYCN</em>

2746 amplification.[<a href="#cit/section_2.15">

274715</a>

2748] </p>

2749<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1178" tabindex="-1">

2750In all stages of disease, amplification of the <em class="gene-name">

2751MYCN</em>

2752 gene strongly predicts a poorer prognosis, in both time to tumor progression and OS, in almost all multivariate regression analyses of prognostic factors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

27531</a>

2754,<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

27552</a>

2756] In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00904241">

2757ANBL00B1 (NCT00904241)</a>

2758 study of 4,832 newly diagnosed patients enrolled between 2007 to 2017, the 5-year EFS and OS rates were 77% and 87%, respectively, for patients whose tumors were <em class="gene-name">

2759MYCN</em>

2760 nonamplified (n = 3,647; 81%). In comparison, the 5-year EFS and OS rates were 51% and 57%, respectively, for patients whose tumors were <em class="gene-name">

2761MYCN</em>

2762 amplified (n = 827; 19%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.8">

27638</a>

2764]</p>

2765<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1201" tabindex="-1">

2766Within the localized-tumor <em class="gene-name">

2767MYCN</em>

2768-amplified cohort, patients with hyperdiploid tumors have better outcomes than do patients with diploid tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.16">

276916</a>

2770] However, patients with hyperdiploid tumors with <em class="gene-name">

2771MYCN</em>

2772 amplification or any segmental chromosomal aberrations do relatively poorly, compared with patients with hyperdiploid tumors without <em class="gene-name">

2773MYCN</em>

2774 amplification.[<a href="#cit/section_2.3">

27753</a>

2776]</p>

2777<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1174" tabindex="-1">

2778Most unfavorable clinical and pathobiological features are associated, to some degree, with <em class="gene-name">

2779MYCN</em>

2780 amplification. In a multivariable logistic regression analysis of 7,102 patients in the International Neuroblastoma Risk Group (INRG) study, pooled segmental chromosomal aberrations and gains of 17q were poor prognostic features, even when not associated with <em class="gene-name">

2781MYCN</em>

2782 amplification. However, another poor prognostic feature, segmental chromosomal aberrations at 11q, are almost entirely mutually exclusive of <em class="gene-name">

2783MYCN</em>

2784 amplification.[<a href="#cit/section_2.17">

278517</a>

2786,<a href="#cit/section_2.18">

278718</a>

2788]</p>

2789<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1183" tabindex="-1">

2790

2791In a cohort of 6,223 patients from the INRG database with known <em class="gene-name">

2792MYCN</em>

2793 status, the OS hazard ratio (HR) associated with <em class="gene-name">

2794MYCN</em>

2795 amplification was 6.3 (95% confidence interval [CI], 5.7&#8211;7.0; <em>

2796P</em>

2797 &lt; .001). The greatest adverse prognostic impact of <em class="gene-name">

2798MYCN</em>

2799 amplification for OS was in the youngest patients (aged &lt;18 months: HR, 19.6; aged &#8805;18 months: HR, 3.0). Patients whose outcome was most impacted by <em class="gene-name">

2800MYCN</em>

2801 status were those with otherwise favorable features, including age younger than 18 months, high mitosis-karyorrhexis index, and low ferritin.[<a href="#cit/section_2.19">

280219</a>

2803][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2804Level of evidence C1</a>

2805]</p>

2806<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1184" tabindex="-1">

2807Intratumoral heterogeneous <em class="gene-name">

2808MYCN</em>

2809 amplification (hetMNA) refers to the coexistence of <em class="gene-name">

2810MYCN</em>

2811-amplified cells as a cluster or as single scattered cells and non-<em class="gene-name">

2812MYCN</em>

2813&#8211;amplified tumor cells. HetMNA has been reported infrequently. It can occur spatially within the tumor as well as between the tumor and the metastasis at the same time or temporally during the disease course. The International Society of Paediatric Oncology Europe Neuroblastoma (SIOPEN) biology group investigated the prognostic significance of this neuroblastoma subtype. Tumor tissue from 99 patients identified as having hetMNA and diagnosed between 1991 and 2015 was analyzed to elucidate the prognostic significance of <em class="gene-name">

2814MYCN</em>

2815-amplified clones in otherwise non-<em class="gene-name">

2816MYCN</em>

2817&#8211;amplified neuroblastomas. Patients younger than 18 months showed a better outcome in all stages compared with older patients. The genomic background correlated significantly with relapse frequency and OS. No relapses occurred in cases of only numerical chromosomal aberrations. This study suggests that hetMNA tumors be evaluated in the context of the genomic tumor background in combination with the clinical pattern, including the patient's age and disease stage. Future studies are needed in patients younger than 18 months who have localized disease with hetMNA.[<a href="#cit/section_2.20">

281820</a>

2819]</p>

2820</section>

2821<section id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1191">

2822<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1191_toc">

2823 <em class="gene-name">

2824FOXR2</em>

2825 activation</h4>

2826<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1192" tabindex="-1">

2827<em class="gene-name">

2828FOXR2</em>

2829 gene expression is observed in approximately 8% of neuroblastoma cases. <em class="gene-name">

2830FOXR2</em>

2831 gene expression is normally absent postnatally, with the exception of male reproductive tissues.[<a href="#cit/section_2.21">

283221</a>

2833] <em class="gene-name">

2834FOXR2</em>

2835 expression is also observed in a subset of central nervous system (CNS) primitive neuroectodermal tumors, termed CNS NB-<em class="gene-name">

2836FOXR2</em>

2837.[<a href="#cit/section_2.22">

283822</a>

2839] <em class="gene-name">

2840FOXR2</em>

2841 overexpression was virtually mutually exclusive in neuroblastoma tumors with both elevated <em class="gene-name">

2842MYC</em>

2843 and <em class="gene-name">

2844MYCN</em>

2845 expression. Although <em class="gene-name">

2846MYCN</em>

2847 gene expression was not elevated in neuroblastoma with <em class="gene-name">

2848FOXR2</em>

2849 activation, the gene expression profile for the <em class="gene-name">

2850FOXR2</em>

2851 expressing cases closely resembled that of <em class="gene-name">

2852MYCN</em>

2853-amplified neuroblastoma. FOXR2 binds MYCN and appears to stabilize the MYCN protein, leading to high levels of MYCN protein in neuroblastoma with <em class="gene-name">

2854FOXR2</em>

2855 activation. This finding provides an explanation for the similar gene expression profiles for neuroblastoma with <em class="gene-name">

2856FOXR2</em>

2857 activation and neuroblastoma with <em class="gene-name">

2858MYCN</em>

2859 amplification. </p>

2860<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1193" tabindex="-1">

2861Neuroblastoma with <em class="gene-name">

2862FOXR2</em>

2863 activation is observed at comparable rates in high-risk and non&#8211;high-risk cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.21">

286421</a>

2865] Among high-risk cases, outcomes for patients whose tumors showed <em class="gene-name">

2866FOXR2</em>

2867 activation were similar to those for cases with <em class="gene-name">

2868MYCN</em>

2869 amplification. In a multivariable analysis, <em class="gene-name">

2870FOXR2</em>

2871 activation was significantly associated with inferior OS, along with INSS stage 4, age 18 months or older, and <em class="gene-name">

2872MYCN</em>

2873 amplification. </p>

2874</section>

2875<section id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1129">

2876<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1129_toc">

2877Exonic mutations in neuroblastoma (including <em class="gene-name">

2878ALK</em>

2879 mutations and amplification)</h4>

2880<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1130" tabindex="-1">

2881Compared with adult cancers, pediatric neuroblastoma tumors show a low number of mutations per genome that affect protein sequence (10&#8211;20 per genome).[<a href="#cit/section_2.23">

288223</a>

2883] The most commonly mutated gene is <em class="gene-name">

2884ALK</em>

2885, which is mutated in approximately 10% of patients (see below). Other genes with even lower frequencies of mutations include <em class="gene-name">

2886ATRX</em>

2887, <em class="gene-name">

2888PTPN11</em>

2889, <em class="gene-name">

2890ARID1A</em>

2891, and <em class="gene-name">

2892ARID1B</em>

2893.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

289424</a>

2895-<a href="#cit/section_2.30">

289630</a>

2897] As shown in Figure 2, most neuroblastoma cases lack mutations in genes that are altered in a recurrent manner. </p>

2898<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1145" tabindex="-1">

2899<figure id="figure_sm_CDR0000777852_888" class="image-center">

2900<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/777943.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2901Enlarge</a>

2902<img id="_sm_CDR0000777852_888" alt="Chart showing the landscape of genetic variation in neuroblastoma." title="Chart showing the landscape of genetic variation in neuroblastoma." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/777943-750.jpg">

2903<figcaption class="caption-container">

2904Figure 2. Data tracks (rows) facilitate the comparison of clinical and genomic data across cases with neuroblastoma (columns). The data sources and sequencing technology used were whole-exome sequencing (WES) from whole-genome amplification (WGA) (light purple), WES from native DNA (dark purple), Illumina WGS (green), and Complete Genomics WGS (yellow). Striped blocks indicate cases analyzed using two approaches. The clinical variables included were sex (male, blue; female, pink) and age (brown spectrum). Copy number alterations indicates ploidy measured by flow cytometry (with hyperdiploid meaning DNA index &gt;1) and clinically relevant copy number alterations derived from sequence data. Significantly mutated genes are those with statistically significant mutation counts given the background mutation rate, gene size, and expression in neuroblastoma. Germline indicates genes with significant numbers of germline ClinVar variants or loss-of-function cancer gene variants in our cohort. DNA repair indicates genes that may be associated with an increased mutation frequency in two apparently hypermutated tumors. Predicted effects of somatic mutations are color coded according to the legend. Reprinted by permission from Macmillan Publishers Ltd: <a href="http://www.nature.com/ng/index.html" title="http://www.nature.com/ng/index.html">

2905Nature Genetics</a>

2906 (Pugh TJ, Morozova O, Attiyeh EF, et al.: The genetic landscape of high-risk neuroblastoma. Nat Genet 45 (3): 279-84, 2013), copyright (2013).</figcaption>

2907</figure>

2908</p>

2909<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1134" tabindex="-1">

2910The <em class="gene-name">

2911ALK</em>

2912 gene provides instructions for making a cell surface receptor tyrosine kinase, expressed at significant levels only in developing embryonic and neonatal brains. <em class="gene-name">

2913ALK</em>

2914 is the exonic mutation found most commonly in neuroblastoma. Germline mutations in <em class="gene-name">

2915ALK</em>

2916 have been identified as the major cause of hereditary neuroblastoma. Somatically acquired <em class="gene-name">

2917ALK</em>

2918-activating exonic mutations are also found as oncogenic drivers in neuroblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.29">

291929</a>

2920] </p>

2921<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1135" tabindex="-1">

2922Two large cohort studies examined the clinical correlates and prognostic significance of <em class="gene-name">

2923ALK</em>

2924 alterations. One study from the COG examined <em class="gene-name">

2925ALK</em>

2926 status in 1,596 diagnostic neuroblastoma samples across all risk groups.[<a href="#cit/section_2.29">

292729</a>

2928] Another study from SIOPEN evaluated 1,092 patients with high-risk neuroblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.31">

292931</a>

2930] </p>

2931<div class="pdq-content-list">

2932<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1180">

2933<li>

2934<em class="gene-name">

2935ALK</em>

2936 tyrosine kinase domain mutations occurred primarily at three hot spots (F1174, R1275, and F1245 positions), with 10% to 15% of mutations occurring at other kinase domain positions.</li>

2937<li>

2938In the COG cohort, the frequency of <em class="gene-name">

2939ALK</em>

2940 mutations was 10% in the high-risk neuroblastoma group, 8% in the intermediate-risk neuroblastoma group, and 6% in the low-risk neuroblastoma group. </li>

2941<li>

2942In the SIOPEN high-risk population, <em class="gene-name">

2943ALK</em>

2944 mutations were divided into clonal (&gt;20% mutant allele frequency [MAF]) and subclonal (0.1%&#8211;20% MAF). Clonal <em class="gene-name">

2945ALK</em>

2946 mutations were detected in 10% of cases, and subclonal mutations were found in 3.9% of patients. A total of 13.9% of the cases had an <em class="gene-name">

2947ALK</em>

2948 mutation.</li>

2949<li>

2950<em class="gene-name">

2951ALK</em>

2952 mutations were found at higher rates in patients with <em class="gene-name">

2953MYCN</em>

2954-amplified tumors compared with those without <em class="gene-name">

2955MYCN</em>

2956 amplification: 10.9% versus 7.2%, respectively, for the COG cohort and 14% versus 6.5%, respectively, for the SIOPEN cohort (for clonal <em class="gene-name">

2957ALK</em>

2958 mutations). </li>

2959<li>

2960For patients with high-risk neuroblastoma, the <em class="gene-name">

2961ALK</em>

2962 amplification was observed in approximately 4% of cases in both the COG and the SIOPEN cohorts. <em class="gene-name">

2963ALK</em>

2964 amplification occurred almost exclusively in cases that also had <em class="gene-name">

2965MYCN</em>

2966 amplification. </li>

2967<li>

2968<em class="gene-name">

2969ALK</em>

2970 alterations were associated with inferior prognoses for high-risk neuroblastoma patients in both the COG and the SIOPEN studies:<div class="pdq-content-list">

2971<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1194">

2972<li>

2973In the SIOPEN cohort, a statistically significant difference in OS was observed between cases with <em class="gene-name">

2974ALK</em>

2975 amplification (ALKa) or clonal <em class="gene-name">

2976ALK</em>

2977 mutation (ALKm) versus subclonal ALKm or no <em class="gene-name">

2978ALK</em>

2979 alterations (5-year OS rate: ALKa, 26% [95% CI, 10%&#8211;47%]; clonal ALKm, 33% [95% CI, 21%&#8211;44%]; subclonal ALKm, 48% [95% CI, 26%&#8211;67%]; and no alteration, 51% [95% CI, 46%&#8211;55%], respectively; <em>

2980P</em>

2981 = .001). In a multivariate model, <em class="gene-name">

2982ALK</em>

2983 amplification (HR, 2.38; <em>

2984P</em>

2985 = .004) and clonal <em class="gene-name">

2986ALK</em>

2987 mutation (HR, 1.77; <em>

2988P</em>

2989 = .001) were independent predictors of poor outcome.</li>

2990<li>

2991In the COG high-risk neuroblastoma population, inferior prognoses, similar to those seen in the SIOPEN cohort, were observed for cases with <em class="gene-name">

2992ALK</em>

2993 mutations and <em class="gene-name">

2994ALK</em>

2995 amplifications. </li>

2996</ul>

2997</div>

2998</li>

2999</ul>

3000</div>

3001<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1181" tabindex="-1">

3002In a study that compared the genomic data of primary diagnostic neuroblastomas originating in the adrenal gland (n = 646) with that of neuroblastomas originating in the thoracic sympathetic ganglia (n = 118), 16% of thoracic tumors harbored <em class="gene-name">

3003ALK</em>

3004 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.32">

300532</a>

3006]</p>

3007<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1136" tabindex="-1">

3008Small-molecule ALK kinase inhibitors such as lorlatinib (added to conventional therapy) are being tested in patients with recurrent <em class="gene-name">

3009ALK</em>

3010-mutated neuroblastoma (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03107988">

3011NCT03107988</a>

3012) and in patients with newly diagnosed high-risk neuroblastoma with activated <em class="gene-name">

3013ALK</em>

3014 (COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03126916">

3015ANBL1531</a>

3016).[<a href="#cit/section_2.29">

301729</a>

3018] For more information, see the sections on <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_214">

3019Treatment of High-Risk Neuroblastoma</a>

3020 and <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_706">

3021Treatment of Recurrent Neuroblastoma</a>

3022 in Neuroblastoma Treatment.</p>

3023<section id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1149">

3024<h5 id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1149_toc">

3025Genomic evolution of exonic mutations</h5>

3026<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1146" tabindex="-1">

3027There are limited data regarding the genomic evolution of exonic mutations from diagnosis to relapse for neuroblastoma. Whole-genome sequencing was applied to 23 paired diagnostic and relapsed neuroblastoma tumor samples to define somatic genetic alterations associated with relapse,[<a href="#cit/section_2.33">

302833</a>

3029] while a second study evaluated 16 paired diagnostic and relapsed specimens.[<a href="#cit/section_2.34">

303034</a>

3031] Both studies identified an increased number of mutations in the relapsed samples compared with the samples at diagnosis. This has been confirmed in a study of neuroblastoma tumor samples sent for next-generation sequencing.[<a href="#cit/section_2.35">

303235</a>

3033]</p>

3034<div class="pdq-content-list">

3035<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1147">

3036<li>

3037In the first study, an increased incidence of mutations in genes associated with RAS-MAPK signaling was found in tumors at relapse compared with tumors from the same patient at diagnosis; 15 of 23 relapse samples contained somatic mutations in genes involved in this pathway, and each mutation was consistent with pathway activation.[<a href="#cit/section_2.33">

303833</a>

3039] <p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1155" tabindex="-1">

3040In addition, three relapse samples showed structural alterations involving MAPK pathway genes consistent with pathway activation, so aberrations in this pathway were detected in 18 of 23 (78%) relapse samples. Aberrations were found in <em class="gene-name">

3041ALK</em>

3042 (n = 10), <em class="gene-name">

3043NF1</em>

3044 (n = 2), and one each in <em class="gene-name">

3045NRAS</em>

3046, <em class="gene-name">

3047KRAS</em>

3048, <em class="gene-name">

3049HRAS</em>

3050, <em class="gene-name">

3051BRAF</em>

3052, <em class="gene-name">

3053PTPN11</em>

3054, and <em class="gene-name">

3055FGFR1</em>

3056. Even with deep sequencing, 7 of the 18 alterations were not detectable in the primary tumor, highlighting the evolution of mutations presumably leading to relapse and the importance of genomic evaluations of tissues obtained at relapse.</p>

3057</li>

3058<li>

3059In the second study, <em class="gene-name">

3060ALK</em>

3061 mutations were not observed in either diagnostic or relapse specimens, but relapse-specific recurrent single-nucleotide variants were observed in 11 genes, including the putative <em class="gene-name">

3062CHD5</em>

3063 neuroblastoma tumor suppressor gene located at chromosome 1p36.[<a href="#cit/section_2.34">

306434</a>

3065]</li>

3066<li>

3067A third retrospective mutation-sequencing study used data from Foundation Medicine to compare tumor samples from patients with newly diagnosed neuroblastoma with tumor samples from patients with refractory and relapsed neuroblastoma. The study found a higher percentage of mutations that were targetable with current drugs in the relapsed and refractory group.[<a href="#cit/section_2.35">

306835</a>

3069]</li>

3070<li>

3071A fourth study evaluated the frequency of <em class="gene-name">

3072ALK</em>

3073 alterations at diagnosis and relapse. There were significantly higher rates of <em class="gene-name">

3074ALK</em>

3075 mutations at relapse than at diagnosis (17.7% at relapse vs. 10.5% at diagnosis). The rate of <em class="gene-name">

3076ALK</em>

3077 amplifications did not differ between diagnosis and relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_2.36">

307836</a>

3079]</li>

3080</ul>

3081</div>

3082<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1204" tabindex="-1">

3083Given the widespread metastatic nature of high-risk and relapsed neuroblastoma, use of circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) technologies may reveal additional genomic alterations not found in conventional tumor biopsies. Moreover, these approaches have demonstrated the ability to detect resistant mutations in patients with neuroblastoma who were treated with ALK inhibitors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.37">

308437</a>

3085][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3086Level of evidence C1</a>

3087] In one analysis of serial ctDNA samples from patients treated with lorlatinib, <em class="gene-name">

3088ALK</em>

3089 variant allele frequency tracked with disease burden in most but not all patients.[<a href="#cit/section_2.38">

309038</a>

3091] In subsets of patients who progressed while taking lorlatinib, second compound mutations in <em class="gene-name">

3092ALK</em>

3093 or mutations in other genes, including RAS pathway genes, were reported.</p>

3094<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1157" tabindex="-1">

3095In a deep-sequencing study, 276 neuroblastoma samples (comprised of all stages and from patients of all ages at diagnosis) underwent very deep (33,000X) sequencing of just two amplified <em class="gene-name">

3096ALK</em>

3097 mutational hot spots, which revealed 4.8% clonal mutations and an additional 5% subclonal mutations. This finding suggests that subclonal <em class="gene-name">

3098ALK</em>

3099 gene mutations are common.[<a href="#cit/section_2.39">

310039</a>

3101] Thus, deep sequencing can reveal the presence of mutations in tiny subsets of neuroblastoma tumor cells that may be able to survive during treatment and grow to constitute a relapse.</p>

3102</section>

3103</section>

3104<section id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1137">

3105<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1137_toc">

3106Genomic alterations promoting telomere maintenance</h4>

3107<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1138" tabindex="-1">

3108Lengthening of telomeres, the tips of chromosomes, promotes cell survival. Telomeres otherwise shorten with each cell replication, eventually resulting in the cell&#8217;s inability to replicate. Patients whose tumors lack telomere maintenance mechanisms have an excellent prognosis, while patients whose tumors harbored telomere maintenance mechanisms have a substantially worse prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_2.40">

310940</a>

3110] Low-risk neuroblastoma tumors, as defined by clinical/biological features, have little telomere lengthening activity. Aberrant genetic mechanisms for telomere lengthening have been identified in high-risk neuroblastoma tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

311124</a>

3112,<a href="#cit/section_2.25">

311325</a>

3114,<a href="#cit/section_2.40">

311540</a>

3116,<a href="#cit/section_2.41">

311741</a>

3118] Thus far, the following three mechanisms, which appear to be mutually exclusive, have been described:</p>

3119<div class="pdq-content-list">

3120<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1139">

3121<li>

3122Chromosomal rearrangements involving a chromosomal region at 5p15.33 proximal to the <em class="gene-name">

3123TERT</em>

3124 gene, which encodes the catalytic unit of telomerase, occur in approximately 20% to 25% of high-risk neuroblastoma cases and are mutually exclusive with <em class="gene-name">

3125MYCN</em>

3126 amplifications and alternative lengthening of telomeres (ALT) activation.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

312724</a>

3128,<a href="#cit/section_2.25">

312925</a>

3130,<a href="#cit/section_2.41">

313141</a>

3132] The rearrangements induce transcriptional upregulation of <em class="gene-name">

3133TERT</em>

3134 by juxtaposing the <em class="gene-name">

3135TERT</em>

3136 coding sequence with strong enhancer elements. Children whose tumors have <em class="gene-name">

3137TERT</em>

3138 rearrangements have a poor prognosis, which is comparable to the prognosis of children whose tumors have <em class="gene-name">

3139MYCN</em>

3140 amplification.[<a href="#cit/section_2.41">

314141</a>

3142]</li>

3143<li>

3144Another mechanism promoting <em class="gene-name">

3145TERT</em>

3146 overexpression is <em class="gene-name">

3147MYCN</em>

3148 amplification,[<a href="#cit/section_2.42">

314942</a>

3150] which is associated with approximately 40% to 50% of high-risk neuroblastoma cases.</li>

3151<li>

3152ALT is an additional mechanism of telomere maintenance that is used by neuroblastoma tumors. ALT activation is present in approximately 20% to 25% of newly diagnosed high-risk cases, compared with approximately 5% to 12% of low-risk and intermediate-risk cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.41">

315341</a>

3154,<a href="#cit/section_2.43">

315543</a>

3156,<a href="#cit/section_2.44">

315744</a>

3158] Compared with newly diagnosed cases, the proportion of neuroblastoma cases with ALT-positive tumors was higher in a cohort of patients who relapsed (10% vs. 48%, respectively). This finding may reflect the relatively indolent course of tumors with ALT activation after relapse, compared with the clinical course of other tumors after relapse. Over time, the proportion of patients with relapsed ALT-positive neuroblastomas (out of patients with neuroblastoma) appears larger than that of patients with another tumor type who relapsed (out of patients diagnosed with that tumor).[<a href="#cit/section_2.43">

315943</a>

3160] Neuroblastoma cases with ALT activation have low <em class="gene-name">

3161TERT</em>

3162 expression and can be identified by immunohistochemistry for the ALT-associated promyelocytic nuclear body, by FISH with a telomere probe to visualize telomere ultrabright spots, and by the C-circle assay.[<a href="#cit/section_2.43">

316343</a>

3164,<a href="#cit/section_2.44">

316544</a>

3166] Approximately 55% to 60% of ALT-positive cases are characterized by deleterious <em class="gene-name">

3167ATRX</em>

3168 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.26">

316926</a>

3170,<a href="#cit/section_2.43">

317143</a>

3172,<a href="#cit/section_2.44">

317344</a>

3174] Cases lacking <em class="gene-name">

3175ATRX</em>

3176 mutations often show low ATRX protein expression.[<a href="#cit/section_2.43">

317743</a>

3178]<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1196" tabindex="-1">

3179ALT-positive tumors in pediatric populations rarely present before the age of 18 months and occur almost exclusively in older children (median age at diagnosis, approximately 8 years).[<a href="#cit/section_2.41">

318041</a>

3181,<a href="#cit/section_2.43">

318243</a>

3183] The proportion of neuroblastoma cases with <em class="gene-name">

3184ATRX</em>

3185 mutations increases with age into the adolescent and young adult populations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.26">

318626</a>

3187]</p>

3188<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1197" tabindex="-1">

3189The prognosis for high-risk patients with ALT activation is as poor as that for patients with <em class="gene-name">

3190MYCN</em>

3191 amplification for EFS;[<a href="#cit/section_2.41">

319241</a>

3193,<a href="#cit/section_2.43">

319443</a>

3195] however, OS is more favorable for patients with ALT activation. The more favorable OS appears to result from a more protracted disease course after relapse, but with long-term survival at 10 to 15 years being as low as that for other high-risk neuroblastoma patients.[<a href="#cit/section_2.41">

319641</a>

3197,<a href="#cit/section_2.43">

319843</a>

3199] In one report, EFS and OS for low-risk and intermediate-risk patients with ALT activation were similar to those observed for ALT-positive patients with high-risk disease.[<a href="#cit/section_2.43">

320043</a>

3201]</p>

3202</li>

3203</ul>

3204</div>

3205</section>

3206<section id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1148">

3207<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1148_toc">

3208Additional biological factors associated with prognosis</h4>

3209<section id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1140">

3210<h5 id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1140_toc">

3211MYC and MYCN expression</h5>

3212<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1141" tabindex="-1">

3213Immunostaining for MYC and MYCN proteins on a restricted subset of 357 undifferentiated/poorly differentiated neuroblastoma tumors demonstrated that elevated MYC/MYCN protein expression is prognostically significant.[<a href="#cit/section_2.45">

321445</a>

3215] Sixty-eight tumors (19%) highly expressed the MYCN protein, and 81 were <em class="gene-name">

3216MYCN</em>

3217 amplified. Thirty-nine tumors (10.9%) expressed MYC highly and were mutually exclusive of high MYCN expression. In the MYC-expressing tumors, <em class="gene-name">

3218MYC</em>

3219 or <em class="gene-name">

3220MYCN</em>

3221 gene amplification was not seen. Segmental chromosomal aberrations were not examined in this study.[<a href="#cit/section_2.45">

322245</a>

3223]</p>

3224<div class="pdq-content-list">

3225<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1156">

3226<li>

3227 Patients with favorable-histology tumors without high MYC/MYCN expression had favorable survival (3-year EFS rate, 89.7% &#177; 5.5%; 3-year OS rate, 97% &#177; 3.2%).</li>

3228<li>

3229Patients with undifferentiated or poorly differentiated histology tumors without MYC/MYCN expression had a 3-year EFS rate of 63.1% (&#177; 13.6%) and a 3-year OS rate of 83.5% (&#177; 9.4%).</li>

3230<li>

3231Three-year EFS rates in patients with <em class="gene-name">

3232MYCN</em>

3233 amplification, high MYCN expression, and high MYC expression were 48.1% (&#177; 11.5%), 46.2% (&#177; 12%), and 43.4% (&#177; 23.1%), respectively. OS rates were 65.8% (&#177; 11.1%), 63.2% (&#177; 12.1%), and 63.5% (&#177; 19.2%), respectively.</li>

3234<li>

3235Additionally, when high expression of MYC and MYCN proteins underwent multivariate analysis with other prognostic factors, including <em class="gene-name">

3236MYC/MYCN</em>

3237 gene amplification, high MYC and MYCN protein expression was independent of other prognostic markers.</li>

3238</ul>

3239</div>

3240</section>

3241<section id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1143">

3242<h5 id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1143_toc">

3243Neurotrophin receptor kinases</h5>

3244<p id="_sm_CDR0000777852_1144" tabindex="-1">

3245Expression of neurotrophin receptor kinases and their ligands vary between high-risk and low-risk tumors. TrkA is found on low-risk tumors, and absence of its ligand NGF is postulated to lead to spontaneous tumor regression. In contrast, TrkB is found in high-risk tumors that also express its ligand, BDNF, which promotes neuroblastoma cell growth and survival.[<a href="#cit/section_2.46">

324646</a>

3247]</p>

3248</section>

3249</section>

3250</section>

3302<li id="section_2.13">

3303Depuydt P, Boeva V, Hocking TD, et al.: Genomic Amplifications and Distal 6q Loss: Novel Markers for Poor Survival in High-risk Neuroblastoma Patients. J Natl Cancer Inst 110 (10): 1084-1093, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29514301&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29514301&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3304[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3305</li>

3306<li id="section_2.14">

3307Ambros PF, Ambros IM, Brodeur GM, et al.: International consensus for neuroblastoma molecular diagnostics: report from the International Neuroblastoma Risk Group (INRG) Biology Committee. 3308[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3309</li>

Lancet Oncol 14 (10): 999-1008, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23890779&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23890779&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3438

3439 </section>

3440

3441

3442

3443 <section id="_12">

3444

3445 <h2>

3446Classification of Neuroblastic Tumors</h2>

3447

3448 <div id="_section_12" class="pdq-sections">

3449<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

3450<h6>

3451In This Section</h6>

3452<ul>

3453<li>

3454<a href="#_1149_toc">

3455International Neuroblastoma Pathology Classification (INPC) System</a>

3456</li>

3457<li>

3458<a href="#_1156_toc">

3459International Neuroblastoma Risk Group (INRG) Classification System</a>

3460</li>

3461</ul>

3462</nav>

3463<p id="_735" tabindex="-1">

3464Neuroblastomas are classified as one of the small round blue cell tumors of childhood. They are a heterogenous group of tumors composed of cellular aggregates with different degrees of differentiation, from mature ganglioneuromas to less mature ganglioneuroblastomas to immature neuroblastomas, reflecting the varying malignant potential of these tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

34651</a>

3466] </p>

3467<p id="_826" tabindex="-1">

3468There are two classification systems for neuroblastoma:</p>

3469<div class="pdq-content-list">

3470<ul id="_1177">

3471<li>

3472<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1149">

3473International Neuroblastoma Pathology Classification (INPC) System</a>

3474.</li>

3475<li>

3476<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1156">

3477International Neuroblastoma Risk Group (INRG) Classification System</a>

3478.</li>

3479</ul>

3480</div>

3481<section id="_1149">

3482<h3 id="_1149_toc">

3483International Neuroblastoma Pathology Classification (INPC) System</h3>

3484<p id="_1150" tabindex="-1">

3485The INPC system was derived from the experience with the original Shimada classification, and the two systems are compared in <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1154">

3486Table 1</a>

3487. The INPC involves evaluation

3488of tumor specimens obtained before therapy for the following morphological features:[<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

34892</a>

3490-<a href="#cit/section_3.6">

34916</a>

3492]</p>

3493<div class="pdq-content-list">

3494<ul id="_1151">

3495<li>

3496Amount of Schwannian stroma.</li>

3497<li>

3498Degree of

3499neuroblastic maturation.</li>

3500<li>

3501Mitosis-karyorrhexis index (MKI) of the neuroblastic

3502cells. </li>

3503</ul>

3504</div>

3505<p id="_1152" tabindex="-1">

3506Favorable and unfavorable prognoses are defined on the basis of

3507these histological parameters and patient age. The prognostic significance of

3508this classification system, and of related systems using similar criteria, has

3509been confirmed in several studies (see <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1154">

3510Table 1</a>

3511).[<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

35122</a>

3513-<a href="#cit/section_3.4">

35144</a>

3515,<a href="#cit/section_3.6">

35166</a>

3517]</p>

3518<table id="_1154" class="table-default expandable-container">

3519<caption>

3520Table 1. Prognostic Evaluation of Neuroblastic Tumors According to the International Neuroblastoma Pathology Classification (Shimada System)<span class="sup">

3521a</span>

3522</caption>

3523<colgroup>

3524<col width="6.07%">

3525<col width="4.24%">

3526<col width="20.61%">

3527<col width="27.49%">

3528<col width="18.61%">

3529<col width="22.94%">

3530</colgroup>

3531<THead>

3532<tr>

3533<th colspan="4">

3534International Neuroblastoma Pathology Classification</th>

3535<th>

3536Original Shimada Classification</th>

3537<th>

3538Prognostic Group</th>

3539</tr>

3540</THead>

3541<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

3542<tr>

3543<td colspan="6">

3544MKI = mitosis-karyorrhexis index.</td>

3545</tr>

3546<tr>

3547<td colspan="6">

3548<span class="sup">

3549a</span>

3550Reprinted with permission. Copyright &#169; 1999 American Cancer Society. All rights reserved.[<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

35512</a>

3552] Hiroyuki Shimada, Inge M. Ambros,

3553Louis P. Dehner,

3554Jun-ichi Hata, Vijay V. Joshi,

3555Borghild Roald, Daniel O. Stram, Robert B. Gerbing,

3556John N. Lukens,

3557Katherine K. Matthay,

3558Robert P. Castleberry, The International Neuroblastoma Pathology

3559Classification (the Shimada System), Cancer, volume 86, issue 2, pages 364&#8211;72. </td>

3560</tr>

3561<tr>

3562<td colspan="6">

3563<span class="sup">

3564b</span>

3565Subtypes of neuroblastoma are described in detail elsewhere.[<a href="#cit/section_3.7">

35667</a>

3567]</td>

3568</tr>

3569<tr>

3570<td colspan="6">

3571<span class="sup">

3572c</span>

3573Rare subtype, especially diagnosed in this age group. Further investigation and analysis required.</td>

3574</tr>

3575<tr>

3576<td colspan="6">

3577<span class="sup">

3578d</span>

3579Prognostic grouping for these tumor categories is not related to patient age.</td>

3580</tr>

3581</TFoot>

3582<tbody>

3583<tr>

3584<td colspan="3">

3585Neuroblastoma: </td>

3586<td>

3587(Schwannian stroma-poor)<span class="sup">

3588b</span>

3589 </td>

3590<td>

3591Stroma-poor</td>

3592<td>

3593&#160;</td>

3594</tr>

3595<tr>

3596<td>

3597&#160;</td>

3598<td colspan="3">

3599Favorable:</td>

3600<td>

3601Favorable</td>

3602<td>

3603Favorable</td>

3604</tr>

3605<tr>

3606<td colspan="2">

3607&#160;</td>

3608<td>

3609&lt;1.5 y</td>

3610<td>

3611Poorly differentiated or differentiating

3612 &amp; low or intermediate MKI tumor</td>

3613<td>

3614&#160;</td>

3615<td>

3616&#160;</td>

3617</tr>

3618<tr>

3619<td colspan="2">

3620&#160;</td>

3621<td>

36221.5&#8211;5 y</td>

3623<td>

3624Differentiating &amp; low MKI tumor</td>

3625<td>

3626&#160;</td>

3627<td>

3628&#160;</td>

3629</tr>

3630<tr>

3631<td>

3632&#160;</td>

3633<td colspan="3">

3634Unfavorable:</td>

3635<td>

3636Unfavorable</td>

3637<td>

3638Unfavorable</td>

3639</tr>

3640<tr>

3641<td rowspan="2" colspan="2">

3642&#160;</td>

3643<td rowspan="2">

3644&lt;1.5 y</td>

3645<td>

3646a) undifferentiated tumor<span class="sup">

3647c</span>

3648</td>

3649<td rowspan="2">

3650&#160;</td>

3651<td rowspan="2">

3652&#160;</td>

3653</tr>

3654<tr>

3655<td>

3656b) high MKI tumor</td>

3657</tr>

3658<tr>

3659<td rowspan="2" colspan="2">

3660&#160;</td>

3661<td rowspan="2">

36621.5&#8211;5 y</td>

3663<td>

3664a) undifferentiated or poorly

3665differentiated tumor</td>

3666<td rowspan="2">

3667&#160;</td>

3668<td rowspan="2">

3669&#160;</td>

3670</tr>

3671<tr>

3672<td>

3673b) intermediate or high MKI tumor</td>

3674</tr>

3675<tr>

3676<td colspan="2">

3677&#160;</td>

3678<td>

3679&#8805;5 y</td>

3680<td>

3681All tumors</td>

3682<td>

3683&#160;</td>

3684<td>

3685&#160;</td>

3686</tr>

3687<tr>

3688<td colspan="3">

3689Ganglioneuroblastoma, intermixed </td>

3690<td>

3691(Schwannian stroma-rich) </td>

3692<td>

3693Stroma-rich intermixed

3694(favorable)

3695</td>

3696<td>

3697Favorable<span class="sup">

3698d</span>

3699</td>

3700</tr>

3701<tr>

3702<td colspan="3">

3703Ganglioneuroma: </td>

3704<td>

3705(Schwannian stroma-dominant)</td>

3706<td>

3707&#160;</td>

3708<td>

3709&#160;</td>

3710</tr>

3711<tr>

3712<td>

3713&#160;</td>

3714<td colspan="2">

3715Maturing </td>

3716<td>

3717&#160;</td>

3718<td>

3719Well differentiated (favorable) </td>

3720<td>

3721Favorable<span class="sup">

3722d</span>

3723</td>

3724</tr>

3725<tr>

3726<td>

3727&#160;</td>

3728<td colspan="2">

3729Mature </td>

3730<td>

3731&#160;</td>

3732<td>

3733Ganglioneuroma</td>

3734<td>

3735&#160;</td>

3736</tr>

3737<tr>

3738<td colspan="3">

3739Ganglioneuroblastoma, nodular </td>

3740<td>

3741(composite Schwannian stroma-rich/stroma-dominate and stroma-poor)

3742</td>

3743<td>

3744Stroma-rich nodular (unfavorable) </td>

3745<td>

3746Unfavorable<span class="sup">

3747d</span>

3748</td>

3749</tr>

3750</tbody>

3751</table>

3752<p id="_1155" tabindex="-1">

3753Most neuroblastomas with <em class="gene-name">

3754MYCN</em>

3755 amplification have unfavorable INPC histology, but about 7% of tumors have favorable histology. The tumors generally do not express MYCN, even with the gene being amplified, and these patients have a more favorable prognosis than do patients whose tumors are <em class="gene-name">

3756MYCN</em>

3757 amplified and overexpress MYCN.[<a href="#cit/section_3.8">

37588</a>

3759]</p>

3760<p id="_2043" tabindex="-1">

3761The individual components of INPC data from the INRG Data Commons (18,865 patients) were analyzed, and the analysis validated the independent prognostic ability of age at diagnosis, histological category, MKI, and grade of differentiation. Four histological prognostic groups of patients were identified (aged &lt;18 months with low vs. high MKI; aged &gt;18 months with differentiating vs. undifferentiating/poorly differentiating tumors). Also, by using a risk schema devoid of the confounding of age and INPC, this analysis identified a novel and unfavorable subgroup of patients older than 547 days with stage 1 or 2, <em class="gene-name">

3762MYCN</em>

3763-nonamplified, intermediate or high MKI diploid tumors who had a very poor event-free survival (EFS) rate (EFS rate, 46%).[<a href="#cit/section_3.9">

37649</a>

3765][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3766Level of evidence C1</a>

3767]</p>

3768</section>

3769<section id="_1156">

3770<h3 id="_1156_toc">

3771International Neuroblastoma Risk Group (INRG) Classification System</h3>

3772<p id="_1157" tabindex="-1">

3773 The INRG used a survival-tree analysis to compare 35 prognostic factors in more than 8,800 patients with neuroblastoma from a variety of clinical trials. The underlying histological features in the INPC (Shimada system) were included in the analysis:[<a href="#cit/section_3.10">

377410</a>

3775,<a href="#cit/section_3.11">

377611</a>

3777]</p>

3778<div class="pdq-content-list">

3779<ul id="_1158">

3780<li>

3781Diagnostic category.</li>

3782<li>

3783Grade of differentiation.</li>

3784<li>

3785MKI. </li>

3786</ul>

3787</div>

3788<p id="_1159" tabindex="-1">

3789Because patient age is used in all risk stratification systems, a cellular classification system that did not employ patient age was desirable, and underlying histological criteria, rather than INPC or Shimada Classification, was used in the final decision tree. Histological findings discriminated prognostic groups most clearly in two subsets of patients, as shown in <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1160">

3790Table 2</a>

3791.</p>

3792<table id="_1160" class="table-default expandable-container">

3793<caption>

3794Table 2. Histological Discrimination of International Neuroblastoma Risk Group Subsets of Neuroblastoma Patients<span class="sup">

3795a</span>

3796</caption>

3798<col width="8.01%">

3799<col width="35.57%">

3800<col width="18.66%">

3801<col width="18.66%">

3802<col width="19.07%">

3803</colgroup>

3813OS (%)</th>

3907</tbody>

3908</table>

3909<p id="_1132" tabindex="-1">

3910The INRG histological subsets are incorporated into the INRG Risk Classification Schema. For more information, see <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1145">

3911Table 4</a>

3912.</p>

3913</section>
