3966

3967

3968 <section id="_14">

3969

3970 <h2>

3971Stage Information for Neuroblastoma</h2>

3972

3973 <div id="_section_14" class="pdq-sections">

3974<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

3975<h6>

3976In This Section</h6>

3977<ul>

3978<li>

3979<a href="#_593_toc">

3980Staging Evaluation<ul>

3981<li>

3982<a href="#_927_toc">

3983Metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) scan</a>

3984</li>

3985<li>

3986<a href="#_1906_toc">

3987PET scan</a>

3988</li>

3989<li>

3990<a href="#_931_toc">

3991Other staging tests and procedures</a>

3992</li>

3993</ul>

3994</a>

3995</li>

3996<li>

3997<a href="#_185_toc">

3998Neuroblastoma Staging Systems<ul>

3999<li>

4000<a href="#_830_toc">

4001International Neuroblastoma Staging System (INSS)</a>

4002</li>

4003<li>

4004<a href="#_834_toc">

4005International Neuroblastoma Risk Group Staging System (INRGSS)</a>

4006</li>

4007<li>

4008<a href="#_17_toc">

4009Children&#8217;s Oncology Group (COG) Neuroblastoma Risk Grouping</a>

4010</li>

4011<li>

4012<a href="#_1134_toc">

4013International Neuroblastoma Risk Grouping (INRG)</a>

4014</li>

4015</ul>

4016</a>

4017</li>

4018</ul>

4019</nav>

4020<section id="_593">

4021<h3 id="_593_toc">

4022Staging Evaluation</h3>

4023<p id="_594" tabindex="-1">

4024Approximately 70% of patients with neuroblastoma have metastatic disease at diagnosis. A thorough evaluation for metastatic disease is performed before

4025therapy initiation. The studies described below are typically performed.[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

40261</a>

4027]</p>

4028<section id="_927">

4029<h4 id="_927_toc">

4030Metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) scan</h4>

4031<p id="_928" tabindex="-1">

4032The extent of metastatic disease is assessed by MIBG scan, which is applicable to all sites of disease, including soft tissue, bone marrow, and cortical bone. Approximately 90% of neuroblastomas will be MIBG avid. The MIBG scan has a sensitivity and specificity of 90% to 99%, and MIBG avidity is equally distributed between primary and metastatic sites.[<a href="#cit/section_4.2">

40332</a>

4034] Although iodine I 123 (123I) has a shorter half-life, it is preferred over 131I because of its lower radiation dose, better quality images, reduced thyroid toxicity, and lower cost. </p>

4035<p id="_929" tabindex="-1">

4036 Imaging with 123I-MIBG is optimal for identifying soft tissue and bony metastases. It was shown to be superior to positron emission tomography&#8211;computed tomography (PET-CT) in one prospective comparison.[<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

40373</a>

4038] In a retrospective review of 132 children with neuroblastoma, technetium Tc 99m-methylene diphosphonate (99mTc-MDP) bone scintigraphy failed to identify unique sites of metastatic disease that would change the disease stage or clinical management determined using 123I-MIBG or PET scanning. It was concluded that bone scans can be omitted in most cases.[<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

40394</a>

4040] </p>

4041<p id="_1905" tabindex="-1">

4042Baseline MIBG scans performed at diagnosis provide an excellent method for monitoring disease response and performing posttherapy surveillance.[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

40435</a>

4044] A retrospective analysis of paired 123I-MIBG and PET scans in 60 patients with newly diagnosed neuroblastoma demonstrated that for International Neuroblastoma Staging System (INSS) stage 1 and stage 2 patients, PET was superior at determining the extent of primary disease and more sensitive for detection of residual masses. In contrast, for stage 4 disease, 123I-MIBG imaging was superior for the detection of bone marrow and bony metastases.[<a href="#cit/section_4.6">

40456</a>

4046] </p>

4047<section id="_890">

4048<h5 id="_890_toc">

4049Curie and SIOPEN scoring methods</h5>

4050<p id="_891" tabindex="-1">

4051Multiple groups have investigated a semiquantitative scoring method to evaluate disease extent and prognostic value. The most common scoring methods in use for evaluation of disease extent and response are the Curie and the International Society of Paediatric Oncology Europe Neuroblastoma (SIOPEN) methods. </p>

4052<div class="pdq-content-list">

4053<ul id="_892">

4054<li>

4055<strong>

4056Curie scoring method:</strong>

4057 The Curie score is a semiquantitative scoring system developed to predict the extent and severity of MIBG-avid disease. The use of the Curie scoring system was assessed as a prognostic marker for response and survival with MIBG-avid, stage 4, newly diagnosed, high-risk neuroblastoma (N = 280), treated on the Children&#8217;s Oncology Group (COG) protocol <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00004188">

4058COG-A3973 (NCT00004188)</a>

4059. For patients with <em class="gene-name">

4060MYCN</em>

4061-nonamplified neuroblastoma, a postinduction chemotherapy Curie score greater than 2 was associated with a higher risk of an event, independent of other known neuroblastoma clinical and biological factors, including age, <em class="gene-name">

4062MYCN</em>

4063 status, ploidy, mitosis-karyorrhexis index, and histological grade.[<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

40647</a>

4065] For patients with <em class="gene-name">

4066MYCN</em>

4067-amplified tumors, a postinduction Curie score greater than 0 was associated with worse outcomes.<p id="_1847" tabindex="-1">

4068The prognostic significance of postinduction Curie scores has been validated in an independent cohort of patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

40698</a>

4070] A retrospective study of Curie scoring of 123I-MIBG scans obtained from high-risk patients who had been prospectively enrolled in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00030719">

4071SIOPEN/HR-NBL1 (NCT00030719)</a>

4072 trial was performed. Scans of ten anatomical regions were evaluated, with each region being scored 0 to 3 on the basis of disease extent, and a cumulative Curie score generated. The optimal prognostic cut point for Curie score at diagnosis was 12 in SIOPEN/HR-NBL1, with a significant outcome difference by Curie score noted (5-year event-free survival [EFS] rate, 43.0% &#177; 5.7% [Curie score &#8804;12] vs. 21.4% &#177; 3.6% [Curie score &gt;12], <em>

4073P</em>

4074 &lt; .0001). The optimal Curie score cut point after induction chemotherapy was 2 in SIOPEN/HR-NBL1, with a postinduction Curie score of greater than 2 being associated with an inferior outcome (5-year EFS rate, 39.2% &#177; 4.7% [Curie score &#8804;2] vs. 16.4% &#177; 4.2% [Curie score &gt;2], <em>

4075P</em>

4076 &lt; .0001). The postinduction Curie score maintained independent statistical significance in Cox models when adjusted for the covariates of age and <em class="gene-name">

4077MYCN</em>

4078 gene copy number.[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

40798</a>

4080]</p>

4081</li>

4082<li>

4083<strong>

4084SIOPEN scoring method:</strong>

4085 SIOPEN independently developed an MIBG scan scoring system that, compared with the Curie scoring system, divided the body into 12 segments, rather than 10 segments, and assigned six degrees, rather than four degrees, of MIBG uptake in each segment.[<a href="#cit/section_4.9">

40869</a>

4087] Subsequently, the SIOPEN scoring system was independently validated using data from a second large clinical trial.[<a href="#cit/section_4.10">

408810</a>

4089]</li>

4090</ul>

4091</div>

4092<p id="_1883" tabindex="-1">

4093 The German Pediatric Oncology Group compared the prognostic value of the Curie and SIOPEN scoring methods in a retrospective study of 58 patients with stage 4 neuroblastoma who were older than 1 year. They demonstrated very similar results. At diagnosis, a Curie score of 2 or lower and a SIOPEN score of 4 or lower (best cutoff) correlated with significantly better EFS and overall survival (OS) rates, compared with higher scores. After four cycles of induction chemotherapy, patients with a complete response by SIOPEN and Curie scoring had a better outcome than did patients with residual uptake in metastases. However, subsequent resolution of MIBG-positive metastases occurring between the fourth and sixth cycles of chemotherapy did not affect prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.11">

409411</a>

4095]</p>

4096<p id="_1894" tabindex="-1">

4097The cited clinical trials did not include postinduction-phase assessments of Curie or SIOPEN scores after transplant and immunotherapy. Cutoffs and outcomes associated with those assessments may differ from the preinduction and postinduction scores. </p>

4098</section>

4099</section>

4100<section id="_1906">

4101<h4 id="_1906_toc">

4102PET scan</h4>

4103<p id="_1907" tabindex="-1">

4104Fluorine F 18-fludeoxyglucose PET scans are used to evaluate extent of disease in patients with tumors that are not MIBG avid.[<a href="#cit/section_4.6">

41056</a>

4106]</p>

4107</section>

4108<section id="_931">

4109<h4 id="_931_toc">

4110Other staging tests and procedures</h4>

4111<p id="_932" tabindex="-1">

4112Other tests and procedures used to stage neuroblastoma include the following:</p>

4113<div class="pdq-content-list">

4114<ul id="_595">

4115<li>

4116<strong>

4117Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy:</strong>

4118 Bone

4119marrow is assessed by bilateral iliac crest marrow aspirates

4120and trephine (core) bone marrow biopsies to exclude bone marrow involvement.

4121To be considered adequate, core biopsy specimens must contain at least 1 cm of

4122marrow, excluding cartilage. Many COG studies require two core biopsies and two aspirates. Bone marrow sampling may not be necessary for tumors that are otherwise stage 1.[<a href="#cit/section_4.12">

412312</a>

4124]</li>

4125<li>

4126<strong>

4127Lymph node assessment:</strong>

4128 Palpable lymph nodes are clinically examined

4129and histologically confirmed if INSS staging is used to evaluate extent of disease.[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

41301</a>

4131] CT, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), or both are used to assess lymph nodes in regions that are not readily identified by physical examination. The International Neuroblastoma Risk Group (INRG) staging system does not require lymph node assessment, although lymph node masses can affect image-defined risk factors (IDRFs). For more information, see the lists of IDRFs (<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1019">

4132original IDRFs</a>

4133 and <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1881">

4134COG IDRFs</a>

4135).</li>

4136<li>

4137<strong>

4138CT and MRI scan:</strong>

4139 <div class="pdq-content-list">

4140<ul id="_596" class="list-dash">

4141<li>

4142Three-dimensional (3-D) imaging of the primary tumor and potential lymph node drainage sites is done using CT scans and/or MRI scans of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis. Ultrasonography is generally considered suboptimal for accurate 3-D

4143measurements.</li>

4144<li>

4145Paraspinal tumors may extend through neural foramina to compress the spinal cord. Therefore, MRI of the spine adjacent to any paraspinal tumor is part of the staging evaluation.</li>

4146<li>

4147A brain/orbit CT and/or MRI is performed if clinically indicated by examination and/or uptake on MIBG scan.</li>

4148</ul>

4149</div>

4150</li>

4151</ul>

4152</div>

4153<p id="_1195" tabindex="-1">

4154Lumbar puncture

4155is avoided because central nervous system (CNS) metastasis at diagnosis is rare,[<a href="#cit/section_4.13">

415613</a>

4157] and lumbar puncture

4158may be associated with an increased incidence of subsequent development of CNS

4159metastasis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.14">

416014</a>

4161]</p>

4162</section>

4163</section>

4164<section id="_185">

4165<h3 id="_185_toc">

4166Neuroblastoma Staging Systems</h3>

4167<p id="_2434" tabindex="-1">

4168Combinations of prognostic factors (clinical and biological features) have been used for decades to risk-stratify patients and inform treatment assignment.[<a href="#cit/section_4.15">

416915</a>

4170] Schema differ across international cooperative groups. The International Risk Group (INRG) Task Force has led efforts to develop uniform approaches for staging and pretreatment risk classification, as outlined below.[<a href="#cit/section_4.16">

417116</a>

4172] The algorithms that use these factors to determine risk are complex and change slightly on the basis of new knowledge. The INRG Staging System (INRGSS) is used in ongoing COG studies and does not depend on a resection variable, but rather on pretreatment imaging combined with age and biological variables.</p>

4173<section id="_830">

4174<h4 id="_830_toc">

4175International Neuroblastoma Staging System (INSS)</h4>

4176<p id="_831" tabindex="-1">

4177The International Neuroblastoma Staging System (INSS) was developed and adopted by the COG in 1986 and by cooperative groups in Europe and Japan in 1993. The INSS is a postsurgical staging system that uses tumor location with respect to midline structures, lymph node status, and, importantly, extent of upfront surgical resection to determine whether a locoregional tumor is INSS stage 1, 2A, 2B, or 3.[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

41781</a>

4179,<a href="#cit/section_4.17">

418017</a>

4181] This system represented the first step in harmonizing disease staging and risk stratification worldwide. As a result of further advances in the understanding of neuroblastoma biology and genetics, a risk classification system was developed that incorporates clinical and biological factors in addition to INSS stage to facilitate risk group and treatment assignment for COG studies.[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

41821</a>

4183,<a href="#cit/section_4.17">

418417</a>

4185-<a href="#cit/section_4.19">

418619</a>

4187] The final use of the INSS by the COG was for the intermediate-risk <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00499616">

4188ANBL0531 (NCT00499616)</a>

4189 study, which was closed in 2014. </p>

4190</section>

4191<section id="_834">

4192<h4 id="_834_toc">

4193International Neuroblastoma Risk Group Staging System (INRGSS)</h4>

4194<p id="_868" tabindex="-1">

4195To create a staging system independent of surgical resection extent, the INRGSS was developed in 2005 using image-defined risk factors (IDRFs) to categorize locoregional tumors as L1 (IDRFs absent), L2 (IDRFs present), M (metastatic), or MS (the equivalent of 4S in the INSS). Presence of IDRFs has been associated with an increase in intraoperative complications, incomplete tumor resection, and worse survival in numerous studies.[<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

419620</a>

4197-<a href="#cit/section_4.22">

419822</a>

4199] Since 2014, COG and SIOPEN clinical trials have used the INRGSS, a preoperative staging system that was developed specifically for the INRG classification system (see <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_780">

4200Table 3</a>

4201), in place of the INSS.</p>

4202<table id="_780" class="table-default expandable-container">

4203<caption>

4204Table 3. International Neuroblastoma Risk Group Staging System<span class="sup">

4205a</span>

4206</caption>

4207<colgroup>

4208<col width="50.00%">

4209<col width="50.00%">

4210</colgroup>

4211<THead>

4212<tr>

4213<th>

4214Stage</th>

4215<th>

4216Description</th>

4217</tr>

4218</THead>

4219<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

4220<tr>

4221<td colspan="2">

4222IDRFs = image-defined risk factors; INSS = International Neuroblastoma Staging System.</td>

4223</tr>

4224<tr>

4225<td colspan="2">

4226<span class="sup">

4227a</span>

4228Adapted from Monclair et al.[<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

422920</a>

4230]; [<a href="#cit/section_4.21">

423121</a>

4232]</td>

4233</tr>

4234</TFoot>

4235<tbody>

4236<tr>

4237<td>

4238<strong>

4239L1</strong>

4240</td>

4241<td>

4242Localized tumor not involving vital structures as defined by the list of IDRFs<span class="sup">

4243a</span>

4244 and confined to one body compartment.</td>

4245</tr>

4246<tr>

4247<td>

4248<strong>

4249L2</strong>

4250</td>

4251<td>

4252Locoregional tumor with presence of one or more IDRFs.<span class="sup">

4253a</span>

4254</td>

4255</tr>

4256<tr>

4257<td>

4258<strong>

4259M </strong>

4260</td>

4261<td>

4262Distant metastatic disease (except stage MS).</td>

4263</tr>

4264<tr>

4265<td>

4266<strong>

4267MS</strong>

4268</td>

4269<td>

4270Metastatic disease in children younger than 18 months with metastases confined to skin, liver, and/or bone marrow. The primary tumor can be INSS stage 1, 2, or 3.</td>

4271</tr>

4272</tbody>

4273</table>

4274<p id="_1019" tabindex="-1">

4275IDRFs, as defined in the original literature, include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

427620</a>

4277,<a href="#cit/section_4.22">

427822</a>

4279]</p>

4280<div class="pdq-content-list">

4281<ul id="_1020">

4282<li>

4283Ipsilateral tumor extension within two body compartments: neck and chest; chest and abdomen; abdomen and pelvis.</li>

4284<li>

4285Infiltration of adjacent organs/structures: pericardium, diaphragm, kidney, liver, duodenopancreatic block, mesentery.</li>

4286<li>

4287Encasement of major vessels by tumor: vertebral artery, internal jugular vein, subclavian vessels, carotid artery, aorta, vena cava, major thoracic vessels, branches of the superior mesenteric artery at its root and the coeliac axis, iliac vessels.</li>

4288<li>

4289Compression of trachea or central bronchi.</li>

4290<li>

4291Encasement of brachial plexus.</li>

4292<li>

4293Infiltration of portohepatic or hepatoduodenal ligament.</li>

4294<li>

4295Infiltration of the costovertebral junction between T9 and T12.</li>

4296<li>

4297Tumor crossing the sciatic notch.</li>

4298<li>

4299Tumor invading renal pedicle.</li>

4300<li>

4301Extension of tumor to base of skull.</li>

4302<li>

4303Intraspinal tumor extension such that more than one-third of the spinal canal is invaded, leptomeningeal space is obliterated, or spinal cord MRI signal is abnormal.</li>

4304</ul>

4305</div>

4306<p id="_1881" tabindex="-1">

4307COG IDRFs, using an anatomical localization approach, include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_4.21">

430821</a>

4309,<a href="#cit/section_4.23">

431023</a>

4311]; [<a href="#cit/section_4.22">

431222</a>

4313][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4314Level of evidence C1</a>

4315]</p>

4316<div class="pdq-content-list">

4317<ul id="_1880">

4318<li>

4319Neck/cervicothoracic junction: Tumor involving/encasing brachial plexus, subclavian vessels and/or vertebral and/or carotid artery, internal jugular vein, base of skull; tumor compressing the trachea.</li>

4320<li>

4321Thorax: Tumor involving/encasing the aorta and/or major branches; tumor compressing the trachea and/or principal bronchi; lower mediastinal tumor, infiltrating the costovertebral junction between T9 and T12.</li>

4322<li>

4323Thoracoabdominal: Tumor involving/encasing the aorta and/or vena cava.</li>

4324<li>

4325Abdomen/pelvis: Tumor involving/encasing the porta hepatis and/or hepatoduodenal ligament, superior mesenteric artery at the root, the origin of the celiac axis, and/or of the superior mesenteric artery; tumor involving/encasing one or both renal pedicles, aorta and/or vena cava; tumor involving/encasing the iliac vessels; pelvic tumor involving/encasing the sciatic notch.</li>

4326<li>

4327Intra-spinal tumor extension: Invading more than one-third of axial plane and/or perimedullary leptomeningeal spaces are not visible, abnormal spinal cord signal; dumbbell tumors with symptoms of spinal cord compression.</li>

4328<li>

4329Any localization involvement/infiltration of adjacent organs/structures: Pericardium, diaphragm, kidney, liver, duodenopancreatic block, mesentery, and others.</li>

4330<li>

4331Tumor involving two body compartments: Neck and chest, chest and abdomen, abdomen and pelvis.</li>

4332<li>

4333Not IDRFs but recorded conditions: Multifocal, pleural effusion, ascites.</li>

4334</ul>

4335</div>

4336<p id="_1908" tabindex="-1">

4337Assessment of surgical resectability should include IDRFs. The more IDRFs present, the higher the morbidity of the operation and the lower the chance of complete resection.</p>

4338<p id="_1890" tabindex="-1">

4339Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is not always effective in eliminating IDRFs, as seen in a retrospective study in the European Unresectable Neuroblastoma trial from 2001 to 2006 that examined data from 143 patients with INSS stage 3 neuroblastoma who were older than 1 year without <em class="gene-name">

4340MYCN</em>

4341 amplification. All patients had surgical risk factors that deemed the tumors unresectable. In a centrally reviewed subset, unfavorable histology by International Neuroblastoma Pathology Classification was found in 53% of patients. At diagnosis, 228 IDRFs were identified.[<a href="#cit/section_4.23">

434223</a>

4343]; [<a href="#cit/section_4.24">

434424</a>

4345][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4346Level of evidence C1</a>

4347]</p>

4348<div class="pdq-content-list">

4349<ul id="_1909">

4350<li>

4351After four cycles of chemotherapy with carboplatin/etoposide alternating with vincristine/cyclophosphamide/doxorubicin, only 32.2% of patients demonstrated resolution of the IDRFs, 49% of patients showed no change in IDRFs, and 18.8% of patients developed new IDRFs. </li>

4352<li>

4353Complete resection was possible in 71.2% of patients in whom the IDRFs were reduced or disappeared. Complete or near complete resection was achieved in 84% of patients (37 of 44) whose IDRFs decreased or disappeared. Complete or near complete resection was achieved in 70% of patients (39 of 56) who had stable IDRFs and in 52% of patients (13 of 25) who had new IDRFs appear. </li>

4354<li>

4355No significant differences were observed in EFS or OS on the basis of the response of the IDRF to chemotherapy and surgical outcomes. There was no association between type of IDRF before surgery and extent of resection. </li>

4356<li>

4357When the tumor was wrapped around the superior mesenteric artery and/or celiac axis, disease-free survival (DFS) and OS were impacted (perhaps because of the difficulty in achieving a complete resection in these areas). </li>

4358<li>

4359Prolonged chemotherapy with more than five courses did not aid in the reduction of IDRFs and was associated with a lower DFS and OS.</li>

4360</ul>

4361</div>

4362<p id="_1125" tabindex="-1">

4363The INRGSS has incorporated this staging system into a risk grouping system using multiple other parameters at diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.15">

436415</a>

4365] For more information, see <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1145">

4366Table 4</a>

4367.</p>

4368<p id="_1138" tabindex="-1">

4369The INRGSS simplifies stages into L1, L2, M, or MS. Localized tumors are classified as stage L1 or L2 disease on the basis of whether one or more of the 20 IDRFs are present.[<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

437020</a>

4371] For example, in the case of spinal cord compression, an IDRF is present when more than one-third of the spinal canal in the axial plane is invaded, when the leptomeningeal spaces are not visible, or when the spinal cord magnetic resonance signal intensity is abnormal. For more information about the INRGSS, see <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_780">

4372Table 3</a>

4373 and the lists of IDRFs (<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1019">

4374original IDRFs</a>

4375 and <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1881">

4376COG IDRFs</a>

4377).</p>

4378<p id="_2477" tabindex="-1">

4379The INRG collaboration has also defined techniques for detecting and quantifying neuroblastoma in bone marrow, both at diagnosis and after treatment. Quantification of bone marrow metastatic disease may result in more accurate assessment of response to treatment,[<a href="#cit/section_4.25">

438025</a>

4381] and it is now incorporated into the International Neuroblastoma Response Criteria, which assess response to therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.26">

438226</a>

4383]</p>

4384<p id="_1895" tabindex="-1">

4385The decision by the INRG Task Force to replace the category of 4S disease with that of the new MS definition was based on reports in which small numbers of infants with L2 primary tumors and 4S metastatic patterns, including those aged 12 to 18 months, had favorable outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

438620</a>

4387,<a href="#cit/section_4.27">

438827</a>

4389] A subsequent study of the actual INRG data found that a number of biological characteristics predicted poor outcome of MS patients (aged 12 to 18 months), and that only those infants with favorable biology had long-term outcomes similar to those with the traditional 4S diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.27">

439027</a>

4391]</p>

4392<p id="_1161" tabindex="-1">

4393By combining the INRGSS, age, and biological factors, each patient is assigned an INRG risk group that is prognostic of outcome and guides the appropriate risk-based treatment approach. The validity of the INRGSS was explored in the following retrospective studies of localized neuroblastoma with previously defined INSS stage without <em class="gene-name">

4394MYCN</em>

4395 amplification:</p>

4396<div class="pdq-content-list">

4397<ul id="_1910">

4398<li>

4399In the first study, using data from a SIOPEN trial, L2 tumors were found in INSS stage 1 (21%), stage 2 (45%), and stage 3 (94%) patients. The INRGSS had predictive value for outcomes, with stage L1 patients having a 5-year EFS rate of 90% and an OS rate of 96%, versus an EFS rate of 79% and an OS rate of 89% for L2 patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

440020</a>

4401] </li>

4402<li>

4403In the second study, data was used from the European multicenter study LNESG1, a trial of primary surgery followed by observation performed between 1995 and 1999. In this study, 291 children had L1 tumors and all underwent primary surgery. Of the L2 patients, 118 had primary surgery and 125 had no surgery (106 of the latter group received neoadjuvant chemotherapy).[<a href="#cit/section_4.28">

440428</a>

4405] <div class="pdq-content-list">

4406<ul id="_1941" class="list-dash">

4407<li>

4408The 5-year EFS and OS rates were 92% and 98% for the L1 group, 86% and 95% for the L2 with primary surgery group, and 73% and 83% for the L2 without primary surgery group.</li>

4409<li>

4410It should be noted that many children with L2 tumors underwent primary surgery and had an outcome significantly superior to that of children who underwent biopsy only as the initial operative procedure (5-year OS rate of 93% vs. 83%). The L2 tumors that underwent primary resection may have been selected for less-risky resectability. However, these children also had a 17% rate of operative complications (vs. 5% in L1 resections).</li>

4411<li>

4412In patients who underwent primary surgery, those with operative complications had a lower OS rate (92% vs. 97%, <em>

4413P</em>

4414 = .05), but this effect on outcome was statistically significant only in patients with L1 tumors.</li>

4415<li>

4416For L2 patients, the operative complications were not statistically related to the IDRFs.[<a href="#cit/section_4.28">

441728</a>

4418]</li>

4419</ul>

4420</div>

4421 </li>

4422</ul>

4423</div>

4424<p id="_1139" tabindex="-1">

4425Most international protocols have begun to incorporate the collection and use of IDRFs to define INRG stage, which is used in risk stratification and assignment of therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.29">

442629</a>

4427,<a href="#cit/section_4.30">

442830</a>

4429] The COG has been collecting and evaluating INRGSS data since 2006. A COG trial that opened in 2014 uses the INRGSS along with input from the surgeon to determine therapy for subsets of patients not at high risk, including those with L1, L2, and MS disease (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02176967">

4430ANBL1232 [NCT02176967]</a>

4431, closed to accrual). Note that the INSS allows patients up to age 12 months to be classified as stage 4S, while the INRGSS allows patients up to age 18 months to be staged as MS. The primary tumor in INSS stage 4S must be INSS stage 1 or 2, while the primary tumor in MS can be INSS stage 3. In August 2018, a COG study for subsets of high-risk patients was opened but is now closed to accrual (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03126916">

4432ANBL1531 [NCT03126916]</a>

4433). Eligible patients include those with stage M disease older than 547 days, stage M patients younger than 547 days with <em class="gene-name">

4434MYCN</em>

4435 amplification, and patients of any age with stage L2 or MS disease with <em class="gene-name">

4436MYCN</em>

4437 amplification. It is anticipated that the use of standardized nomenclature will contribute substantially to more uniform staging and facilitate comparisons of clinical trials conducted in different parts of the world.</p>

4438</section>

4439<section id="_17">

4440<h4 id="_17_toc">

4441Children&#8217;s Oncology Group (COG) Neuroblastoma Risk Grouping</h4>

4442<p id="_600" tabindex="-1">

4443The COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00904241">

4444ANBL00B1 (NCT00904241)</a>

4445 biology study serves as the infrastructure for rapid and reliable acquisition of tumor prognostic markers used for risk classification and clinical trial eligibility. For more information about the COG risk categories, see <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_2398">

4446Table 5</a>

4447. </p>

4448<p id="_2509" tabindex="-1">

4449For information about eligibility for high-risk patients in the ANBL1531 trial, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1817">

4450Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation</a>

4451 section in the Treatment of High-Risk Neuroblastoma section.</p>

4452</section>

4453<section id="_1134">

4454<h4 id="_1134_toc">

4455International Neuroblastoma Risk Grouping (INRG)</h4>

4456<p id="_1124" tabindex="-1">

4457The INRG classification schema assigns neuroblastoma patients to one of 16 pretreatment risk groups on the basis of INRG stage, age, histological category, grade of tumor differentiation, <em class="gene-name">

4458MYCN</em>

4459 amplification, 11q aberration (the only segmental chromosomal aberration studied), and ploidy. Four levels of risk were defined according to outcomes among 8,800 patients with high-quality data, as they had been entered in clinical trials (see <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1145">

4460Table 4</a>

4461). Because the 2006 neuroblastoma risk classification system had not been modified to include INRGSS, a comprehensive analysis was performed of IDRF data collected from patients enrolled in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00904241">

4462ANBL00B1 (NCT00904241)</a>

4463 biology study. </p>

4464<p id="_2479" tabindex="-1">

4465The COG analyzed almost 5,000 patients with newly diagnosed neuroblastoma who were enrolled in the ANBL00B1 study between 2007 and 2017 and treated with more modern therapy. In addition to using the INRGSS, segmental chromosomal status of 1q was examined with the above prognostic factors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.31">

446631</a>

4467] </p>

4468<p id="_2480" tabindex="-1">

4469In the overall risk grouping, histology is an important risk determinant for all stage L1 and L2 tumors, and grade of differentiation discriminates among neuroblastomas and nodular ganglioneuroblastomas in patients older than 18 months. The goals of the INRG are to increase international collaboration and classify patients uniformly so that the results of clinical trials conducted around the world can be compared.[<a href="#cit/section_4.16">

447016</a>

4471]</p>

4472<table id="_1145" class="table-default expandable-container">

4473<caption>

4474Table 4. International Neuroblastoma Risk Group (INRG) Pretreatment Classification Schema<span class="sup">

4475a</span>

4476</caption>

4477<colgroup>

4478<col width="4.45%">

4479<col width="6.00%">

4480<col width="18.02%">

4481<col width="19.49%">

4482<col width="14.24%">

4483<col width="10.45%">

4486</colgroup>

4487<THead>

4488<tr>

4489<th colspan="2">

4490INRG Stage</th>

4491<th>

4492Histological Category</th>

4493<th>

4494Grade of Tumor Differentiation</th>

4495<th>

4496<em class="gene-name">

4497MYCN</em>

4498</th>

4499<th>

450011q Aberration</th>

4501<th>

4502Ploidy</th>

4503<th>

4504Pretreatment Risk Group</th>

4507<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

4508<tr>

4509<td colspan="8">

4510GN = ganglioneuroma; GNB = ganglioneuroblastoma; NA = not amplified.</td>

4511</tr>

4512<tr>

4515a</span>

451715</a>

4518]</td>

4893<li id="section_4.27">

4894Taggart DR, London WB, Schmidt ML, et al.: Prognostic value of the stage 4S metastatic pattern and tumor biology in patients with metastatic neuroblastoma diagnosed between birth and 18 months of age. J Clin Oncol 29 (33): 4358-64, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21969516&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21969516&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4895[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4896</li>

4897<li id="section_4.28">

4898Monclair T, Mosseri V, Cecchetto G, et al.: Influence of image-defined risk factors on the outcome of patients with localised neuroblastoma. A report from the LNESG1 study of the European International Society of Paediatric Oncology Neuroblastoma Group. Pediatr Blood Cancer 62 (9): 1536-42, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25663103&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25663103&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4899[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4900</li>

4901<li id="section_4.29">

4902Cecchetto G, Mosseri V, De Bernardi B, et al.: Surgical risk factors in primary surgery for localized neuroblastoma: the LNESG1 study of the European International Society of Pediatric Oncology Neuroblastoma Group. J Clin Oncol 23 (33): 8483-9, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16293878&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16293878&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4903[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4904</li>

4905<li id="section_4.30">

4906Simon T, Hero B, Benz-Bohm G, et al.: Review of image defined risk factors in localized neuroblastoma patients: Results of the GPOH NB97 trial. Pediatr Blood Cancer 50 (5): 965-9, 2008.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17914735&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17914735&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4907[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4908</li>

4909<li id="section_4.31">

4910Irwin MS, Naranjo A, Zhang FF, et al.: Revised Neuroblastoma Risk Classification System: A Report From the Children's Oncology Group. J Clin Oncol 39 (29): 3229-3241, 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34319759&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34319759&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4911[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4912</li>

4913</ol>

4914</div>

4915

4916 </section>

4917

4918

4919

4920 <section id="_1180">

4921

4922 <h2>

4923Special Considerations for the Treatment of Children With Cancer</h2>

4924

4925 <div id="_section_1180" class="pdq-sections">

4926<p id="_1181" tabindex="-1">

4927Cancer in children and adolescents is rare, although the overall incidence has been slowly increasing since 1975.[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

49281</a>

4929] Children and adolescents with

4930cancer are usually referred to medical centers that have a multidisciplinary team

4931of cancer specialists with experience treating the cancers that occur during

4932childhood and adolescence. This multidisciplinary team approach incorporates the skills

4933of the following health care professionals

4934and others to ensure that children receive treatment, supportive care, and rehabilitation

4935that will enable them to achieve optimal survival and quality of life:</p>

4936<div class="pdq-content-list">

4937<ul id="_1182">

4938<li>

4939Primary care physician. </li>

4940<li>

4941Pediatric pathologists.</li>

4942<li>

4943Pediatric surgeons. </li>

4944<li>

4945Pediatric radiation

4946oncologists.</li>

4947<li>

4948 Pediatric medical oncologists/hematologists.</li>

4949<li>

4950Pediatric nurse specialists.</li>

4951<li>

4952 Social workers.</li>

4953<li>

4954Child life professionals.</li>

4955</ul>

4956</div>

4957<p id="_1183" tabindex="-1">

4958For specific information about supportive care for children and adolescents with cancer, see the PDQ summaries on <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/information-summaries/supportive-care" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/information-summaries/supportive-care">

4959Supportive and Palliative Care</a>

4960.</p>

4961<p id="_1184" tabindex="-1">

4962The American Academy of Pediatrics has outlined guidelines for pediatric cancer centers and their role in the treatment of

4963pediatric patients with cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_5.2">

49642</a>

4965] At these pediatric cancer centers, clinical trials are

4966available for most types of cancer that occur in children and

4967adolescents, and the opportunity to participate is offered to

4968most patients and families. Clinical trials for children and adolescents with

4969cancer are generally designed to compare potentially better therapy with

4970current standard therapy. Most of the progress

4971made in identifying curative therapies for childhood cancers has been achieved

4972through clinical trials. Other types of clinical trials explore or define novel therapies when there is no standard therapy for a cancer diagnosis. Information about ongoing clinical trials is

4973available from the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials">

4974NCI website</a>

4975.</p>

4976<h6 do-not-show="toc">

4977References</h6>

4978<ol>

4979<li id="section_5.1">

4980Smith MA, Altekruse SF, Adamson PC, et al.: Declining childhood and adolescent cancer mortality. Cancer 120 (16): 2497-506, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24853691&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24853691&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4981[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4982</li>

4983<li id="section_5.2">

4984American Academy of Pediatrics: Standards for pediatric cancer centers. Pediatrics 134 (2): 410-4, 2014. <a href="https://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/134/2/410" title="https://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/134/2/410">

4985Also available online</a>

4986. Last accessed May 19, 2023.</li>

4987</ol>

4988</div>

4989

4990 </section>

4991

4992

4993

4994 <section id="_30">

4995

4996 <h2>

4997Treatment Option Overview for Neuroblastoma</h2>

4998

4999 <div id="_section_30" class="pdq-sections">

5000<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

5001<h6>

5002In This Section</h6>

5003<ul>

5004<li>

5005<a href="#_421_toc">

5006Revised International Neuroblastoma Response Criteria (INRC)</a>

5007</li>

5008<li>

5009<a href="#_604_toc">

5010Surgery</a>

5011</li>

5012<li>

5013<a href="#_144_toc">

5014Radiation Therapy</a>

5015</li>

5016<li>

5017<a href="#_816_toc">

5018Treatment of Spinal Cord Compression</a>

5019</li>

5020<li>

5021<a href="#_793_toc">

5022Surveillance During and After Treatment</a>

5023</li>

5024</ul>

5025</nav>

5026<p id="_1854" tabindex="-1">

5027Treatment is risk based. In the Children's Oncology Group (COG) risk system, each child is assigned to a low-risk, intermediate-risk, or high-risk group on the basis of the following factors:[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

50281</a>

5029-<a href="#cit/section_6.7">

50307</a>

5031] </p>

5032<div class="pdq-content-list">

5033<ul id="_896">

5034<li>

5035International Neuroblastoma Staging System (INSS) stage.</li>

5036<li>

5037Age.</li>

5038<li>

5039International Neuroblastoma Pathologic Classification (INPC).[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

50408</a>

5041]</li>

5042<li>

5043Ploidy.</li>

5044<li>

5045Amplification of the <em class="gene-name">

5046MYCN</em>

5047 oncogene within tumor tissue.[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

50482</a>

5049-<a href="#cit/section_6.7">

50507</a>

5051]</li>

5052</ul>

5053</div>

5054<p id="_2481" tabindex="-1">

5055Assessment of risk for low-stage <em class="gene-name">

5056MYCN</em>

5057-amplified neuroblastoma is controversial because it is so rare. </p>

5058<p id="_687" tabindex="-1">

5059A study of 87 patients with INSS stage 1 or stage 2 <em class="gene-name">

5060MYCN</em>

5061-amplified neuroblastoma pooled from several clinical trial groups demonstrated no effect of age, stage, or initial treatment on outcome. The event-free survival (EFS) rate was 53%, and the overall survival (OS) rate was 72%. Survival was superior in patients whose tumors were hyperdiploid rather than diploid (EFS rate, 82% &#177; 20% vs. 37% &#177; 21%; OS rate, 94% &#177; 11% vs. 54% &#177; 15%).[<a href="#cit/section_6.9">

50629</a>

5063]</p>

5064<p id="_2503" tabindex="-1">

5065The COG considers infants with stage 4 and stage 4S disease with <em class="gene-name">

5066MYCN</em>

5067 amplification to be at high risk.[<a href="#cit/section_6.5">

50685</a>

5069] The overall EFS and OS rates for infants with stage 4 and 4S disease and <em class="gene-name">

5070MYCN</em>

5071 amplification was only 30% at 2 to 5 years after treatment in a European study.[<a href="#cit/section_6.10">

507210</a>

5073] </p>

5074<p id="_2418" tabindex="-1">

5075For more information about the COG risk categories, see <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_2398">

5076Table 5</a>

5077.</p>

5078<p id="_897" tabindex="-1">

5079Other biological factors that influenced treatment selection in some previous COG studies included unbalanced 11q loss of heterozygosity and loss of heterozygosity for chromosome 1p.[<a href="#cit/section_6.11">

508011</a>

5081-<a href="#cit/section_6.13">

508213</a>

5083] In 2012, the COG Neuroblastoma Committee defined favorable genomics, for purposes of risk assignment, as hyperdiploid neuroblastoma cells without segmental copy number aberrations, including no loss of copy number at 1p, 3p, 4p, or 11q and no gain of copy number at 1q, 2p, or 17q. This does not correspond to the International Neuroblastoma Risk Group Staging System, which only includes 11q abnormalities; however, the criteria may change in future versions.</p>

5084<table id="_2398" class="table-default expandable-container">

5085<caption>

5086Table 5. Children's Oncology Group Neuroblastoma Risk Strata<span class="sup">

5087a</span>

5088</caption>

5090<col width="14.28%">

5091<col width="14.28%">

5092<col width="14.28%">

5093<col width="14.28%">

5094<col width="14.28%">

5095<col width="14.28%">

5096<col width="14.28%">

5097</colgroup>

5098<THead>

5099<tr>

5102<th>

5103Stage</th>

5104<th>

5106<th>

5107<em class="gene-name">

5108MYCN</em>

5116</tr>

5426</tr>

5427<tr>

5428<td>

543112 months to &lt;18 months</td>

5432<td>

5433Any</td>

5434<td>

5435Any</td>

5436<td>

5437UH</td>

5438<td>

5439&#160;</td>

5440</tr>

5441<tr>

5442<td>

54434</td>

5444<td>

5445&#8805;18 months</td>

5446<td>

5447Any</td>

5448<td>

5449Any</td>

5450<td>

5451Any</td>

5452<td>

5453&#160;</td>

5454</tr>

5455<tr>

5456<td>

54574s</td>

5458<td>

5459&lt;12 months</td>

5460<td>

5461Amp</td>

5462<td>

5463Any</td>

5464<td>

5465Any</td>

5466<td>

5467Asymptomatic or symptomatic</td>

5468</tr>

5469</tbody>

5470</table>

5471<p id="_836" tabindex="-1">

5472Generally, treatment is based on whether the tumor is classified as low, intermediate, or high risk, as follows:</p>

5473<div class="pdq-content-list">

5474<ul id="_898">

5475<li>

5476<strong>

5477Low risk.</strong>

5478 For patients with low-risk tumors, the approach is either observation or resection, with chemotherapy restricted to symptomatic patients with low-risk biology. The 5-year OS rate was 98% for the low-risk patients among more than 5,000 patients enrolled in the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00904241">

5479ANBL00B1 (NCT00904241)</a>

5480 biology study.[<a href="#cit/section_6.14">

548114</a>

5482] The ongoing COG study is looking at the reduction of therapy in a limited subset of patients with low-risk tumors. </li>

5483<li>

5484<strong>

5485Intermediate risk.</strong>

5486 For patients with intermediate-risk tumors, chemotherapy is often given before definitive resection. Multiagent chemotherapy consisting of doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, a platinum drug, and etoposide is used. The number of chemotherapy cycles is based on clinical and tumor biological risk factors and response to therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.13">

548713</a>

5488] The goal of chemotherapy is to deliver a sufficient duration of chemotherapy (with or without surgery) to achieve at least a partial response (at least 50% reduction of soft tissue masses) and resolution of metastatic disease.[<a href="#cit/section_6.13">

548913</a>

5490] In recent studies, select patients have been observed without undergoing chemotherapy or attempted resection. The 5-year OS rate was about 95% for the intermediate-risk patients among more than 5,000 patients enrolled in the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00904241">

5491ANBL00B1 (NCT00904241)</a>

5492 biology study.[<a href="#cit/section_6.14">

549314</a>

5494] In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00499616">

5495ANBL0531 (NCT00499616)</a>

5496 study, the duration and intensity of chemotherapy was decreased in several subsets of intermediate-risk children to further diminish side effects; no declines in outcomes were seen.[<a href="#cit/section_6.13">

549713</a>

5498]</li>

5499<li>

5500<strong>

5501High risk.</strong>

5502 For high-risk patients, treatment has intensified to include chemotherapy, surgery, radiation therapy, myeloablative therapy and stem cell transplant (SCT), isotretinoin, and immunotherapy, resulting in 5-year survival rates of 62%.[<a href="#cit/section_6.14">

550314</a>

5504] Statistically significant improvement in survival was observed in a randomized phase III COG study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00567567">

5505ANBL0532 [NCT00567567]</a>

5506) with tandem cycles of myeloablative therapy with SCT, compared with a single cycle of myeloablative therapy and SCT. The 3-year EFS rate for patients who received tandem transplants was superior (<em>

5507P</em>

5508 = .006) to the EFS rate for patients who received single transplants. However, there was a potential selection bias resulting from a large proportion of patients who were not randomized.[<a href="#cit/section_6.15">

550915</a>

5510][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5511Level of evidence A1</a>

5512] For more information, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_907">

5513Consolidation phase</a>

5514 section.</li>

5515</ul>

5516</div>

5517<p id="_1249" tabindex="-1">

5518<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_942">

5519Table 6</a>

5520 summarizes the treatment options for patients with low-risk, intermediate-risk, high-risk, and stage 4S neuroblastoma by INSS-based risk group.</p>

5521<table id="_942" class="table-default expandable-container">

5522<caption>

5523Table 6. Treatment Options for Neuroblastoma</caption>

5524<colgroup>

5525<col width="23.80%">

5526<col width="32.85%">

5527<col width="43.33%">

5528</colgroup>

5529<THead>

5530<tr>

5531<th colspan="2">

5532COG Risk-Group Assignment </th>

5533<th>

5534Treatment Options</th>

5535</tr>

5536</THead>

5537<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

5538<tr>

5539<td colspan="3">

5540COG = Children's Oncology Group; GM-CSF = granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor; 131I-MIBG = iodine I 131-metaiodobenzylguanidine; SCT = stem cell transplant.</td>

5541</tr>

5542</TFoot>

5543<tbody>

5544<tr>

5545<td rowspan="4" colspan="2">

5546Low-Risk Neuroblastoma</td>

5547<td>

5548<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_818">

5549Surgery followed by observation</a>

5550.</td>

5551</tr>

5552<tr>

5553<td>

5554<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_821">

5555Observation with or without biopsy</a>

5556.</td>

5557</tr>

5558<tr>

5559<td>

5560<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_760">

5561Chemotherapy with or without surgery</a>

5562 (for symptomatic disease or unresectable progressive disease after surgery).</td>

5563</tr>

5564<tr>

5565<td>

5566<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_621">

5567Radiation therapy</a>

5568 (only for emergency therapy).</td>

5569</tr>

5570<tr>

5571<td rowspan="3" colspan="2">

5572Intermediate-Risk Neuroblastoma</td>

5573<td>

5574<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_642">

5575Chemotherapy with or without surgery</a>

5576.</td>

5577</tr>

5578<tr>

5579<td>

5580<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_651">

5581Surgery and observation</a>

5582 (in infants).

5583</td>

5584</tr>

5585<tr>

5586<td>

5587<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_656">

5588Radiation therapy</a>

5589 (if needed).</td>

5590</tr>

5591<tr>

5592<td colspan="2">

5593High-Risk Neuroblastoma</td>

5594<td>

5595<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_661">

5596A regimen of chemotherapy, surgery, tandem cycles of myeloablative therapy and SCT, radiation therapy, and dinutuximab, with GM-CSF and isotretinoin</a>

5597.</td>

5598</tr>

5599<tr>

5600<td rowspan="3" colspan="2">

5601Stage 4S/MS Neuroblastoma</td>

5602<td>

5603<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_775">

5604Observation with supportive care</a>

5605 (for asymptomatic patients with favorable tumor biology). </td>

5606</tr>

5607<tr>

5608<td>

5609<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_777">

5610Chemotherapy</a>

5611 (for symptomatic patients or those with unfavorable biology). </td>

5612</tr>

5613<tr>

5614<td>

5615<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1852">

5616Radiation therapy</a>

5617 (rarely for patients with symptoms related to hepatomegaly from metastatic disease).</td>

5618</tr>

5619</tbody>

5620</table>

5621<section id="_421">

5622<h3 id="_421_toc">

5623Revised International Neuroblastoma Response Criteria (INRC)</h3>

5624<p id="_2083" tabindex="-1">

5625INRC is used to assess response to treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_6.16">

562616</a>

5627-<a href="#cit/section_6.18">

562818</a>

5629] Overall response in the revised INRC integrates tumor response in the primary tumor, soft tissue and bone metastases, and bone marrow. Primary and metastatic soft tissue sites are assessed using Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) and iodine I 123 (123I) metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) scans or fluorine F 18-fludeoxyglucose (18F-FDG) positron emission tomography (PET) scans if the tumor is MIBG nonavid. 123I-MIBG scans, or 18F-FDG PET scans for MIBG-nonavid disease, replace Technetium Tc 99m (99mTc) diphosphonate bone scintigraphy for osteomedullary metastasis assessment. Bone marrow is assessed by histology or immunohistochemistry and cytology or immunocytology. Bone marrow with 5% or less tumor involvement is classified as minimal disease. Urinary catecholamine levels are not included in response assessment. Overall response is defined as complete response, partial response, minor response, stable disease, or progressive disease.[<a href="#cit/section_6.18">

563018</a>

5631]</p>

5632<p id="_1242" tabindex="-1">

5633 The overall INRC response criteria are defined as follows:[<a href="#cit/section_6.16">

563416</a>

5635,<a href="#cit/section_6.17">

563617</a>

5637]</p>

5638<div class="pdq-content-list">

5639<ul id="_423">

5640<li>

5641<strong>

5642Complete Response:</strong>

5643 No evidence of disease, including resolution of MIBG uptake (or PET scan positivity in MIBG non-avid disease) in any location of soft tissue or bone, with less than 10 mm remaining on 3-D imaging of primary tumor; target lymph nodes less than 15 mm in short dimension; and no histological tumor in two bone marrow biopsies and two bone marrow aspirates sampled at one time point.</li>

5644<li>

5645<strong>

5646Partial Response:</strong>

5647 30% or more decrease in longest diameter of primary site <strong>

5648and</strong>

5649 no new lesions <strong>

5650and</strong>

5651 MIBG (or 18F-FDG PET) stable or improved <strong>

5652and</strong>

5653 at least a 50% reduction in absolute MIBG bone score or a 50% or greater reduction in number of 18F-FDG PET-avid bone lesions. </li>

5654<li>

5655<strong>

5656Minor Response:</strong>

5657 Partial response or complete response of at least one component of disease, but at least one other component with stable disease <strong>

5658and</strong>

5659 no component with progressive disease. </li>

5660<li>

5661<strong>

5662Progressive Disease:</strong>

5663 Any new lesion; increase in longest diameter in any measurable lesion by 20% <strong>

5664and</strong>

5665 increase of at least 5 mm in longest diameter; previous negative bone marrow now positive for tumor; any new soft tissue lesion that is MIBG (or 18F-FDG PET) avid or positive by biopsy; a new avid bone site; <strong>

5666or</strong>

5667 increase in relative MIBG score of 1.25% or greater. </li>

5668<li>

5669<strong>

5670Stable Disease:</strong>

5671 Neither sufficient shrinkage for partial response nor sufficient increase for progressive disease and may have greater than 5% tumor infiltration as defined in minimal disease.</li>

5672</ul>

5673</div>

5674<p id="_1244" tabindex="-1">

5675Care should be taken in interpreting the development of metastatic disease in an infant who was initially considered to have stage 1 or 2 disease. If the pattern of metastases in such a patient is consistent with a 4S pattern of disease (involvement of skin, liver, and/or bone marrow, the latter less than 10% involved), these patients are not classified as having progressive/metastatic disease, which would typically be a criterion for removal from protocol therapy. Instead, these patients are managed as stage 4S patients. </p>

5676<p id="_1127" tabindex="-1">

5677Controversy exists regarding the necessity of measuring the primary tumor response in all three dimensions or whether the single longest dimension, as in RECIST tumor response determination, is equally useful.[<a href="#cit/section_6.19">

567819</a>

5679] The latter has been adopted for use in the INRC.</p>

5680</section>

5681<section id="_604">

5682<h3 id="_604_toc">

5683Surgery</h3>

5684<p id="_605" tabindex="-1">

5685In patients without metastatic disease, the standard of care is to perform an initial surgery. This surgery aims to accomplish the following, on the basis of the disease stage and the risk group:</p>

5686<div class="pdq-content-list">

5687<ul id="_899">

5688<li>

5689Obtain tissue for diagnosis. Incisional or core biopsy only is recommended for patients with L2 disease,[<a href="#cit/section_6.20">

569020</a>

5691][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5692Level of evidence C1</a>

5693] and an up-front resection should generally not be attempted. For more information about image-defined risk factors, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_834">

5694International Neuroblastoma Risk Group Staging System (INRGSS)</a>

5695 section.<div class="pdq-content-list">

5696<ul id="_2523">

5697<li>

5698Either incisional biopsy or percutaneous core needle biopsy are acceptable for patients with L2 disease. In a multi-institutional retrospective study, there was no significant difference in the ability to accurately obtain a primary diagnosis by percutaneous core needle biopsy compared with incisional biopsy (95.7% vs. 98.9%, <em>

5699P</em>

5700 = .314) or determine MYCN copy number (92.4% vs. 97.8%; <em>

5701P</em>

5702 = .111). The yield for loss of heterozygosity and tumor ploidy was lower with percutaneous core needle biopsy (dependent on the number of cores/volume of tissue obtained) than with incisional biopsy (56.1% vs. 90.9%, <em>

5703P</em>

5704 &lt; .05; and 58.0% vs. 88.5%, <em>

5705P</em>

5706 &lt; .05). Complications did not differ between the groups.[<a href="#cit/section_6.21">

570721</a>

5708][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5709Level of evidence C1</a>

5710] </li>

5711</ul>

5712</div>

5713</li>

5714<li>

5715Near-total or total resection of the primary tumor is recommended based on stage. <div class="pdq-content-list">

5716<ul id="_2524">

5717<li>

5718This is standard for patients with low-risk (excluding prenatally diagnosed infants who are candidates for observation) and intermediate-risk disease. In patients with L1 tumors (defined as having no image-defined surgical risk factors), the tumors are resectable with low risk of nephrectomy or life-threatening complications. Unilateral adrenal gland primary tumors, thoracic L1 disease, or neck L1 disease should be resected up front (per the surgeons&#8217; discretion).[<a href="#cit/section_6.20">

571920</a>

5720][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5721Level of evidence C1</a>

5722]</li>

5723<li>

5724Minimally invasive surgery may be considered in highly selected patients with neuroblastoma if it is performed by a pediatric surgical oncologist who has expertise using this technique.[<a href="#cit/section_6.22">

572522</a>

5726][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5727Level of evidence C1</a>

5728]; [<a href="#cit/section_6.23">

572923</a>

5730,<a href="#cit/section_6.24">

573124</a>

5732] </li>

5733</ul>

5734</div>

5735</li>

5736</ul>

5737</div>

5738<p id="_900" tabindex="-1">

5739The COG reported that expectant observation in infants younger than 6 months with small (L1) adrenal masses resulted in an excellent EFS and OS while avoiding surgical intervention in a large majority of patients.[<a href="#cit/section_6.25">

574025</a>

5741] According to the surgical guidelines described in the intermediate-risk neuroblastoma clinical trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00499616">

5742ANBL0531 [NCT00499616]</a>

5743), the primary tumor is not routinely resected in patients with 4S neuroblastoma. German studies of selected groups of patients have biopsied tissue and observed infants with both L1 and L2 tumors without <em class="gene-name">

5744MYCN</em>

5745 amplification, avoiding additional surgery and chemotherapy in most patients.[<a href="#cit/section_6.26">

574626</a>

5747]</p>

5748<p id="_901" tabindex="-1">

5749Whether there is any advantage to gross-total resection of the primary tumor mass after chemotherapy in stage 4 patients older than 18 months remains controversial.[<a href="#cit/section_6.27">

575027</a>

5751-<a href="#cit/section_6.32">

575232</a>

5753] A meta-analysis of stage 3 versus stage 4 neuroblastoma patients, at all ages combined, found an advantage for gross-total resection (&gt;90%) over subtotal resection in stage 3 neuroblastoma only.[<a href="#cit/section_6.33">

575433</a>

5755] Also, a small study suggested that after neoadjuvant chemotherapy, completeness of resection was affected by the number of image-defined risk factors remaining.[<a href="#cit/section_6.34">

575634</a>

5757] When an experienced surgeon performed the procedure, a 90% or greater resection of the primary tumor in stage 4 neuroblastoma resulted in a higher local control rate, but it did not have a statistically significant impact on OS.[<a href="#cit/section_6.35">

575835</a>

5759]</p>

5760<p id="_2483" tabindex="-1">

5761For more information about image-defined risk factors, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_834">

5762International Neuroblastoma Risk Group Staging System (INRGSS)</a>

5763 section.</p>

5764</section>

5765<section id="_144">

5766<h3 id="_144_toc">

5767Radiation Therapy</h3>

5768<p id="_41" tabindex="-1">

5769In the current treatment paradigm, radiation therapy for patients with low-risk or intermediate-risk neuroblastoma is reserved for symptomatic life-threatening or

5770organ-threatening tumor bulk that did not respond rapidly enough to chemotherapy. Common situations in which radiation therapy is used in these patients include the following: </p>

5771<div class="pdq-content-list">

5772<ul id="_606">

5773<li>

5774Infants aged 60 days and younger with stage 4S and marked respiratory compromise from liver metastases that has not responded to chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.36">

577536</a>

5776]</li>

5777<li>

5778For patients with spinal cord compression. However, most patients are treated with chemotherapy or neurosurgical intervention because of the responsiveness of neuroblastoma to chemotherapy and the potentially devastating late effects of radiation therapy in young children.[<a href="#cit/section_6.37">

577937</a>

5780]</li>

5781</ul>

5782</div>

5783<p id="_1848" tabindex="-1">

5784Radiation therapy has become part of the standard of care for patients with high-risk disease and is usually delivered after high-dose chemotherapy and stem cell rescue. For more information, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_214">

5785Treatment of High-Risk Neuroblastoma</a>

5786 section.</p>

5787<p id="_2441" tabindex="-1">

5788Limiting the use of radiation therapy in infants with neuroblastoma (who generally have non&#8211;high-risk disease) is supported by long-term follow-up data from the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study. This study demonstrated higher rates of second malignant neoplasms and significant chronic health conditions in infants who were treated with radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.38">

578938</a>

5790][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5791Level of evidence C1</a>

5792]</p>

5793</section>

5794<section id="_816">

5795<h3 id="_816_toc">

5796Treatment of Spinal Cord Compression</h3>

5797<p id="_869" tabindex="-1">

5798<strong>

5799Spinal cord compression is considered a medical emergency.</strong>

5800 Patients receive immediate treatment because neurological recovery is more likely when symptoms are present for a relatively short time before diagnosis and treatment. Recovery also depends on the severity of neurological defects (weakness vs. paralysis). Neurological outcome appears to be similar whether cord compression is treated with chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or surgery, although radiation therapy is used less frequently than in the past. </p>

5801<p id="_902" tabindex="-1">

5802The completed COG neuroblastoma clinical trials recommended immediate chemotherapy for cord compression in low-risk or intermediate-risk patients.[<a href="#cit/section_6.37">

580337</a>

5804,<a href="#cit/section_6.39">

580539</a>

5806,<a href="#cit/section_6.40">

580740</a>

5808] In a single study in this setting looking at the effect of glucocorticoids on neurological outcome, treatment was associated with improved early symptom relief. However, glucocorticoids did not prevent late residual impairment.[<a href="#cit/section_6.40">

580940</a>

5810]</p>

5811<p id="_870" tabindex="-1">

5812Children with severe spinal cord compression that does not promptly improve or those with worsening symptoms may benefit from neurosurgical intervention. Laminectomy may result in later kyphoscoliosis and may not eliminate the need for chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.37">

581337</a>

5814,<a href="#cit/section_6.39">

581539</a>

5816,<a href="#cit/section_6.40">

581740</a>

5818] It was thought that osteoplastic laminotomy, a procedure that does not remove bone, would result in less spinal deformity. Osteoplastic laminotomy may be associated with a lower incidence of progressive spinal deformity requiring fusion, but there is no evidence that functional neurological deficit is improved with laminoplasty.[<a href="#cit/section_6.41">

581941</a>

5820] </p>

5821<p id="_1855" tabindex="-1">

5822The burden of long-term health problems in survivors of neuroblastoma with intraspinal extension is high. In a systematic review of 28 studies of treatment and outcome of patients with intraspinal extension, the severity of the symptoms at diagnosis and the treatment modalities were most associated with the presence of long-term health problems. In particular, the severity of neurological motor deficits was most likely to predict neurological outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_6.42">

582342</a>

5824] The severity of motor deficits at diagnosis is associated with spinal deformity and sphincter dysfunction at the end of follow-up, while sphincter dysfunction at diagnosis was correlated with long-term sphincter problems.[<a href="#cit/section_6.43">

582543</a>

5826] This supports the initiation of treatment before symptoms have deteriorated to complete loss of neurological function.</p>

5827<p id="_1163" tabindex="-1">

5828In a series of 34 infants with symptomatic epidural spinal cord compression, both surgery and chemotherapy provided unsatisfactory results once paraplegia had been established. The frequency of grade 3 motor deficits and bowel dysfunction increased with a longer symptom duration interval. Most infants with symptomatic epidural spinal cord compression developed sequelae, which were severe in about one-half of patients.[<a href="#cit/section_6.44">

582944</a>

5830]</p>

5831</section>

5832<section id="_793">

5833<h3 id="_793_toc">

5834Surveillance During and After Treatment</h3>

5835<p id="_2393" tabindex="-1">

5836Although the role of surveillance imaging for detection of neuroblastoma relapse has not been well studied, most patients will undergo regular imaging tests after completing therapy. Many patients who relapse do not have their disease detected by scans, but rather present with symptoms. Factors such as risk stratification, disease sites, biomolecular markers, and cumulative radiation dose may be considered in surveillance after treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_6.45">

583745</a>

5838-<a href="#cit/section_6.47">

583947</a>

5840]</p>

5841<p id="_2484" tabindex="-1">

5842 In a series of 183 patients diagnosed with neuroblastoma, 50 patients experienced recurrence or progression. Relapsed disease was detected in most patients by symptoms/examination, MIBG scan, urinary catecholamines, and/or x-rays or ultrasonography.[<a href="#cit/section_6.47">

584347</a>

5844]</p>

5845<div class="pdq-content-list">

5846<ul id="_2394">

5847<li>

5848Of the 50 patients, 37 had clinically evident or measurable disease detected by x-ray, ultrasonography, or urinary catecholamines. The addition of MIBG scanning identified eight additional recurrences. </li>

5849<li>

5850The cross-sectional imaging (computed tomography [CT]/magnetic resonance imaging) was only required to identify 10% of cases (5 of 50).</li>

5851<li>

5852Thirty-two of the 50 relapses were detected by scheduled surveillance investigations, and 18 of the 50 (36%) relapses were detected because of new symptoms and/or history. </li>

5853<li>

5854Twenty-three of 50 relapses were associated with new concerning symptoms and/or examination. As a result, 18 of 50 patients had earlier-than-planned imaging performed, 17 of whom had new lesions that corresponded to the symptoms or examination. Seventeen of the 18 patients were high risk at diagnosis.</li>

5855</ul>

5856</div>

5857<p id="_1914" tabindex="-1">

5858Cross-sectional imaging with CT scans is controversial because of the amount of radiation received and the low proportion of relapses detected with this modality.[<a href="#cit/section_6.47">

585947</a>

5860]</p>

5861</section>

5862<h6 do-not-show="toc">

5863References</h6>
