6059

6060 <section id="_230">

6061

6062 <h2>

6063Treatment of Non–High-Risk Neuroblastoma</h2>

6064

6065 <div id="_section_230" class="pdq-sections">

6066<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

6067<h6>

6068In This Section</h6>

6069<ul>

6070<li>

6071<a href="#_2399_toc">

6072Low-Risk Neuroblastoma<ul>

6073<li>

6074<a href="#_461_toc">

6075Treatment options for low-risk neuroblastoma</a>

6076</li>

6077<li>

6078<a href="#_1022_toc">

6079Treatment options under clinical evaluation</a>

6080</li>

6081</ul>

6082</a>

6083</li>

6084<li>

6085<a href="#_203_toc">

6086Intermediate-Risk Neuroblastoma<ul>

6087<li>

6088<a href="#_462_toc">

6089Treatment options for intermediate-risk neuroblastoma</a>

6090</li>

6091<li>

6092<a href="#_1033_toc">

6093Treatment options under clinical evaluation</a>

6094</li>

6095</ul>

6096</a>

6097</li>

6098</ul>

6099</nav>

6100<section id="_2399">

6101<h3 id="_2399_toc">

6102Low-Risk Neuroblastoma</h3>

6103<p id="_757" tabindex="-1">

6104Low-risk neuroblastoma represents nearly one-half of all newly diagnosed patients. The success of previous Children's Oncology Group (COG) clinical trials has contributed to the continued reduction in therapy for select patients with neuroblastoma. According to the COG risk categorization, patients with low-risk disease generally have low-stage disease (International Neuroblastoma Staging System [INSS] stage 1, 2A, or 2B, and International Neuroblastoma Risk Group [INRGSS] stage L1) and the tumors are <em class="gene-name">

6105MYCN</em>

6106-nonamplified, hyperdiploid, and have favorable histology. For more information about the COG risk categories, see <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_2398">

6107Table 5</a>

6108.</p>

6109<p id="_849" tabindex="-1">

6110For more information about low-stage disease, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_772">

6111Treatment of INSS Stage 4S and INRG Stage MS Neuroblastoma</a>

6112 section.</p>

6113<section id="_461">

6114<h4 id="_461_toc">

6115Treatment options for low-risk neuroblastoma</h4>

6116<p id="_759" tabindex="-1">

6117For patients with localized disease that appears to be resectable (either based on the absence of image-defined risk factors [L1] or on the surgeon's expertise), the tumor should be resected by an experienced surgeon. If the biology is confirmed to be favorable, residual disease after surgery is not considered a risk factor for relapse and chemotherapy is not indicated. Several studies have shown that patients with favorable biology and residual disease have excellent outcomes, with event-free survival (EFS) rates exceeding 90% and overall survival (OS) rates ranging from 99% to 100%.[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

61181</a>

6119,<a href="#cit/section_7.2">

61202</a>

6121] </p>

6122<p id="_2485" tabindex="-1">

6123Some patients with presumed neuroblastoma have been observed without biopsy. The COG is studying this strategy further in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02176967">

6124ANBL1232 (NCT02176967)</a>

6125 trial (closed to accrual).[<a href="#cit/section_7.3">

61263</a>

6127,<a href="#cit/section_7.4">

61284</a>

6129]</p>

6130<p id="_620" tabindex="-1">

6131Treatment options for low-risk neuroblastoma include the following:</p>

6132<div class="pdq-content-list">

6133<ol id="_621">

6134<li>

6135<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_818">

6136Surgery followed by observation</a>

6137 (children &gt;1 year with INSS stage 1 or 2).</li>

6138<li>

6139<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_821">

6140Observation with or without biopsy</a>

6141. <div class="pdq-content-list">

6142<ul id="_2406">

6143<li>

6144Observation without biopsy (for perinatal neuroblastoma with small adrenal tumors). The COG experience with observation of apparent neuroblastoma without diagnostic biopsy is limited and under investigation.</li>

6145<li>

6146Observation with biopsy (for infants aged &lt;12 months with stage 4S disease without hepatomegaly and <em class="gene-name">

6147MYCN</em>

6148-nonamplified tumors; infants aged &lt;12 months with localized disease, favorable histology and genomics, and <em class="gene-name">

6149MYCN</em>

6150-nonamplified tumors with no segmental chromosomal aberrations).</li>

6151</ul>

6152</div>

6153 </li>

6154<li>

6155<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_760">

6156Chemotherapy with or without surgery</a>

6157 (for symptomatic disease or unresectable progressive disease after surgery).</li>

6158<li>

6159Radiation therapy (only for emergency therapy).</li>

6160</ol>

6161</div>

6162<section id="_818">

6163<h5 id="_818_toc">

6164Surgery followed by observation</h5>

6165<p id="_819" tabindex="-1">

6166Treatment for patients categorized as low risk may be surgery alone. For more information, see <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_2398">

6167Table 5</a>

6168.</p>

6169<p id="_1915" tabindex="-1">

6170Evidence (surgery followed by observation):</p>

6171<div class="pdq-content-list">

6172<ol id="_1916">

6173<li>

6174Results from the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003119">

6175COG-P9641</a>

6176 study showed that surgery alone, even without complete resection, can cure nearly all patients with stage 1 neuroblastoma and the vast majority of patients with asymptomatic, favorable-biology, and INSS stage 2A or stage 2B disease.[<a href="#cit/section_7.2">

61772</a>

6178] </li>

6179<li>

6180Similar outcomes were seen in a nonrandomized clinical trial in Japan.[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

61815</a>

6182]</li>

6183</ol>

6184</div>

6185</section>

6186<section id="_821">

6187<h5 id="_821_toc">

6188Observation with or without biopsy</h5>

6189<p id="_1186" tabindex="-1">

6190Observation without biopsy has been used to treat perinatal neuroblastoma with small adrenal tumors.</p>

6191<p id="_822" tabindex="-1">

6192 A COG study determined that selected small INSS stage 1 or stage 2 adrenal masses, presumed to be neuroblastoma, detected in infants younger than 6 months by screening or incidental ultrasonography, may safely be observed without obtaining a definitive histological diagnosis and without surgical intervention. This technique avoids potential complications of surgery in newborn patients.[<a href="#cit/section_7.3">

61933</a>

6194] Patients are observed frequently to detect any tumor growth or spread, indicating a need for intervention. Additional studies, including an expansion of criteria allowing observation without surgery, are under way in the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02176967">

6195ANBL1232 (NCT02176967)</a>

6196 study (closed to accrual).</p>

6197<p id="_823" tabindex="-1">

6198Evidence (observation without biopsy):</p>

6199<div class="pdq-content-list">

6200<ol id="_824">

6201<li>

6202The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00445718">

6203COG-ANBL00P2</a>

6204 study reported that expectant observation is safe in patients younger than 6 months with solid adrenal tumors smaller than 3.1 cm (or cystic tumors smaller than 5 cm) and INSS stage 1 disease.[<a href="#cit/section_7.3">

62053</a>

6206]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6207<ul id="_837">

6208<li>

6209Sixty-seven of 83 patients (81%) demonstrated spontaneous regression and avoided surgical intervention.</li>

6210<li>

6211Eighty-three of 87 eligible patients were observed without biopsy or resection; only 16 patients (19%) ultimately underwent surgery.</li>

6212<li>

6213The 3-year EFS rate for a neuroblastoma event was 97.7%, and the OS rate was 100%.</li>

6214</ul>

6215</div>

6216</li>

6217</ol>

6218</div>

6219<p id="_1920" tabindex="-1">

6220Controversy exists about the need to attempt resection, at the time of diagnosis or later, in asymptomatic infants aged 12 months or younger with apparent stage 2B and stage 3 <em class="gene-name">

6221MYCN</em>

6222-nonamplified and favorable-biology disease. In a German clinical trial, some of these patients were observed after biopsy or partial resection without chemotherapy or radiation therapy. Many patients did not progress locally and never underwent a first or additional resection.[<a href="#cit/section_7.4">

62234</a>

6224] In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02176967">

6225ANBL1232 (NCT02176967)</a>

6226 study (closed to accrual), infants younger than 18 months who have L2 tumors with favorable biology are being observed after tumor biopsy. </p>

6227</section>

6228<section id="_760">

6229<h5 id="_760_toc">

6230Chemotherapy with or without surgery</h5>

6231<p id="_1185" tabindex="-1">

6232Chemotherapy with or without surgery is used to treat the following:</p>

6233<div class="pdq-content-list">

6234<ul id="_1917">

6235<li>

6236Symptomatic disease. The chemotherapy regimen consists of carboplatin, cyclophosphamide,

6237doxorubicin, and etoposide. The cumulative chemotherapy dose of each agent is kept low to minimize long-term effects.[<a href="#cit/section_7.2">

62382</a>

6239] </li>

6240<li>

6241Unresectable progressive disease after surgery. </li>

6242</ul>

6243</div>

6244<p id="_761" tabindex="-1">

6245Evidence (for removal of chemotherapy):</p>

6246<div class="pdq-content-list">

6247<ol id="_762">

6248<li>

6249The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003119">

6250COG-P9641</a>

6251 study was one of the first COG studies to test risk stratification based on consensus-derived factors. In this phase III nonrandomized trial, 915 infants and children with INSS stage 2A and 2B disease underwent an initial operation to obtain tissue for diagnosis and biology studies and for maximal safe primary tumor resection. Chemotherapy was reserved for patients with, or at risk of, symptomatic disease, with less than 50% tumor resection at diagnosis, or with unresectable progressive disease after surgery alone.[<a href="#cit/section_7.2">

62522</a>

6253]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6254<ol id="_2407" class="lower-alpha">

6255<li>

6256<strong>

6257Stage 1:</strong>

6258 <div class="pdq-content-list">

6259<ul id="_2408">

6260<li>

6261Patients with stage 1 disease achieved a 5-year EFS rate of 93% and a 5-year OS rate of 99%.</li>

6262</ul>

6263</div>

6264</li>

6265<li>

6266<strong>

6267Stage 2A and 2B:</strong>

6268<div class="pdq-content-list">

6269<ul id="_2409">

6270<li>

6271 Asymptomatic patients with stage 2A and 2B disease (n = 306) who were observed after initial operation had a 5-year EFS rate of 87% and an OS rate of 96%. </li>

6272<li>

6273The EFS rate was significantly better for patients with stage 2A than for patients with stage 2B neuroblastoma (92% vs. 85%; <em>

6274P</em>

6275 = .0321), but OS did not differ significantly (98% vs. 96%; <em>

6276P</em>

6277 = .2867). </li>

6278<li>

6279The primary study objective (to achieve a 3-year OS rate of 95% for asymptomatic patients with stage 2A and 2B disease) was met. </li>

6280<li>

6281Patients with stage 2B disease had a lower EFS and OS if they had an unfavorable histology (EFS rate, 72%; OS rate, 86%) or diploid tumors (EFS rate, 75%; OS rate, 84%) or were older than 18 months. </li>

6282<li>

6283Outcomes for patients with stage 2B, diploid tumors, and unfavorable histology were particularly poor (EFS rate, 54%; OS rate, 70%), with no survivors among the few patients who had additional 1p loss of heterozygosity. </li>

6284<li>

6285All the deaths occurred in children older than 18 months.</li>

6286</ul>

6287</div>

6288</li>

6289<li>

6290<strong>

6291Outcome of asymptomatic patients at diagnosis who were observed after initial operation and patients treated with chemotherapy postoperatively:</strong>

6292 Of the initial 915 patients, 800 were asymptomatic at diagnosis and observed after their initial operations. Within this group, 11% of patients experienced recurrent or progressive disease. Of the 115 patients who underwent surgery followed by immediate chemotherapy (median, 4 cycles; range, 1&#8211;8 cycles), 81% of the patients had a very good partial response or better. After chemotherapy, 10% of the patients had disease recurrence or progression. <div class="pdq-content-list">

6293<ul id="_2410">

6294<li>

6295For patients treated with surgery alone, the 5-year EFS rate was 89%, and the OS estimate was 97%.</li>

6296<li>

6297For patients treated with surgery and immediate chemotherapy, the 5-year EFS rate was 91%, and the OS estimate was 98%.</li>

6298</ul>

6299</div>

6300</li>

6301<li>

6302<strong>

6303<em class="gene-name">

6304MYCN</em>

6305 amplification:</strong>

6306 The impact of <em class="gene-name">

6307MYCN</em>

6308-amplified tumors was analyzed in patients with stage 1 disease.<div class="pdq-content-list">

6309<ul id="_2411">

6310<li>

6311 For patients with <em class="gene-name">

6312MYCN</em>

6313-nonamplified tumors, the 5-year EFS rate was 93%, and the OS rate was 99%.</li>

6314<li>

6315For patients with <em class="gene-name">

6316MYCN</em>

6317-amplified tumors, the 5-year EFS rate was 70% (<em>

6318P</em>

6319 = .0042), and the OS rate was 80% (<em>

6320P</em>

6321 &lt; .001).</li>

6322</ul>

6323</div>

6324</li>

6325</ol>

6326</div>

6327</li>

6328</ol>

6329</div>

6330</section>

6331</section>

6332<section id="_1022">

6333<h4 id="_1022_toc">

6334Treatment options under clinical evaluation</h4>

6335<p id="_1023" tabindex="-1">

6336Information about National Cancer Institute (NCI)&#8211;supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

6337NCI website</a>

6338. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

6339ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

6340.</p>

6341<section id="_TrialSearch_1022_sid_5">

6342<h5 id="_TrialSearch_1022_sid_5_toc">

6343Current Clinical Trials</h5>

6344<p id="_TrialSearch_1022_22" tabindex="-1">

6345Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

6346advanced clinical trial search</a>

6347 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

6348General information</a>

6349 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

6350</section>

6351</section>

6352</section>

6353<section id="_203">

6354<h3 id="_203_toc">

6355Intermediate-Risk Neuroblastoma</h3>

6356<p id="_2400" tabindex="-1">

6357According to the COG risk classification, intermediate risk includes the following: </p>

6358<div class="pdq-content-list">

6359<ul id="_2486">

6360<li>

6361Patients with stage 2A or 2B disease, with resection of less than 50% or biopsy only of <em class="gene-name">

6362MYCN</em>

6363-nonamplified tumors.</li>

6364<li>

6365Patients with <em class="gene-name">

6366MYCN</em>

6367 nonamplified stage 2A/2B or 4S disease who are symptomatic.</li>

6368<li>

6369 Children younger than 18 months with stage 3 disease without <em class="gene-name">

6370MYCN</em>

6371 amplification (regardless of histology).</li>

6372<li>

6373 Children older than 18 months with stage 3 disease, <em class="gene-name">

6374MYCN</em>

6375-nonamplified and favorable histology.</li>

6376<li>

6377 Infants younger than 12 months with stage 4 disease and <em class="gene-name">

6378MYCN</em>

6379-nonamplified, favorable histology.</li>

6380<li>

6381 Infants aged 12 to 18 months with stage 4, <em class="gene-name">

6382MYCN</em>

6383-nonamplified, favorable histology, and hyperdiploid tumors.</li>

6384</ul>

6385</div>

6386<p id="_2487" tabindex="-1">

6387 A subset of 4S patients were included and classified as intermediate risk if they had diploid tumor or unfavorable histology and no <em class="gene-name">

6388MYCN</em>

6389 amplification. </p>

6390<p id="_2488" tabindex="-1">

6391For more information about the COG risk categories, see <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_2398">

6392Table 5</a>

6393.</p>

6394<p id="_1857" tabindex="-1">

6395The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003093">

6396COG-A3961 (NCT00003093)</a>

6397 intermediate-risk study results,[<a href="#cit/section_7.6">

63986</a>

6399] associated with results from European studies, were used to redefine the intermediate-risk groupings used in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00499616">

6400ANBL0531 (NCT00499616)</a>

6401 trial.[<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

64027</a>

6403] </p>

6404<p id="_2395" tabindex="-1">

6405For more information about the pretreatment classification schema for intermediate-risk neuroblastoma, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1134">

6406International Neuroblastoma Risk Grouping (INRG)</a>

6407 section.</p>

6408<p id="_850" tabindex="-1">

6409For more information about 4S and MS tumors, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_772">

6410Treatment of INSS Stage 4S and INRG Stage MS Neuroblastoma</a>

6411 section.</p>

6412<section id="_462">

6413<h4 id="_462_toc">

6414Treatment options for intermediate-risk neuroblastoma</h4>

6415<p id="_640" tabindex="-1">

6416Treatment options for intermediate-risk neuroblastoma include the following:</p>

6417<div class="pdq-content-list">

6418<ol id="_641">

6419<li>

6420<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_642">

6421Chemotherapy with or without surgery</a>

6422.</li>

6423<li>

6424<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_651">

6425Surgery and observation</a>

6426 (in infants).</li>

6427<li>

6428<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_656">

6429Radiation therapy</a>

6430 (if needed).</li>

6431</ol>

6432</div>

6433<section id="_642">

6434<h5 id="_642_toc">

6435Chemotherapy with or without surgery</h5>

6436<p id="_643" tabindex="-1">

6437Patients categorized as intermediate risk have been successfully treated with complete surgical resection

6438and two, four, or eight cycles of neoadjuvant chemotherapy. The chemotherapy regimen consists of carboplatin, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, and etoposide. The cumulative dose of each agent is kept low to minimize long-term effects from the chemotherapy regimen

6439

6440 (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00499616">

6441ANBL0531 [NCT00499616]</a>

6442).

6443As a rule, patients whose tumors had unfavorable biology received eight cycles of chemotherapy, compared with either two or four cycles for patients whose tumors had favorable biology.

6444

6445 </p>

6446<p id="_1858" tabindex="-1">

6447In cases of abdominal neuroblastoma thought to involve a kidney, nephrectomy is not undertaken before a course of chemotherapy has been given.[<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

64488</a>

6449] Nephrectomy should be avoided.</p>

6450<p id="_644" tabindex="-1">

6451Whether initial chemotherapy is indicated for all intermediate-risk infants with localized neuroblastoma requires further study.</p>

6452<p id="_645" tabindex="-1">

6453Evidence (chemotherapy with or without surgery):</p>

6454<div class="pdq-content-list">

6455<ol id="_646">

6456<li>

6457The goal of the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00499616">

6458ANBL0531 (NCT00499616)</a>

6459 study was to reduce therapy for subsets of patients with intermediate-risk neuroblastoma (<em class="gene-name">

6460MYCN</em>

6461-nonamplified, age and stage defined). Treatment duration (two, four, or eight cycles of moderate-dose neoadjuvant chemotherapy) was assigned according to clinical features and a tumor biology (including allelic status of 1p36 and 11q23) and response-based algorithm. The 3-year EFS and OS rates for the entire study cohort (N = 404) were 83.2% and 94.9%, respectively. Treatment duration and intensity was reduced for several subsets of patients. The study added stage 4 patients with favorable biology who were aged 12 to 18 months.[<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

64627</a>

6463]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6464<ul id="_647">

6465<li>

6466In the legacy (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003093">

6467A3961 [NCT00003093]</a>

6468) study, the administration of neoadjuvant chemotherapy facilitated at least a partial resection of 99.6% of previously unresectable tumors. No significant difference was noted in OS according to the degree of resection accomplished (complete vs. incomplete) in either study.[<a href="#cit/section_7.6">

64696</a>

6470,<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

64717</a>

6472] </li>

6473<li>

6474Less than 3% of patients in the ANBL0531 study received local radiation therapy, and only the patients with progressive hepatic enlargement or spinal cord compression received radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

64757</a>

6476]</li>

6477<li>

6478The 3-year EFS rate was 92% for patients with stage 3 disease with favorable histopathology (n = 269); 90% for patients with stage 4S disease and unfavorable biology, including diploidy or unfavorable histology (n = 31); and 81% for infants with stage 4 disease (n = 176) (<em>

6479P</em>

6480 &lt; .001 for stages 3 and 4S vs. stage 4). </li>

6481<li>

6482Infants with stage 4 disease with favorable biology (n = 61) had a superior 3-year EFS, compared with those with confirmed unfavorable biology tumors (n = 47) (3-year EFS rate, 86.9% vs. 66.8%; <em>

6483P</em>

6484 = .02), although OS was not significantly different (3-year OS rate, 95.0% vs. 86.7%; <em>

6485P</em>

6486 = .08).</li>

6487<li>

6488Only infants were stratified by ploidy. Those with diploid tumors received eight versus four cycles of chemotherapy. The 3-year OS rate estimates were 98% for stage 3 disease, 97% for stage 4S disease, and 93% for stage 4 disease (<em>

6489P</em>

6490 = .002 for stages 3 and 4S vs. stage 4). Infants with diploidy had a poorer outcome (<em>

6491P</em>

6492 = .03), as did all patients with diploidy studied, when combined (<em>

6493P</em>

6494 = .03).</li>

6495<li>

6496In patients with favorable biological features, there was no difference in OS between those who received eight cycles of chemotherapy (100%) for persistent disease and those who received four cycles (96%).</li>

6497<li>

6498There was no unexpected toxicity. </li>

6499</ul>

6500</div>

6501</li>

6502<li>

6503A German prospective clinical trial enrolled 340 infants aged 1 year or younger whose tumors were stage 1, 2, or 3; histologically verified; and lacked <em class="gene-name">

6504MYCN</em>

6505 amplification. Chemotherapy was given at diagnosis to 57 infants with organs threatened by the tumor. The tumor was completely resected or nearly so in 190 infants who underwent low-risk surgery. A total of 93 infants whose tumors were not resectable without high-risk surgery because of age or organ involvement were observed without chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.4">

65064</a>

6507] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6508<ul id="_648">

6509<li>

6510The 3-year OS rate was excellent (95%) for infants who received chemotherapy.</li>

6511<li>

6512Further surgery was avoided in 33 infants, and chemotherapy was avoided in 72 infants. </li>

6513<li>

6514The 3-year OS rate for the infants who were observed without treatment was 99%. The metastases-free survival rate was 94% for infants with unresected tumors and did not differ from the rate for infants treated with surgery or chemotherapy (median follow-up, 58 months). </li>

6515<li>

6516Forty-four of 93 infants with unresected tumors experienced spontaneous regression (17 were complete regressions), and 39 infants experienced progression.</li>

6517<li>

6518The investigators suggested that a wait-and-see strategy is appropriate for infants with localized neuroblastoma because regressions have been observed after the first year of life.</li>

6519</ul>

6520</div>

6521</li>

6522<li>

6523Moderate-dose chemotherapy has been shown to be effective in the prospective Infant Neuroblastoma European Study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00025597">

6524EURO-INF-NB-STUDY-1999-99.1</a>

6525). About one-half of the infants with unresectable, nonmetastatic neuroblastoma and no <em class="gene-name">

6526MYCN</em>

6527 amplification underwent a safe surgical resection and avoided long-term adverse effects.[<a href="#cit/section_7.9">

65289</a>

6529][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6530Level of evidence C1</a>

6531]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6532<ul id="_649">

6533<li>

6534The 5-year OS rate was 99%, and the EFS rate was 90% (median follow-up, 6 years).</li>

6535<li>

6536In this study, infants who underwent surgical resection had a better EFS than did those who did not have surgery.</li>

6537</ul>

6538</div>

6539</li>

6540<li>

6541A prospective International Society of Paediatric Oncology Europe Neuroblastoma (SIOPEN) trial treated infants with <em class="gene-name">

6542MYCN</em>

6543 nonamplified stage 2 or stage 3 unresectable neuroblastoma, as well as those aged 12 to 18 months who had favorable International Neuroblastoma Pathology Classification.[<a href="#cit/section_7.10">

654410</a>

6545][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6546Level of evidence C2</a>

6547]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6548<ul id="_952">

6549<li>

6550The EFS rate was 98% with conventional chemotherapy.</li>

6551<li>

6552These results are similar to results from the COG-A3961 trial.</li>

6553</ul>

6554</div>

6555</li>

6556<li>

6557 In two European prospective trials of infants with disseminated neuroblastoma without <em class="gene-name">

6558MYCN</em>

6559 gene amplification, infants with INSS stage 3 primary or positive skeletal scintigraphy without radiological bone metastasis (identified mostly by MIBG scan, but a few with just technetium Tc 99m bone scan) were not administered chemotherapy unless life-threatening or organ-threatening symptoms developed. When given, chemotherapy consisted of short and standard doses.[<a href="#cit/section_7.11">

656011</a>

6561]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6562<ul id="_851">

6563<li>

6564The OS rate was 100% in the 41 patients who did not have INSS stage 4S, regardless of initial chemotherapy.</li>

6565<li>

6566In infants with overt metastases to the skeleton, lung, and central nervous system (by radionuclide scan, but not by plain x-ray or computed tomography [CT] scan), the 2-year OS rate was 96% (n = 45).</li>

6567<li>

6568No patients died of surgery-related or chemotherapy-related complications on either protocol. </li>

6569</ul>

6570</div>

6571</li>

6572<li>

6573A retrospective analysis from the COG evaluated patients aged 12 to 18 months with metastatic disease and favorable biological features. In legacy trials, these patients were treated with high-risk disease regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_7.12">

657412</a>

6575]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6576<ul id="_2525">

6577<li>

6578This analysis demonstrated that this group of patients had similar excellent outcomes with intermediate-risk therapy, compared with high-risk therapy. These patients are now treated with intermediate-risk therapy in current clinical trials.</li>

6579</ul>

6580</div>

6581</li>

6582</ol>

6583</div>

6584</section>

6585<section id="_651">

6586<h5 id="_651_toc">

6587Surgery and observation (in infants)</h5>

6588<p id="_652" tabindex="-1">

6589The need for chemotherapy in all asymptomatic infants with stage 3 or stage 4 disease is controversial, as some European studies have shown favorable outcomes with surgery and observation.[<a href="#cit/section_7.11">

659011</a>

6591] </p>

6592<p id="_653" tabindex="-1">

6593Evidence (surgery and observation in infants):</p>

6594<div class="pdq-content-list">

6595<ol id="_654">

6596<li>

6597A French study classified infants as stage 4 because of a primary tumor infiltrating across the midline (INSS stage 3 primary with metastases limited to 4S category) or positive bone scintigraphy not associated with changes in the cortical bone documented on plain radiographs and/or CT.[<a href="#cit/section_7.13">

659813</a>

6599]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6600<ul id="_2489">

6601<li>

6602Infants with this classification were reported to have a better outcome with less aggressive chemotherapy than were other stage 4 infants (EFS rate, 90% vs. 27%).</li>

6603<li>

6604 However, a much higher proportion of those with radiologically demonstrated cortical bone lesions also had tumors with <em class="gene-name">

6605MYCN</em>

6606 amplification.</li>

6607</ul>

6608</div>

6609</li>

6610<li>

6611Building on the French study, SIOPEN conducted a prospective trial of 125 infants (n = 41 with INSS 3 primary tumors or positive scintigraphy) with disseminated neuroblastoma without <em class="gene-name">

6612MYCN</em>

6613 amplification to determine whether these patients could be observed in the absence of symptoms. However, treating physicians did not always follow the wait-and-see strategy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.11">

661411</a>

6615]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6616<ul id="_852">

6617<li>

6618There was no significant difference in 2-year OS rates between patients with unresectable primary tumors and patients with resectable primary tumors (97% vs. 100%) and between patients with negative and positive skeletal scintigraphy without radiological abnormalities (100% vs. 97%).</li>

6619</ul>

6620</div>

6621</li>

6622<li>

6623A German prospective clinical trial enrolled 340 infants aged 1 year or younger whose tumors were stage 1, 2, or 3; verified histologically; and lacked <em class="gene-name">

6624MYCN</em>

6625 amplification. Of the 190 infants who underwent resection, 8 had stage 3 disease. A total of 93 infants whose tumors were not resectable without high-risk surgery, because of age or organ involvement, were observed without chemotherapy, which included 21 stage 3 patients. Fifty-seven infants, including 41 stage 3 patients, were treated with chemotherapy to control threatening symptoms.[<a href="#cit/section_7.4">

66264</a>

6627]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6628<ul id="_853">

6629<li>

6630The 3-year OS rate was excellent for the entire group of infants with unresected tumors (99%), infants who received chemotherapy (95%), and infants with resected tumors (98%) (<em>

6631P</em>

6632 = .45). </li>

6633</ul>

6634</div>

6635</li>

6636</ol>

6637</div>

6638</section>

6639<section id="_656">

6640<h5 id="_656_toc">

6641Radiation therapy </h5>

6642<p id="_657" tabindex="-1">

6643Radiation therapy for children with intermediate-risk disease is reserved for patients with progressive disease during treatment with chemotherapy or progressive unresectable disease after treatment with chemotherapy.</p>

6644<p id="_1921" tabindex="-1">

6645In a prospective randomized COG trial that tested reduced-intensity chemotherapy for patients with intermediate-risk neuroblastoma, only 12 of 479 patients (2.5%) received local radiation therapy (21 Gy). One patient had stage 4S disease, five patients had stage 3 disease, and six patients had stage 4 disease. Radiation therapy was administered for clinical deterioration despite initial therapy (eight patients), residual macroscopic disease and unfavorable biological features (three patients), or relapse after therapy (one patient).[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

66461</a>

6647,<a href="#cit/section_7.6">

66486</a>

6649,<a href="#cit/section_7.14">

665014</a>

6651]</p>

6652</section>

6653</section>

6654<section id="_1033">

6655<h4 id="_1033_toc">

6656Treatment options under clinical evaluation</h4>

6657<p id="_1034" tabindex="-1">

6658Information about National Cancer Institute (NCI)&#8211;supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

6659NCI website</a>

6660. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

6661ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

6662.</p>

6663<section id="_TrialSearch_1033_sid_11">

6664<h5 id="_TrialSearch_1033_sid_11_toc">

6665Current Clinical Trials</h5>

6666<p id="_TrialSearch_1033_22" tabindex="-1">

6667Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

6668advanced clinical trial search</a>

6669 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

6670General information</a>

6671 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

6672</section>

6673</section>

6674</section>

6704[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6708[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6709</li>

6710<li id="section_7.9">

J Clin Oncol 29 (4): 449-55, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21172879&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21172879&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6712[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6713</li>

6714<li id="section_7.10">

Eur J Cancer 49 (17): 3671-9, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23907002&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23907002&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6716[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6720[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6721</li>

6724[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6725</li>

6726<li id="section_7.13">

6727Minard V, Hartmann O, Peyroulet MC, et al.: Adverse outcome of infants with metastatic neuroblastoma, MYCN amplification and/or bone lesions: results of the French society of pediatric oncology. Br J Cancer 83 (8): 973-9, 2000.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10993641&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10993641&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6728[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6729</li>

6730<li id="section_7.14">

6731Kim C, Choi YB, Lee JW, et al.: Excellent treatment outcomes in children younger than 18 months with stage 4 MYCN nonamplified neuroblastoma. Korean J Pediatr 61 (2): 53-58, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29563945&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29563945&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6732[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6733</li>

6734</ol>

6735</div>

6736

6737 </section>

6738

6739

6740

6741 <section id="_214">

6742

6743 <h2>

6744Treatment of High-Risk Neuroblastoma</h2>

6745

6746 <div id="_section_214" class="pdq-sections">

6747<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

6748<h6>

6749In This Section</h6>

6750<ul>

6751<li>

6752<a href="#_707_toc">

6753Treatment Options for High-Risk Neuroblastoma<ul>

6754<li>

6755<a href="#_661_toc">

6756Chemotherapy, surgery, tandem cycles of myeloablative therapy and SCT, radiation therapy, and dinutuximab with GM-CSF and isotretinoin</a>

6757</li>

6758</ul>

6759</a>

6760</li>

6761<li>

6762<a href="#_1817_toc">

6763Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation<ul>

6764<li>

6765<a href="#_TrialSearch_1817_sid_8_toc">

6766Current Clinical Trials</a>

6767</li>

6768</ul>

6769</a>

6770</li>

6771</ul>

6772</nav>

6773<p id="_2401" tabindex="-1">

6774Patients most at risk for disease progression and mortality are older than 18 months, have metastatic disease or localized disease with unfavorable biology such as <em class="gene-name">

6775MYCN</em>

6776 amplification, or have unfavorable histology. For more information about the Children's Oncology Group (COG) risk categories, see <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_2398">

6777Table 5</a>

6778.</p>

6779<p id="_854" tabindex="-1">

6780Approximately 8% to 10% of infants with stage MS disease have <em class="gene-name">

6781MYCN</em>

6782-amplified tumors and are usually treated using high-risk protocols. The 5-year event-free survival (EFS) and overall survival (OS) rates were 60% and 64%, respectively, for the infants with stage MS disease and <em class="gene-name">

6783MYCN</em>

6784 amplification (n = 23), among the 5,000 patients enrolled in the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00904241">

6785ANBL00B1 (NCT00904241)</a>

6786 trial.[<a href="#cit/section_8.1">

67871</a>

6788]</p>

6789<p id="_660" tabindex="-1">

6790For children with high-risk neuroblastoma who received current treatments, the 5-year OS rate was about 60% for patients diagnosed between 2007 and 2017.[<a href="#cit/section_8.1">

67911</a>

6792] Children with aggressively treated, high-risk neuroblastoma may develop late recurrences, some more than 5 years after completion of therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.2">

67932</a>

6794,<a href="#cit/section_8.3">

67953</a>

6796] </p>

6797<p id="_1015" tabindex="-1">

6798A study from the International Neuroblastoma Risk Group (INRG) database found 146 patients with distant metastases limited to lymph nodes, termed stage 4N, who tended to have favorable-biology disease and a good outcome (5-year OS rate, 85%). This finding suggests that for this special subgroup of high-risk, stage 4 patients, less-intensive therapy might be considered.[<a href="#cit/section_8.4">

67994</a>

6800]</p>

6801<section id="_707">

6802<h3 id="_707_toc">

6803Treatment Options for High-Risk Neuroblastoma</h3>

6804<p id="_789" tabindex="-1">

6805Outcomes for patients with high-risk neuroblastoma remain poor despite recent improvements in survival in randomized trials.</p>

6806<p id="_658" tabindex="-1">

6807Treatment options for high-risk neuroblastoma typically include the following:</p>

6808<div class="pdq-content-list">

6809<ol id="_659">

6810<li>

6811<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_661">

6812A regimen of chemotherapy, surgery, tandem cycles of myeloablative therapy and stem cell transplant (SCT), radiation therapy, and dinutuximab with granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) and isotretinoin</a>

6813.</li>

6814</ol>

6815</div>

6816<section id="_661">

6817<h4 id="_661_toc">

6818Chemotherapy, surgery, tandem cycles of myeloablative therapy and SCT, radiation therapy, and dinutuximab with GM-CSF and isotretinoin</h4>

6819<p id="_683" tabindex="-1">

6820Treatment for patients with high-risk disease is generally divided into the following three phases: </p>

6821<div class="pdq-content-list">

6822<ul id="_790">

6823<li>

6824<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_905">

6825Induction</a>

6826 (includes chemotherapy and surgical resection).</li>

6827<li>

6828<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_907">

6829Consolidation</a>

6830 (tandem cycles of myeloablative therapy and SCT and radiation therapy to the site of the primary tumor and residual metastatic sites).</li>

6831<li>

6832<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_912">

6833Postconsolidation</a>

6834 (immunotherapy with GM-CSF and isotretinoin therapy).</li>

6835</ul>

6836</div>

6837<section id="_905">

6838<h5 id="_905_toc">

6839Induction phase</h5>

6840<p id="_906" tabindex="-1">

6841The backbone of the most commonly used induction therapy includes dose-intensive cycles of cisplatin and etoposide alternating with vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and doxorubicin.[<a href="#cit/section_8.5">

68425</a>

6843] Topotecan and cyclophosphamide were added to this regimen on the basis of the antineuroblastoma activity seen in patients with relapsed disease.[<a href="#cit/section_8.6">

68446</a>

6845] Response to therapy after four cycles of chemotherapy or at the end of induction chemotherapy correlates with EFS at the completion of high-risk therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.7">

68467</a>

6847-<a href="#cit/section_8.9">

68489</a>

6849] </p>

6850<p id="_2490" tabindex="-1">

6851Evidence (induction chemotherapy with or without additional treatments):</p>

6852<div class="pdq-content-list">

6853<ol id="_2491">

6854<li>

6855In one study, the addition of dinutuximab anti-GD2 treatment with GM-CSF and low-dose interleukin-2 (IL-2), given with each induction chemotherapy course, had encouraging outcomes in 42 children with newly diagnosed stage 4 disease.[<a href="#cit/section_8.10">

685610</a>

6857]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6858<ul id="_2494">

6859<li>

6860 This induction therapy, followed by standard consolidation and postconsolidation therapy,

6861 produced early partial responses or better in most patients, reduced tumor volumes, and an encouraging 3-year EFS rate of 73.7%.</li>

6862</ul>

6863</div>

6864</li>

6865<li>

6866A European prospective randomized controlled trial investigated extended induction therapy in 422 patients with newly diagnosed high-risk neuroblastoma. Patients were randomly assigned to receive either standard induction chemotherapy with six chemotherapy courses or experimental induction chemotherapy that began with two additional courses of topotecan, cyclophosphamide, and etoposide, followed by standard induction chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.11">

686711</a>

6868][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6869Level of evidence B3</a>

6870]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6871<ul id="_2492">

6872<li>

6873 The 3-year EFS rate was 34% for patients who received the experimental induction regimen and 32% for patients who received the standard induction regimen.</li>

6874<li>

6875 The addition of two topotecan-containing chemotherapy courses did not improve the EFS of patients with high-risk neuroblastoma and resulted in more toxicity per patient.</li>

6876</ul>

6877</div>

6878</li>

6879<li>

6880European investigators completed another randomized study of induction regimens for patients with high-risk neuroblastoma. A total of 630 patients were randomly assigned to receive either cisplatin, vincristine, carboplatin, etoposide, and cyclophosphamide (rCOJEC regimen; n = 313) or the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center N5 induction regimens (MSKCC-N5; n = 317).[<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

688112</a>

6882][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6883Level of evidence B1</a>

6884]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6885<ul id="_2493">

6886<li>

6887 There were no significant differences in metastatic complete response rates between the two regimens (32% for rCOJEC vs. 35% for MSKCC-N5; <em>

6888P</em>

6889 = .368) or 3-year EFS rates (44% for rCOJEC vs. 47% for MSKCC-N5; <em>

6890P</em>

6891 = .527). </li>

6892<li>

6893 Patients who received the rCOJEC regimen experienced less acute toxicity. </li>

6894<li>

6895The rCOJEC regimen has been selected as the standard induction regimen for the next International Society of Pediatric Oncology European Neuroblastoma (SIOPEN) trial.</li>

6896</ul>

6897</div>

6898</li>

6899</ol>

6900</div>

6901<p id="_1224" tabindex="-1">

6902After a response to induction chemotherapy, resection of the primary tumor is usually attempted. Whether a gross-total resection is beneficial either before or after induction chemotherapy is controversial.[<a href="#cit/section_8.13">

690313</a>

6904]</p>

6905<p id="_1922" tabindex="-1">

6906Evidence (resection of the primary tumor before or after chemotherapy):</p>

6907<div class="pdq-content-list">

6908<ol id="_1923">

6909<li>

6910The COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00004188">

6911A3973 (NCT00004188)</a>

6912 study had central surgical review of 220 patients who underwent attempted gross-total resection after induction chemotherapy. By the surgeon&#8217;s estimate, the degree of resection was determined to be 90% or greater versus less than 90%, but only 63% concordance with central review of imaging was found.[<a href="#cit/section_8.14">

691314</a>

6914][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6915Level of evidence C1</a>

6916] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6917<ul id="_1924">

6918<li>

6919Nevertheless, the surgeon&#8217;s assessment of 90% or greater resection versus less than 90% resection predicted an EFS rate of 46% versus 38% (<em>

6920P</em>

6921 = .01), respectively, and a cumulative incidence of local relapse rate of 8.5% versus 20%, respectively.</li>

6922<li>

6923OS rates were not significantly different between the two groups (57% vs. 49%, <em>

6924P</em>

6925 = .3).</li>

6926<li>

6927The author's conclusion supports continued efforts to achieve greater than 90% resection to decrease local recurrence.</li>

6928</ul>

6929</div>

6930</li>

6931<li>

6932A single-center retrospective study of 87 children with high-risk neuroblastoma demonstrated no significant benefit of gross-total resection compared with near-total (&gt;90%) resection.[<a href="#cit/section_8.15">

693315</a>

6934][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6935Level of evidence C2</a>

6936] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6937<ul id="_1925">

6938<li>

6939However, the results suggest that greater than 90% resection is associated with improved OS compared with less than 90% resection.</li>

6940</ul>

6941</div>

6942</li>

6943</ol>

6944</div>

6945<p id="_1949" tabindex="-1">

6946The potential benefit of aggressive surgical approaches in high-risk patients with metastatic disease to achieve complete tumor resection, either at the time of diagnosis or after chemotherapy, has not been unequivocally demonstrated. Several studies have reported that complete resection of the primary tumor at diagnosis improved survival. However, the outcome in these patients may be more dependent on the biology of the tumor, which itself may determine resectability, than on the extent of surgical resection.[<a href="#cit/section_8.16">

694716</a>

6948-<a href="#cit/section_8.18">

694918</a>

6950]</p>

6951<p id="_2495" tabindex="-1">

6952 In stage 4 patients older than 18 months, controversy exists about whether there is any advantage to gross-total resection of the primary tumor after chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.14">

695314</a>

6954,<a href="#cit/section_8.17">

695517</a>

6956-<a href="#cit/section_8.19">

695719</a>

6958] In some studies, patients who underwent incomplete resections fared less well than those who underwent complete resections.[<a href="#cit/section_8.20">

695920</a>

6960] These outcomes could have resulted from either the biology of unresectable tumors or reduction of tumor bulk.[<a href="#cit/section_8.21">

696121</a>

6962][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6963Level of evidence B1</a>

6964] Complete resection that requires nephrectomy is not recommended because of the nephrotoxic nature of standard chemotherapy and unproven effect of complete resection on outcome.</p>

6965<p id="_2504" tabindex="-1">

6966At the end of induction therapy, patients with high-risk disease typically undergo a full disease evaluation. Management of patients with residual disease at the end of conventional induction therapy is not standardized. A retrospective study analyzed 201 patients with high-risk disease who had a partial response or less at the end of induction therapy. Patients were selected to immediately receive either high-dose chemotherapy (cohort 1), bridging therapy (usually chemoimmunotherapy of 131 I-MIBG) followed by high-dose chemotherapy (cohort 2), or additional therapy but not high-dose chemotherapy (cohort 3).[<a href="#cit/section_8.22">

696722</a>

6968]</p>

6969<div class="pdq-content-list">

6970<ul id="_2505">

6971<li>

6972Despite having less-favorable features, patients in cohort 2 had similar EFS compared with patients in cohort 1, while patients in cohort 3 had inferior EFS.</li>

6973<li>

6974Among patients with stable disease in metastatic sites at the end of induction therapy, patients in cohort 2 had superior EFS compared with patients in cohort 1.</li>

6975</ul>

6976</div>

6977<p id="_2506" tabindex="-1">

6978These retrospective data suggest a role for bridging therapy in patients with incomplete response to conventional induction therapy.</p>

6979</section>

6980<section id="_907">

6981<h5 id="_907_toc">

6982Consolidation phase</h5>

6983<p id="_908" tabindex="-1">

6984The consolidation phase of high-risk regimens involves myeloablative chemotherapy and SCT, which attempts to eradicate minimal residual disease (MRD) using otherwise lethal doses of ablative chemotherapy rescued by autologous stem cells (collected during induction chemotherapy) to repopulate the bone marrow. Several large randomized controlled studies have shown an improvement in 3-year EFS rates for treatment with SCT (31%&#8211;47%) versus conventional chemotherapy (22%&#8211;31%).[<a href="#cit/section_8.23">

698523</a>

6986-<a href="#cit/section_8.25">

698725</a>

6988] Previously, total-body irradiation had been used in SCT conditioning regimens. Most current protocols use tandem chemotherapy and SCT with carboplatin/etoposide/melphalan or busulfan/melphalan as conditioning for SCT.[<a href="#cit/section_8.26">

698926</a>

6990][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6991Level of evidence C1</a>

6992]</p>

6993<p id="_1245" tabindex="-1">

6994Evidence (myeloablative chemotherapy and stem cell rescue):</p>

6995<div class="pdq-content-list">

6996<ol id="_1246">

6997<li>

6998A large European multicenter trial of consolidation therapy randomly assigned patients who had completed a multidrug induction regimen (cisplatin, carboplatin, cyclophosphamide, vincristine, and etoposide with or without topotecan, vincristine, and doxorubicin) and achieved an adequate response to receive either busulfan/melphalan or carboplatin/etoposide/melphalan.[<a href="#cit/section_8.27">

699927</a>

7000][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7001Level of evidence A1</a>

7002]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7003<ul id="_1926">

7004<li>

7005Induction therapy with cisplatin, carboplatin, cyclophosphamide, vincristine, and etoposide, and consolidation for SCT with busulfan/melphalan resulted in an improved EFS, without an effect on OS or severe adverse events.</li>

7006</ul>

7007</div>

7008</li>

7009<li>

7010A randomized clinical study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00567567">

7011COG-ANBL0532</a>

7012) tested the efficacy of two cycles versus one cycle of myeloablative chemotherapy with stem cell rescue.[<a href="#cit/section_8.28">

701328</a>

7014][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7015Level of evidence A1</a>

7016] Children older than 18 months with stage 4 neuroblastoma who had received six cycles of induction chemotherapy were then randomly assigned to receive a single autologous SCT with carboplatin/etoposide/melphalan or tandem transplants with cyclophosphamide/thiotepa followed by reduced-dose carboplatin/etoposide/melphalan. After tumor bed radiation therapy, most patients were randomly assigned to a second separate trial to receive isotretinoin alone or isotretinoin with dinutuximab and immune enhancement. <div class="pdq-content-list">

7017<ul id="_1247">

7018<li>

7019The 3-year EFS rate from the time of randomization was 62% for tandem transplants and 48% for single SCT (<em>

7020P</em>

7021 = .006). The 3-year OS rate was 74% for tandem autologous SCTs and 69% for single autologous SCT (<em>

7022P</em>

7023 = .25).</li>

7024<li>

7025For randomized patients who subsequently received dinutuximab and immune enhancement, the 3-year EFS rate was 73% for tandem SCTs and 55% for single SCT (<em>

7026P</em>

7027 = .004), while the OS rate was 84% and 74%, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_8.28">

702828</a>

7029][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7030Level of evidence B1</a>

7031]</li>

7032<li>

7033These study results have an important limitation: a substantial portion of the patients were not randomly assigned to therapy (because of patient and provider preference), introducing a potential selection bias.</li>

7034</ul>

7035</div>

7036</li>

7037<li>

7038An updated Cochrane review evaluated three randomized clinical trials comparing autologous bone marrow transplant (BMT) with standard chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.23">

703923</a>

7040-<a href="#cit/section_8.25">

704125</a>

7042,<a href="#cit/section_8.29">

704329</a>

7044,<a href="#cit/section_8.30">

704530</a>

7046]

7047<div class="pdq-content-list">

7048<ul id="_953">

7049<li>

7050EFS was significantly better for autologous BMT, but there was no statistically significant difference in OS.</li>

7051</ul>

7052</div>

7053</li>

7054<li>

7055A review of 147 allogeneic transplant cases submitted to the Center for International Blood and Marrow Transplant Research found no advantage for allogeneic transplant over autologous transplant, even if the allogeneic transplant recipient had received a previous autologous transplant.[<a href="#cit/section_8.31">

705631</a>

7057]</li>

7058</ol>

7059</div>

7060<p id="_2501" tabindex="-1">

7061In a separate prospective, randomized study, there was no advantage to purging harvested stem cells of neuroblastoma cells before transplantation.[<a href="#cit/section_8.32">

706232</a>

7063]</p>

7064<p id="_909" tabindex="-1">

7065For more information about transplantation, see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/hp-stem-cell-transplant/autologous">

7066Pediatric Autologous Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation</a>

7067 and <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/hp-stem-cell-transplant">

7068Pediatric Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation and Cellular Therapy for Cancer</a>

7069.</p>

7070<p id="_910" tabindex="-1">

7071Radiation to the primary tumor site (whether or not a complete excision was obtained) is indicated after myeloablative therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.33">

707233</a>

7073,<a href="#cit/section_8.34">

707434</a>

7075]; [<a href="#cit/section_8.35">

707635</a>

7077][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7078Level of evidence C1</a>

7079] Boost radiation therapy for gross-residual disease was not shown to improve local control when studied prospectively in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00567567">

7080ANBL0532 (NCT00567567)</a>

7081 trial.[<a href="#cit/section_8.36">

708236</a>

7083][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7084Level of evidence C1</a>

7085] The optimal dose of radiation therapy has not been determined.[<a href="#cit/section_8.37">

708637</a>

7087]</p>

7088<p id="_2045" tabindex="-1">

7089Evidence (radiation therapy with a boost vs. radiation therapy without a boost for incomplete resection):</p>

7090<div class="pdq-content-list">

7091<ol id="_2046">

7092<li>

7093Because of the high rates of local recurrence after incomplete surgical resection, the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00567567">

7094ANBL0532 (NCT00567567)</a>

7095 trial prospectively evaluated the potential benefit of boost radiation therapy for patients with gross-residual tumor and compared the results with the preceding COG clinical trial for high-risk neuroblastoma (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00004188">

7096A3973 [NCT00004188]</a>

7097), in which patients did not receive boost radiation therapy. All patients on the ANBL0532 trial received 21.6 Gy of radiation to the preoperative primary tumor volume after induction chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.36">

709836</a>

7099][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7100Level of evidence C1</a>

7101]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7102<ul id="_2047">

7103<li>

7104There were no differences in outcomes between the patients in the ANBL0532 trial who received a single SCT and boost radiation therapy (n = 74) and the patients in the A3973 trial who underwent an incomplete resection and received no boost radiation therapy (n = 47).</li>

7105<li>

7106The 5-year cumulative incidence of local progression was 16.3% for patients in the ANBL0532 trial versus 10.6% for patients in the A3973 trial (<em>

7107P</em>

7108 = .4126).</li>

7109<li>

7110The EFS rate was 50.9% for patients in the ANBL0532 trial versus 48.9% for patients in the A3973 trial (<em>

7111P</em>

7112 = .5084). </li>

7113<li>

7114The OS rate was 68.1% for patients in the ANBL0532 trial versus 56.9% for patients in the A3973 trial (<em>

7115P</em>

7116 = .2835).</li>

7117<li>

7118Boost radiation therapy administered to gross residual tumor that was present at the end of induction did not significantly improve the 5-year cumulative incidence of local progression; therefore, it is not recommended.[<a href="#cit/section_8.36">

711936</a>

7120]</li>

7121</ul>

7122</div>

7123</li>

7124</ol>

7125</div>

7126<p id="_2392" tabindex="-1">

7127Extensive lymph node irradiation, regardless of the extent of surgical resection preceding SCT, did not benefit patients for local progression or OS.[<a href="#cit/section_8.38">

712838</a>

7129][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7130Level of evidence C1</a>

7131]</p>

7132<p id="_1952" tabindex="-1">

7133Treatment of bony metastatic disease, delivered at the time of primary tumor bed irradiation, is also considered to maximize disease control.

7134Radiation therapy to metastatic disease sites is determined on an individual basis or according to protocol guidelines for patients enrolled in studies. Many children present with widespread bony metastases. Because it is not feasible to irradiate all initial sites, the current practice is to treat the sites that have not responded, as assessed by MIBG before SCT.[<a href="#cit/section_8.39">

713539</a>

7136-<a href="#cit/section_8.41">

713741</a>

7138] Metastatic sites identified at diagnosis that did not receive radiation

7139during frontline therapy appeared to have a higher risk of involvement at first relapse

7140relative to previously irradiated metastatic sites.[<a href="#cit/section_8.39">

714139</a>

7142] </p>

7143<p id="_2496" tabindex="-1">

7144In a retrospective series of 159 children with high-risk stage M neuroblastoma, focal irradiation was delivered to all metastatic sites, regardless of response to chemotherapy, unless metastases were too numerous.[<a href="#cit/section_8.42">

714542</a>

7146] </p>

7147<div class="pdq-content-list">

7148<ul id="_2497">

7149<li>

7150 The 5-year control rate of irradiated metastatic sites was 81%.</li>

7151<li>

7152 Metastases that became MIBG negative after chemotherapy were significantly less likely to recur than the sites that remained MIBG positive.</li>

7153<li>

7154 Patients whose disease did not relapse in their irradiated metastatic sites had improved OS.</li>

7155<li>

7156 When feasible to deliver radiation therapy, including to sites that resolved with induction chemotherapy, radiation therapy was more than 90% effective in providing disease control in those metastatic sites.</li>

7157</ul>

7158</div>

7159<p id="_2498" tabindex="-1">

7160These observations support the current

7161paradigm of irradiating metastases that persist by MIBG uptake after induction chemotherapy in high-risk

7162patients.

7163Irradiation of more than 50% of the bone marrow is not advised.[<a href="#cit/section_8.42">

716442</a>

7165] </p>

7166<p id="_1948" tabindex="-1">

7167In cases where diffuse bone metastases remain after induction chemotherapy, high-dose chemotherapy is followed by reassessment before deciding on consolidative radiation therapy. </p>

7168<p id="_911" tabindex="-1">

7169Preliminary outcomes of proton radiation therapy to treat patients with high-risk neuroblastoma primary tumors have been published, demonstrating acceptable efficacy and toxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_8.43">

717043</a>

7171]</p>

7172</section>

7173<section id="_912">

7174<h5 id="_912_toc">

7175Postconsolidation phase</h5>

7176<p id="_913" tabindex="-1">

7177Postconsolidation therapy is designed to treat potential MRD after SCT.[<a href="#cit/section_8.29">

717829</a>

7179] For high-risk patients in remission after SCT, dinutuximab combined with GM-CSF given together with isotretinoin demonstrated improved EFS.[<a href="#cit/section_8.44">

718044</a>

7181,<a href="#cit/section_8.45">

718245</a>

7183]</p>

7184</section>

7185<p id="_662" tabindex="-1">

7186Evidence (all treatments):</p>

7187<div class="pdq-content-list">

7188<ol id="_663">

7189<li>

7190A randomized study compared high-dose therapy and purged autologous BMT with three cycles of intensive consolidation chemotherapy. In addition, after the completion of either chemotherapy or autologous BMT, patients were randomly assigned to stop therapy or to receive 6 months of isotretinoin. The EFS and OS results described below reflect outcome from the time of each randomization.[<a href="#cit/section_8.23">

719123</a>

7192]; [<a href="#cit/section_8.29">

719329</a>

7194][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7195Level of evidence A1</a>

7196]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7197<ul id="_668">

7198<li>

7199The 5-year EFS rate was significantly better in the ABMT arm (30%), than in the consolidation chemotherapy arm (19%; <em>

7200P</em>

7201 = .04). There was no significant difference in 5-year OS rates between the two arms (39% vs. 30%; <em>

7202P</em>

7203 = .08).</li>

7204<li>

7205 Patients who received isotretinoin had

7206a higher 5-year EFS rate than did patients who received no maintenance therapy (42% vs. 31%), although the difference was not significant (<em>

7207P</em>

7208 = .12). </li>

7209<li>

7210The OS rate was higher for patients randomly assigned to receive isotretinoin (50%) than for those who stopped therapy (39%), but this difference was not significant (<em>

7211P</em>

7212 = .10).</li>

7213</ul>

7214</div>

7215</li>

7216<li>

7217A retrospective, single-institution, nonrandomized trial compared patients who received GM-CSF and 3F8 anti-GD2 antibody therapy after either autologous SCT or conventional chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.46">

721846</a>

7219] The patients were a mixture of those referred for initial treatment or further therapy, and included patients with refractory and relapsed disease, some of whom had received autologous SCT at referring institutions. In the autologous SCT group, there was a significantly longer time from first chemotherapy or from autologous SCT to initiation of GM-CSF and 3F8 anti-GD2 antibody treatment. The autologous SCT group also had significantly more ultra&#8211;high-risk patients. <div class="pdq-content-list">

7220<ul id="_1198">

7221<li>

7222A trend for better EFS with GM-CSF and 3F8 anti-GD2 antibody therapy and autologous SCT was observed (65% vs. 51%, <em>

7223P</em>

7224 = .128), but there was no statistically significant difference in OS between patients who were treated with chemotherapy alone and those who were treated with autologous SCT.</li>

7225</ul>

7226</div>

7227</li>

7228<li>

7229In a COG phase III trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00026312">

7230ANBL0032 [NCT00026312]</a>

7231), participants who had previously undergone SCT were randomly assigned to receive dinutuximab administered with GM-CSF and IL-2 in conjunction with isotretinoin, versus isotretinoin alone.[<a href="#cit/section_8.44">

723244</a>

7233]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7234<ul id="_814">

7235<li>

7236 Immunotherapy together with isotretinoin (EFS rate, 66%) was superior to standard isotretinoin maintenance therapy (EFS rate, 46%). As a result, immunotherapy post-SCT is considered the standard of care in COG trials for high-risk disease.</li>

7237<li>

7238As a result of the COG studies, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved dinutuximab.</li>

7239<li>

7240Long-term follow-up (median follow-up time, 9.97 years; range, 0.7&#8211;15.3 years) was available for 226 eligible patients. The 5-year EFS rate was 56.6% (&#177; 4.7%) for patients randomly assigned to receive immunotherapy (n = 114) versus 46.1% (&#177; 5.1%) for those randomly assigned to receive isotretinoin only (n = 112) (<em>

7241P</em>

7242 = .042). The 5-year OS rate was 73.2% (&#177; 4.2%) for patients who received immunotherapy, versus 56.6% (&#177; 5.1%) for patients who received isotretinoin (<em>

7243P</em>

7244 = .045). Thirteen of 122 patients who received dinutuximab developed human anti-chimeric antibodies (HACA). Plasma levels of dinutuximab, HACA, and soluble IL-2 receptor-alpha did not correlate with EFS, OS, or clinically significant toxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_8.47">

724547</a>

7246][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7247Level of evidence B1</a>

7248]</li>

7249<li>

7250After randomization was stopped for ANBL0032, all patients were assigned to receive immunotherapy. With longer follow-up data available for 1,183 patients, survival and toxicity results were similar to previous reports. For patients older than 18 months at diagnosis with INSS stage 4 disease (n = 662), the 5-year EFS rate was 57%, and the OS rate was 70.9%. Toxicities were similar to those reported for the randomized cohort. Among patients with available data, higher dinutuximab levels and Fc gamma receptor 3A (FCGR3A) genotype were associated with superior EFS.[<a href="#cit/section_8.48">

725148</a>

7252]</li>

7253<li>

7254Anti-GD2 antibodies, along with modulation of the immune system to enhance the antibody's antineuroblastoma activity, are often used to help treat patients with neuroblastoma. The clinical effectiveness of one such antibody led to the FDA approval of dinutuximab. The patient's response to immunotherapy may be caused, in part, by variation in immune function among patients. One anti-GD2 antibody, termed 3F8, used for treating neuroblastoma exclusively at one institution, directs natural killer cells to kill the neuroblastoma cells. However, the natural killer cells can be inhibited by the interaction of HLA antigens and killer immunoglobulin receptor (KIR) subtypes.[<a href="#cit/section_8.49">

725549</a>

7256,<a href="#cit/section_8.50">

725750</a>

7258] This finding was confirmed and expanded by an analysis of outcomes for patients treated in the national randomized <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00026312">

7259COG-ANBL0032 (NCT00026312)</a>

7260 study with the anti-GD2 antibody dinutuximab combined with GM-CSF and IL-2. The study found that certain KIR/KIR-ligand genotypes were associated with better outcomes for patients who were treated with immunotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.51">

726151</a>

7262][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810019&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810019&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7263Level of evidence A2</a>

7264] The presence of inhibitory KIR/KIR ligands was associated with a decreased effect of immunotherapy. Thus, the patient's immune system genes help determine response to immunotherapy for neuroblastoma. Additional studies are needed to determine whether this immune system genotyping can guide patient selection for certain immunotherapies.</li>

7265</ul>

7266</div>

7267</li>

7268<li>

7269A European study compared dinutuximab-beta (dinutuximab manufactured in hamster cells instead of mouse cells) to dinutuximab-beta plus subcutaneous (SQ) IL-2 administered as maintenance therapy after high-dose chemotherapy with autologous SCT. All patients additionally received isotretinoin. [<a href="#cit/section_8.52">

727052</a>

7271]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7272<ul id="_1950">

7273<li>

7274The addition of SQ IL-2 did not improve outcome. The 3-year EFS rate was 56% for patients treated with dinutuximab-beta and 60% for patients treated with dinutuximab-beta and SQ IL-2 (<em>

7275P</em>

7276 = .76).</li>

7277<li>

7278There was also no difference in incidence of relapse/progression or 5-year OS. </li>

7279<li>

7280Patients treated with IL-2 had higher rates of fever, pain, allergic reaction, capillary leak syndrome, neurotoxicity, and gastrointestinal toxicity. In this study, only 62% of patients randomly assigned to the IL-2 arm received the planned therapy because of toxicity.</li>

7281</ul>

7282</div>

7283</li>

7284<li>

7285A second SIOPEN trial reported the following:[<a href="#cit/section_8.52">

728652</a>

7287] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7288<ul id="_2499">

7289<li>

7290Response rates and 2-year EFS and OS rates did not differ for patients treated with IL-2 versus no IL-2.</li>

7291<li>

7292 SIOPEN subsequently eliminated IL-2 from standard postconsolidation therapy.</li>

7293</ul>

7294</div>

7295</li>

7296<li>

7297A third randomized, phase II, SIOPEN trial compared treatment with IL-2 to treatment without IL-2.[<a href="#cit/section_8.53">

729853</a>

7299]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7300<ul id="_2500">

7301<li>

7302Response, EFS, and OS rates were not significantly different with IL-2 than without IL-2, but toxicity was higher in the IL-2 arm.</li>

7303</ul>

7304</div>

7305</li>

7306</ol>

7307</div>

7308<p id="_2078" tabindex="-1">

7309On the basis of the SIOPEN data, the COG removed IL-2 from standard postconsolidation immunotherapy.</p>

7310<p id="_2049" tabindex="-1">

7311Radioactive MIBG therapy has been used to treat recurrent neuroblastoma with some success. This therapy has been shown to be safe and feasible to incorporate into the treatment regimen for newly diagnosed children with high-risk neuroblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_8.54">

731254</a>

7313] A randomized trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03126916">

7314ANBL1531 [NCT03126916]</a>

7315) incorporating radioactive MIBG therapy into the complex therapy for newly diagnosed high-risk neuroblastoma is under way. </p>

7316<p id="_2026" tabindex="-1">

7317A multi-institution, phase II clinical trial of children with high-risk neuroblastoma explored maintenance therapy using difluoromethylornithine (DFMO), an ornithine decarboxylase inhibitor.[<a href="#cit/section_8.55">

731855</a>

7319] Although the study claimed that survival was improved compared with a subset of patients who were previously treated in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00026312">

7320ANBL0032 (NCT00026312)</a>

7321 trial, the historical comparison and potential patient selection bias limit the validity of this finding. In the absence of randomized data, the value of adding DFMO to the multidisciplinary treatment of children with neuroblastoma cannot be ascertained. Further studies of DFMO therapy for patients with neuroblastoma are planned, and some trials are under way.</p>

7322<p id="_2507" tabindex="-1">

7323A GD2/GD3 ganglioside vaccine is another approach that has been studied for patients in first remission after completion of standard therapy. In a randomized trial that mainly included patients in first remission, early introduction of beta-glucan along with a GD2/GD3 vaccine increased GD2/GD3 antibody titers without increasing toxicity. PFS rates were similar for patients in both randomized treatment arms. However, patients with higher titers had more favorable PFS rates, regardless of the treatment arm.[<a href="#cit/section_8.56">

732456</a>

7325][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7326Level of evidence B1</a>

7327]

7328</p>

7329</section>

7330</section>

7331<section id="_1817">

7332<h3 id="_1817_toc">

7333Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation</h3>

7334<p id="_1818" tabindex="-1">

7335Information about National Cancer Institute (NCI)&#8211;supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

7336NCI website</a>

7337. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

7338ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

7339.</p>

7340<p id="_1819" tabindex="-1">

7341The following is an example of a national and/or institutional clinical trial that is currently being conducted:</p>

7342<div class="pdq-content-list">

7343<ul id="_1820">

7344<li>

7345<strong>

7346<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03126916">

7347ANBL1531 (NCT03126916)</a>

7348</strong>

7349 (A Phase III Study of 131I-MIBG or ALK Inhibitor Therapy Added to Intensive Therapy for Children With Newly Diagnosed High-Risk Neuroblastoma)<strong>

7350:</strong>

7351 The standard current COG therapy consists of induction chemotherapy, consolidation with surgery and tandem SCT, and postconsolidation radiation therapy with isotretinoin and dinutuximab immune-enhanced immunotherapy. During the 4-week initial induction chemotherapy cycle, patients will be screened for the <em class="gene-name">

7352ALK</em>

7353 gene aberration (which occurs in approximately 10%&#8211;15% of high-risk patients). Before the second cycle of induction chemotherapy, the treatment arm assignment occurs. Most patients enrolled will be MIBG avid and lack the <em class="gene-name">

7354ALK</em>

7355 aberration, and will be randomly assigned to one of the following two treatment arms: <div class="pdq-content-list">

7356<ol id="_1876" class="lower-alpha">

7357<li>

7358Arm A consists of standard COG therapy, as described above.</li>

7359<li>

7360Arm B consists of standard COG therapy but with an MIBG cycle added after the third cycle of induction chemotherapy.</li>

7361</ol>

7362</div>

7363<p id="_1859" tabindex="-1">

7364Patients with the <em class="gene-name">

7365ALK</em>

7366 gene mutation or <em class="gene-name">

7367ALK</em>

7368 amplification will receive nonrandomized COG standard induction chemotherapy with the ALK inhibitor lorlatinib added, followed by further therapy on the standard COG treatment plan.</p>

7369<p id="_1860" tabindex="-1">

7370Patients with MIBG nonavid, <em class="gene-name">

7371ALK</em>

7372 nonaberrant tumors will receive standard current chemotherapy as in arm A above.</p>

7373<p id="_1954" tabindex="-1">

7374The classification for the ANBL1531 trial is based on the INRG staging system.</p>

7375<p id="_1955" tabindex="-1">

7376Boost radiation was discontinued in this trial because no clear benefit over historical controls was apparent.</p>

7377</li>

7378</ul>

7379</div>

7380<section id="_TrialSearch_1817_sid_8">

7381<h4 id="_TrialSearch_1817_sid_8_toc">

7382Current Clinical Trials</h4>

7383<p id="_TrialSearch_1817_22" tabindex="-1">

7384Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

7385advanced clinical trial search</a>

7386 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

7387General information</a>

7388 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

7389</section>

7390</section>
