Pediatr Transplant 20 (2): 284-9, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26614402&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26614402&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7496[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7497</li>

7498<li id="section_8.27">

7499Ladenstein R, P&#246;tschger U, Pearson ADJ, et al.: Busulfan and melphalan versus carboplatin, etoposide, and melphalan as high-dose chemotherapy for high-risk neuroblastoma (HR-NBL1/SIOPEN): an international, randomised, multi-arm, open-label, phase 3 trial. 7500[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7501</li>

7620

7621 </section>

7622

7623

7624

7625 <section id="_772">

7626

7627 <h2>

7628Treatment of INSS Stage 4S and INRG Stage MS Neuroblastoma</h2>

7629

7630 <div id="_section_772" class="pdq-sections">

7631<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

7632<h6>

7633In This Section</h6>

7634<ul>

7635<li>

7636<a href="#_937_toc">

7637Treatment Options for Stage 4S/MS Neuroblastoma<ul>

7638<li>

7639<a href="#_775_toc">

7640Observation with supportive care</a>

7641</li>

7642<li>

7643<a href="#_777_toc">

7644Chemotherapy</a>

7645</li>

7646<li>

7647<a href="#_1852_toc">

7648Radiation therapy (for patients with symptoms related to hepatomegaly from metastatic disease)</a>

7649</li>

7650</ul>

7651</a>

7652</li>

7653<li>

7654<a href="#_1041_toc">

7655Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation<ul>

7656<li>

7657<a href="#_TrialSearch_1041_sid_8_toc">

7658Current Clinical Trials</a>

7659</li>

7660</ul>

7661</a>

7662</li>

7663</ul>

7664</nav>

7665<p id="_1862" tabindex="-1">

7666International Neuroblastoma Staging System (INSS) stage 4S patients are younger than 12 months and have an INSS stage 1 or stage 2 primary tumor. International Neuroblastoma Risk Group (INRG) stage MS patients are younger than 18 months with any stage of primary tumor. Both staging systems have the same definition of limited pattern of metastases.</p>

7667<p id="_1896" tabindex="-1">

7668The decision by the INRG Task Force to replace the category of 4S disease with that of the new MS definition was based on reports in which small numbers of infants with L2 primary tumors and 4S metastatic patterns, including patients aged 12 to 18 months, had favorable outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_9.1">

76691</a>

7670,<a href="#cit/section_9.2">

76712</a>

7672] A subsequent study of the actual INRG data found that a number of biological characteristics predicted poor outcome of patients aged 12 to 18 months with stage MS disease, and that only those infants with favorable biology had long-term outcomes similar to those with the traditional 4S diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_9.2">

76732</a>

7674]</p>

7675<p id="_2431" tabindex="-1">

7676Infants with INRG stage MS disease have more favorable biology and superior outcomes despite receiving less aggressive therapy. The 5-year event-free survival (EFS) rate was 86%, and the overall survival (OS) rate was 95%. For patients with <em class="gene-name">

7677MYCN</em>

7678-amplified tumors, the 5-year EFS rate was 60%, and the OS rate was 65%.[<a href="#cit/section_9.3">

76793</a>

7680]</p>

7681<p id="_855" tabindex="-1">

7682Many patients with stage 4S/MS neuroblastoma do not require therapy. However, tumors with unfavorable biology or patients who are symptomatic because of evolving hepatomegaly and organ compromise are at increased risk of death and are treated with low-dose to moderate-dose chemotherapy. Eight percent to 10% of these patients will have <em class="gene-name">

7683MYCN</em>

7684 amplification and are treated with high-risk treatment regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_9.4">

76854</a>

7686]</p>

7687<p id="_1171" tabindex="-1">

7688For more information about the Children's Oncology Group (COG) classification schema for stage 4S/MS neuroblastoma, see <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_2398">

7689Table 5</a>

7690.</p>

7691<section id="_937">

7692<h3 id="_937_toc">

7693Treatment Options for Stage 4S/MS Neuroblastoma</h3>

7694<p id="_938" tabindex="-1">

7695There is no standard approach for the treatment of stage 4S/MS neuroblastoma. </p>

7696<p id="_939" tabindex="-1">

7697Treatment options for stage 4S/MS neuroblastoma include the following:</p>

7698<div class="pdq-content-list">

7699<ol id="_774">

7700<li>

7701<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_775">

7702Observation with supportive care</a>

7703 (for asymptomatic patients with favorable tumor biology).</li>

7704<li>

7705<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_777">

7706Chemotherapy</a>

7707 (for symptomatic patients or patients with unfavorable biology).</li>

7708<li>

7709<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1852">

7710Radiation therapy</a>

7711 (rarely for patients with symptoms related to hepatomegaly from metastatic disease).</li>

7712</ol>

7713</div>

7714<p id="_940" tabindex="-1">

7715Resection of the primary tumor is not associated with improved outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_9.5">

77165</a>

7717-<a href="#cit/section_9.7">

77187</a>

7719] Rarely, infants with massive hepatic 4S/MS neuroblastoma develop cirrhosis from the chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy that is used to control the disease and may benefit from orthotopic liver transplant.[<a href="#cit/section_9.8">

77208</a>

7721]</p>

7722<section id="_775">

7723<h4 id="_775_toc">

7724Observation with supportive care</h4>

7725<p id="_1189" tabindex="-1">

7726Observation with supportive care is used to treat asymptomatic patients with favorable tumor biology.</p>

7727<p id="_776" tabindex="-1">

7728The treatment of children with stage 4S/MS disease depends on clinical presentation.[<a href="#cit/section_9.5">

77295</a>

7730,<a href="#cit/section_9.6">

77316</a>

7732] Most patients do not require therapy unless bulky disease causes organ compromise and risk of death. </p>

7733</section>

7734<section id="_777">

7735<h4 id="_777_toc">

7736Chemotherapy</h4>

7737<p id="_1190" tabindex="-1">

7738Chemotherapy is used to treat symptomatic patients or patients with unfavorable biology. Patients with evidence of rapid tumor growth in the first several weeks of life require immediate intervention with chemotherapy to avoid potentially irreversible abdominal compartment syndrome and hepatic and/or renal failure.[<a href="#cit/section_9.9">

77399</a>

7740]</p>

7741<p id="_778" tabindex="-1">

7742Infants diagnosed with INSS stage 4S/MS neuroblastoma, particularly those with hepatomegaly or those younger than 2 months with high-risk features or hepatomegaly, have the potential for rapid clinical deterioration and may benefit from early initiation of therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.9">

77439</a>

7744] It has been difficult to identify infants with stage 4S disease who will benefit from chemotherapy.</p>

7745<p id="_1889" tabindex="-1">

7746A scoring system to measure signs and symptoms of deterioration or compromise was developed to better assess this group of stage 4S patients.[<a href="#cit/section_9.10">

774710</a>

7748] This scoring system has been evaluated retrospectively, was predictive of the clinical course, and has been applied prospectively to guide the management of patients with INSS stage 4S disease.[<a href="#cit/section_9.10">

774910</a>

7750,<a href="#cit/section_9.11">

775111</a>

7752] The scoring system has been modified on the basis of the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00499616">

7753ANBL0531 (NCT00499616)</a>

7754 study results in the youngest infants discussed above to guide chemotherapeutic intervention for 4S/MS in infants.[<a href="#cit/section_9.9">

77559</a>

7756]</p>

7757<p id="_857" tabindex="-1">

7758Various chemotherapy regimens (cyclophosphamide alone, carboplatin/etoposide, cyclophosphamide/doxorubicin/vincristine) have been used to treat symptomatic patients. The approach is to administer the chemotherapy only as long as symptoms persist to avoid toxicity, which contributes to poorer survival. Additionally, lower doses of chemotherapy are often recommended for very young or low-weight infants, along with granulocyte colony-stimulating factors after each cycle of chemotherapy.</p>

7759<p id="_858" tabindex="-1">

7760Evidence (chemotherapy for 4S/MS disease):</p>

7761<div class="pdq-content-list">

7762<ol id="_859">

7763<li>

7764The COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00499616">

7765ANBL0531 (NCT00499616)</a>

7766 trial prospectively studied a subset of 4S patients who had <em class="gene-name">

7767MYCN</em>

7768-nonamplified tumors with impaired or impending organ dysfunction or unfavorable biology (unfavorable histology and/or diploid DNA index). Forty-nine patients were enrolled, 41 of whom were symptomatic and 28 of whom had unfavorable biology. Patients were assigned to receive two, four, or eight cycles of chemotherapy on the basis of the tumor biology, age of the patient, and symptoms.[<a href="#cit/section_9.9">

77699</a>

7770][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7771Level of evidence C1</a>

7772]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7773<ul id="_1887">

7774<li>

7775The 3-year OS rate was 81.4%. </li>

7776<li>

7777Eight of the nine deaths occurred in patients younger than 2 months at diagnosis. Five deaths were related to acute complications of rapidly progressing hepatomegaly (i.e., abdominal compartment syndrome, renal failure, respiratory failure, coagulopathy, and infection). Patients younger than 40 days at diagnosis had more than 13 times the risk of dying compared with patients older than 47 days. The study was amended after the five deaths to mandate immediate chemotherapy for patients with 4S disease younger than 2 months at diagnosis with evolving hepatomegaly. No deaths related to complications of hepatomegaly occurred in the subsequent infants enrolled, including 18 infants who were younger than 2 months.<p id="_1928" tabindex="-1">

7778Emergent surgical abdominal decompression can be used to avoid respiratory deterioration and improve ventilation.[<a href="#cit/section_9.12">

777912</a>

7780,<a href="#cit/section_9.13">

778113</a>

7782]</p>

7783</li>

7784<li>

7785This study confirmed the inferior outcome of patients with unfavorable biology (DI = 1, segmental chromosome aberrations [1p and/or 11p loss of heterozygosity, unfavorable histology] without <em class="gene-name">

7786MYCN</em>

7787 amplification) compared with symptomatic patients with favorable biology. </li>

7788<li>

7789Both of the patients with late death died of metastatic disease and had unfavorable biology. </li>

7790</ul>

7791</div>

7792</li>

7793<li>

7794Eighty stage 4S patients were enrolled on the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003119">

7795COG-P9641</a>

7796 trial. Forty-one patients with asymptomatic stage 4S neuroblastoma were treated with surgery or biopsy alone, and 39 patients were treated with surgery and chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.14">

779714</a>

7798]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7799<ul id="_860">

7800<li>

7801Overall, the 5-year EFS rate was 77%, and the OS rate was 91%.</li>

7802<li>

7803The 5-year EFS rate was 63% for patients treated with surgery or biopsy alone and 95% for patients treated with surgery and chemotherapy (<em>

7804P</em>

7805 = .0016).</li>

7806<li>

7807The 5-year OS rate was 84% for patients treated with surgery or biopsy alone and 97% for patients treated with surgery and chemotherapy (<em>

7808P</em>

7809 = .1302).<p id="_1942" tabindex="-1">

7810Previously, chemotherapy toxicity was thought to be responsible for the poorer survival of patients with stage 4S disease; however, the use of chemotherapy on the COG-P9641 trial was restricted to specific clinical situations with a recommended number of cycles.</p>

7811</li>

7812</ul>

7813</div>

7814</li>

7815<li>

7816Also, on the COG-P9641 trial, asymptomatic infants with biologically favorable (<em class="gene-name">

7817MYCN</em>

7818-nonamplified) INSS stage 4S disease did not receive chemotherapy until the development of progressive disease or clinical symptoms.[<a href="#cit/section_9.14">

781914</a>

7820]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7821<ul id="_861">

7822<li>

7823Infants who became symptomatic had disease-related organ failure and infectious complications resulting in an inferior OS compared with those who received immediate chemotherapy (4&#8211;8 cycles of therapy). The 3-year OS rate for infants who did not receive chemotherapy was 84% versus 97% for infants who received chemotherapy (<em>

7824P</em>

7825 = .1321). </li>

7826</ul>

7827</div>

7828</li>

7829<li>

7830For the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00499616">

7831COG-ANBL0531</a>

7832 trial, treatment was allocated on the basis of symptoms, age, and tumor biology.[<a href="#cit/section_9.9">

78339</a>

7834]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7835<ul id="_2502">

7836<li>

7837The 2-year OS rate for INSS stage 4S patients was 81%, which is lower than that reported in other cooperative trials such as COG-P9641.</li>

7838<li>

7839 Many patients enrolled in the ANBL0531 study were more ill than patients entered in previous trials, in part because tumor biopsy was not required in symptomatic infants. Previous trials mainly included asymptomatic patients, most with favorable tumor biology. </li>

7840</ul>

7841</div>

7842</li>

7843<li>

7844A prospective study was performed in 125 infants with stage 4S <em class="gene-name">

7845MYCN</em>

7846-nonamplified tumors or INSS stage 3 primary tumors and/or positive bone scintigraphy not associated with changes in the cortical bone documented on plain radiographs and/or computed tomography.[<a href="#cit/section_9.11">

784711</a>

7848] A pretreatment symptom score was used to determine initial treatment. Observation was recommended for infants with low symptom scores (n = 86), and chemotherapy was recommended for infants with high symptom scores (n = 37). <p id="_1929" tabindex="-1">

7849The chemotherapy for patients with high symptom scores included two to four 3-day courses of carboplatin and etoposide. If symptoms persisted or progressive disease developed, up to four 5-day courses of cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, and vincristine were administered. One-half of the patients underwent complete or partial resection of the primary tumor.</p>

7850<div class="pdq-content-list">

7851<ul id="_862">

7852<li>

7853There was no difference in the 2-year EFS and OS between asymptomatic and symptomatic patients (EFS rate, 87% vs. 88%; OS rate, 98% vs. 97%), although many of the investigators preferred to give chemotherapy in the presence of a low symptom score.</li>

7854<li>

7855For infants with low symptom scores, there was no difference in the outcome between the initially untreated infants (n = 56; OS rate, 93%) and treated infants (n = 30; OS rate, 86%). </li>

7856<li>

7857The OS rate was 90% for infants presenting with high symptom scores.</li>

7858<li>

7859There was no significant difference in 2-year OS rates between patients with unresectable primary tumors and patients with resectable primary tumors (97% vs. 100%) and between patients with negative and positive skeletal scintigraphy without radiological abnormalities (100% vs. 97%).</li>

7860</ul>

7861</div>

7862</li>

7863</ol>

7864</div>

7865</section>

7866<section id="_1852">

7867<h4 id="_1852_toc">

7868Radiation therapy (for patients with symptoms related to hepatomegaly from metastatic disease)</h4>

7869<p id="_1892" tabindex="-1">

7870In rare cases of marked hepatomegaly in symptomatic MS (4S) infants with neuroblastoma who were unresponsive to chemotherapy, very low-dose radiation therapy has been used. In a series of 41 symptomatic infants with MS disease, radiation therapy was administered to five infants, three of whom died.[<a href="#cit/section_9.9">

78719</a>

7872]</p>

7873</section>

7874</section>

7875<section id="_1041">

7876<h3 id="_1041_toc">

7877Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation</h3>

7878<p id="_1042" tabindex="-1">

7879Information about National Cancer Institute (NCI)&#8211;supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

7880NCI website</a>

7881. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

7882ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

7883.</p>

7884<section id="_TrialSearch_1041_sid_8">

7885<h4 id="_TrialSearch_1041_sid_8_toc">

7886Current Clinical Trials</h4>

7887<p id="_TrialSearch_1041_22" tabindex="-1">

7888Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

7889advanced clinical trial search</a>

7890 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

7891General information</a>

7892 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

7893</section>

7894</section>

7948[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7949</li>

7950<li id="section_9.14">

7951Strother DR, London WB, Schmidt ML, et al.: Outcome after surgery alone or with restricted use of chemotherapy for patients with low-risk neuroblastoma: results of Children's Oncology Group study P9641. J Clin Oncol 30 (15): 1842-8, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22529259&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22529259&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7952[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7953</li>

7954</ol>

7955</div>

7956

7957 </section>

7958

7959

7960

7961 <section id="_706">

7962

7963 <h2>

7964Treatment of Recurrent Neuroblastoma</h2>

7965

7966 <div id="_section_706" class="pdq-sections">

7967<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

7968<h6>

7969In This Section</h6>

7970<ul>

7971<li>

7972<a href="#_796_toc">

7973Prognostic Factors for Recurrent Neuroblastoma</a>

7974</li>

7975<li>

7976<a href="#_121_toc">

7977Recurrent Neuroblastoma in Patients Initially Classified as Low Risk<ul>

7978<li>

7979<a href="#_171_toc">

7980Locoregional recurrence</a>

7981</li>

7982<li>

7983<a href="#_172_toc">

7984Metastatic recurrence or disease refractory to standard treatment</a>

7985</li>

7986</ul>

7987</a>

7988</li>

7989<li>

7990<a href="#_133_toc">

7991Recurrent Neuroblastoma in Patients Initially Classified as Intermediate Risk<ul>

7992<li>

7993<a href="#_173_toc">

7994Locoregional recurrence</a>

7995</li>

7996<li>

7997<a href="#_174_toc">

7998Metastatic recurrence</a>

7999</li>

8000</ul>

8001</a>

8002</li>

8003<li>

8004<a href="#_138_toc">

8005Recurrent Neuroblastoma in Patients Initially Classified as High Risk</a>

8006</li>

8007<li>

8008<a href="#_703_toc">

8009Recurrent Neuroblastoma in the Central Nervous System</a>

8010</li>

8011<li>

8012<a href="#_811_toc">

8013Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation for Recurrent or Refractory Neuroblastoma<ul>

8014<li>

8015<a href="#_TrialSearch_811_sid_11_toc">

8016Current Clinical Trials</a>

8017</li>

8018</ul>

8019</a>

8020</li>

8021</ul>

8022</nav>

8023<p id="_795" tabindex="-1">

8024Tumor growth resulting from maturation should be differentiated from tumor progression by performing a biopsy and reviewing histology. Patients may have persistent maturing disease with metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) uptake that does not affect outcome, particularly patients with low-risk and intermediate-risk disease.[<a href="#cit/section_10.1">

80251</a>

8026] An analysis of 23 paired MIBG and positron emission tomography (PET) scans in 14 patients with refractory or recurrent high-risk neuroblastoma treated with iodine I 131-MIBG (131I-MIBG) found that the MIBG scan was more sensitive than fluorine F 18-fludeoxyglucose (18F-FDG) PET for detecting metastatic bone lesions, although there was a trend for 18F-FDG PET to be more sensitive for soft tissue lesions.[<a href="#cit/section_10.2">

80272</a>

8028] </p>

8029<p id="_1167" tabindex="-1">

8030Subclonal <em class="gene-name">

8031ALK</em>

8032 mutations or other MAPK pathway lesions may be present at diagnosis, with subsequent clonal expansion at relapse. Consequently, serial sampling of progressive tumors may lead to the identification of potentially actionable mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_10.3">

80333</a>

8034,<a href="#cit/section_10.4">

80354</a>

8036] Modern comprehensive molecular analysis comparing primary and relapsed neuroblastoma from the same patients revealed extensive clonal enrichment and several newly discovered mutations, with many tumors showing new or clonal-enriched mutations in the RAS-MAPK pathway. This was true for patients with both high-risk and low-risk tumors at diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_10.5">

80375</a>

8038,<a href="#cit/section_10.6">

80396</a>

8040] For more information, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1937">

8041Genomic and Biological Features of Neuroblastoma</a>

8042 section.</p>

8043<p id="_2521" tabindex="-1">

8044Sequencing of recurrent and refractory neuroblastoma tumors from pediatric (n = 59) and young adult patients (n = 1) enrolled in the NCI-COG Pediatric MATCH trial revealed genomic alterations that were considered actionable for treatment in MATCH study arms in 27 of 60 tumors (45%).[<a href="#cit/section_10.7">

80457</a>

8046] Hotspot mutations in <em class="gene-name">

8047ALK</em>

8048 were most frequent, reported in 19 of 60 tumors (31.7%). MAPK pathway mutations (<em class="gene-name">

8049NF1</em>

8050, <em class="gene-name">

8051NRAS</em>

8052) were detected in 4 of 60 tumors (6.7%), and <em class="gene-name">

8053FGFR1</em>

8054 mutations were detected in 3 of 60 tumors (5%). </p>

8055<p id="_1093" tabindex="-1">

8056If neuroblastoma recurs in a child originally diagnosed with high-risk disease, the prognosis is usually poor despite additional intensive therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.8">

80578</a>

8058-<a href="#cit/section_10.11">

805911</a>

8060] However, it is often possible to gain many additional months of life for these patients with alternative chemotherapy regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_10.12">

806112</a>

8062,<a href="#cit/section_10.13">

806313</a>

8064] Clinical trials are appropriate for these patients and may be offered. Information about ongoing clinical trials is available from the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials">

8065NCI website</a>

8066.</p>

8067<section id="_796">

8068<h3 id="_796_toc">

8069Prognostic Factors for Recurrent Neuroblastoma</h3>

8070<p id="_2432" tabindex="-1">

8071A comprehensive analysis of the patterns of relapse was conducted using the International Neuroblastoma Risk Group (INRG) database on patients diagnosed/enrolled between 1989 and 2017.[<a href="#cit/section_10.14">

807214</a>

8073][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8074Level of evidence C1</a>

8075]</p>

8076<div class="pdq-content-list">

8077<ul id="_2433">

8078<li>

8079For 1,833 children, the pattern of first relapse included isolated local (19%), distant only (65%), and combined sites (16%).</li>

8080<li>

8081Patients with isolated local failure had more favorable prognostic features.</li>

8082<li>

8083Patients with stage 3 disease were more likely to have isolated local failure than patients with all other stages (49% vs. 16%, <em>

8084P</em>

8085 &lt; .001).</li>

8086<li>

8087The 5-year overall survival (OS) rates significantly differed by relapse pattern, with a rate of 64% for isolated local, 23% for distant only, and 26% for combined sites (<em>

8088P</em>

8089 &lt; .001).</li>

8090<li>

8091After controlling for age, stage, and <em class="gene-name">

8092MYCN</em>

8093 status, patients with isolated local failure (adjusted hazard ratio [HR], 0.46; <em>

8094P</em>

8095 &lt; .001) and distant-only failure (adjusted HR, 0.57; <em>

8096P</em>

8097 &lt; .001) remained at decreased risk for death, compared with patients with combined failure.</li>

8098</ul>

8099</div>

8100<p id="_2435" tabindex="-1">

8101The INRG database was used to examine clinical and biological features that are prognostic of survival after relapse or progression of INRG Staging System (INRGSS) stage MS pattern neuroblastoma. Of the 1,511 patients diagnosed between 1984 and 2021 who met the eligibility criteria, 209 patients were identified as having an event. Eligibility criteria included patients younger than 365 days at initial diagnosis with INRGSS stage MS disease or with INSS stage 4S, or patients aged 365 to 546 days with INSS stage 4 disease and metastasis limited to the liver, skin, and/or bone marrow.[<a href="#cit/section_10.15">

810215</a>

8103][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8104Level of evidence C1</a>

8105]</p>

8106<div class="pdq-content-list">

8107<ul id="_2440">

8108<li>

8109In this group, the median time to first event was 8.16 months.</li>

8110<li>

8111Most relapses had a component of metastatic failure. These metastases more commonly occurred at sites outside of the liver, skin, and bone marrow.</li>

8112<li>

8113The 5-year OS rate was 62% for patients treated in 2001 and later.</li>

8114</ul>

8115</div>

8116<p id="_797" tabindex="-1">

8117The International Neuroblastoma Risk Group Project performed a survival-tree analysis of clinical and biological characteristics (defined at diagnosis) associated with survival after relapse in 2,266 patients with neuroblastoma entered in large clinical trials in well-established clinical trials groups around the world.[<a href="#cit/section_10.8">

81188</a>

8119] The survival-tree analysis revealed the following:</p>

8120<div class="pdq-content-list">

8121<ul id="_914">

8122<li>

8123The OS rate was 20% in the entire relapsed population.</li>

8124<li>

8125Among patients with all stages of disease at diagnosis, <em class="gene-name">

8126MYCN</em>

8127 amplification predicted a poorer prognosis, measured as 5-year OS. </li>

8128<li>

8129Among patients diagnosed with International Neuroblastoma Staging System (INSS) stage 4 without amplification, age older than 18 months and high lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level predicted poor prognosis.</li>

8130<li>

8131Among patients with <em class="gene-name">

8132MYCN</em>

8133 amplification, those diagnosed with stage 1 and stage 2 disease had a better prognosis than those diagnosed with stage 3 and stage 4 disease.</li>

8134<li>

8135Among patients with <em class="gene-name">

8136MYCN</em>

8137-nonamplified tumors who were not stage 4, patients with hyperdiploidy had a better prognosis than patients with diploidy in those younger than 18 months. Among those older than 18 months, patients with differentiating tumors fared much better than patients with undifferentiated and poorly differentiated tumors.</li>

8138</ul>

8139</div>

8140<p id="_798" tabindex="-1">

8141Significant prognostic factors determined at diagnosis for postrelapse survival include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_10.8">

81428</a>

8143]</p>

8144<div class="pdq-content-list">

8145<ul id="_799">

8146<li>

8147Age.</li>

8148<li>

8149INSS stage.</li>

8150<li>

8151<em class="gene-name">

8152MYCN</em>

8153 status.</li>

8154<li>

8155Time from diagnosis to first relapse.</li>

8156<li>

8157LDH level, ploidy, and histological grade of tumor differentiation (to a lesser extent).</li>

8158</ul>

8159</div>

8160<p id="_800" tabindex="-1">

8161The Children&#8217;s Oncology Group (COG) experience with recurrence in patients with low-risk and intermediate-risk neuroblastoma showed that most patients can be salvaged. The COG reported a 3-year event free survival (EFS) rate of 88% and an OS rate of 96% in intermediate-risk patients and a 5-year EFS rate of 89% and OS rate of 97% in low-risk patients.[<a href="#cit/section_10.16">

816216</a>

8163,<a href="#cit/section_10.17">

816417</a>

8165] Moreover, in most patients originally diagnosed with low-risk or intermediate-risk disease, local recurrence or recurrence in the 4S pattern may be treated successfully with observation alone, surgery alone, or with moderate-dose chemotherapy, without myeloablative therapy and stem cell transplant.</p>

8166<p id="_1930" tabindex="-1">

8167The OS after recurrence in children presenting with high-risk neuroblastoma is generally extremely poor. However, such patients at first relapse after complete remission or minimal residual disease (MRD) in whom relapse was a single site of soft tissue mass (a few children also had bone marrow or bone disease at relapse) had a 5-year OS rate of 35% in one single-institution study. All patients underwent surgical resection of the soft tissue disease. <em class="gene-name">

8168MYCN</em>

8169 amplification and multifocal soft tissue disease were associated with a worse postprogression survival.[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

817018</a>

8171] Older

8172children with local recurrence, with either unfavorable International Neuroblastoma Pathology Classification at diagnosis or

8173<em class="gene-name">

8174MYCN</em>

8175 gene amplification, have a poor prognosis and may be treated with surgery or aggressive combination chemotherapy, or they may be offered entry into a clinical trial.</p>

8176<p id="_2417" tabindex="-1">

8177<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_2405">

8178Table 7</a>

8179 summarizes the treatment options for recurrent neuroblastoma by INSS-based risk group.</p>

8180<table id="_2405" class="table-default expandable-container">

8181<caption>

8182Table 7. Treatment Options for Recurrent Neuroblastoma</caption>

8183<colgroup>

8184<col width="50.00%">

8185<col width="50.00%">

8186</colgroup>

8187<THead>

8188<tr>

8189<th>

8190COG Risk-Group Assignment </th>

8191<th>

8192Treatment Options </th>

8193</tr>

8194</THead>

8195<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

8196<tr>

8197<td colspan="2">

8198COG = Children's Oncology Group; 131I-MIBG = iodine I 131-metaiodobenzylguanidine.</td>

8199</tr>

8200</TFoot>

8201<tbody>

8202<tr>

8203<td rowspan="2">

8204Locoregional recurrence in patients initially classified as low risk</td>

8205<td>

8207Surgery followed by observation or chemotherapy</a>

8208.</td>

8209</tr>

8210<tr>

8211<td>

8212<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_694">

8213Chemotherapy that may be followed by surgery</a>

8214.</td>

8215</tr>

8216<tr>

8217<td rowspan="3">

8218Metastatic recurrence in patients initially classified as low risk</td>

8219<td>

8220<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_696">

8221Observation</a>

8222 (if metastatic disease is in a 4S pattern in an infant).</td>

8223</tr>

8224<tr>

8227Chemotherapy</a>

8228.</td>

8229</tr>

8230<tr>

8231<td>

8232<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_696">

8233Surgery followed by chemotherapy</a>

8234.</td>

8235</tr>

8236<tr>

8237<td rowspan="3">

8238Locoregional recurrence in patients initially classified as intermediate risk</td>

8239<td>

8240<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_699">

8241Surgery</a>

8242 (complete resection).</td>

8243</tr>

8244<tr>

8245<td>

8246<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_699">

8247Surgery (incomplete resection) followed by chemotherapy</a>

8248. </td>

8249</tr>

8250<tr>

8251<td>

8252<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_728">

8253Radiation therapy</a>

8254 (only for patients with disease progression after chemotherapy and second-look surgery).</td>

8255</tr>

8256<tr>

8257<td>

8258Metastatic recurrence in patients initially classified as intermediate risk</td>

8259<td>

8260<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_701">

8261High-risk therapy</a>

8262.</td>

8263</tr>

8264<tr>

8265<td rowspan="5">

8266Recurrence in patients initially classified as high risk</td>

8267<td>

8268 <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_710">

8269Chemotherapy combined with immunotherapy</a>

8270.</td>

8271</tr>

8272<tr>

8273<td>

8274<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_710">

8275131I-MIBG alone, in combination with other therapy, or followed by stem cell rescue</a>

8276.</td>

8277</tr>

8278<tr>

8279<td>

8280<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_710">

8281Novel therapies, including ALK inhibitors for those patients with <em class="gene-name">

8282ALK</em>

8283 mutations</a>

8284.</td>

8285</tr>

8286<tr>

8287<td>

8288<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_710">

8289Chemotherapy</a>

8290.</td>

8291</tr>

8292<tr>

8293<td>

8294<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_710">

8295Immunotherapy</a>

8296.</td>

8297</tr>

8298<tr>

8299<td rowspan="3">

8300Recurrence in the central nervous system</td>

8301<td>

8302<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1008">

8303Surgery and radiation therapy</a>

8304.</td>

8305</tr>

8306<tr>

8307<td>

8309Chemotherapy in combination with surgery and radiation therapy</a>

8310.</td>

8311</tr>

8312<tr>

8313<td>

8316.</td>

8317</tr>

8318</tbody>

8319</table>

8320</section>

8321<section id="_121">

8322<h3 id="_121_toc">

8323Recurrent Neuroblastoma in Patients Initially Classified as Low Risk</h3>

8324<section id="_171">

8325<h4 id="_171_toc">

8326Locoregional recurrence</h4>

8327<p id="_694" tabindex="-1">

8328Treatment options for locoregional recurrent neuroblastoma initially classified as low risk include the following:</p>

8329<div class="pdq-content-list">

8330<ol id="_726">

8331<li>

8332Surgery followed by observation or chemotherapy.</li>

8333<li>

8334Chemotherapy that may be followed by surgery.</li>

8335</ol>

8336</div>

8337<p id="_916" tabindex="-1">

8338Local or regional recurrent cancer is resected if possible.</p>

8339<p id="_917" tabindex="-1">

8340Patients with favorable biology and regional recurrence more than 3 months after completion of planned treatment are observed if resection of the recurrence is total or near

8341total (&#8805;90% resection). Those with favorable biology and a less-than-near-total

8342resection are treated with chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.16">

834316</a>

8344,<a href="#cit/section_10.17">

834517</a>

8346,<a href="#cit/section_10.19">

834719</a>

8348]</p>

8349<p id="_918" tabindex="-1">

8350Infants younger than 1 year at the time of locoregional recurrence

8351whose tumors have any unfavorable biological properties are observed if

8352resection is total or near total. If the resection is less than near total,

8353these infants are treated with chemotherapy.

8354Chemotherapy may consist of moderate doses of carboplatin, cyclophosphamide,

8355doxorubicin, and etoposide, or cyclophosphamide and topotecan. The cumulative dose of each agent is kept low to minimize long-term effects, as used in previous COG trials (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003119">

8356COG-P9641</a>

8357 and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003093">

8358COG-A3961</a>

8359).[<a href="#cit/section_10.16">

836016</a>

8361,<a href="#cit/section_10.17">

836217</a>

8363,<a href="#cit/section_10.19">

836419</a>

8365] </p>

8366<p id="_801" tabindex="-1">

8367Evidence (surgery followed by observation or chemotherapy):</p>

8368<div class="pdq-content-list">

8369<ol id="_802">

8370<li>

8371A COG study of low-risk patients with stages 1, 2A, 2B, and 4S neuroblastoma enrolled 915 patients, 800 of whom were asymptomatic and treated with surgery alone followed by observation. The other patients received chemotherapy with or without surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_10.17">

837217</a>

8373] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8374<ul id="_803">

8375<li>

8376About 10% of patients developed progressive or recurrent tumors. </li>

8377<li>

8378Most recurrences were treated during the study with surgery alone or moderate chemotherapy with or without surgery. </li>

8379<li>

8380Most patients' disease was salvaged, as demonstrated by the EFS (89%) and OS (97%) rates at 5 years.</li>

8381</ul>

8382</div>

8383</li>

8384</ol>

8385</div>

8386</section>

8387<section id="_172">

8388<h4 id="_172_toc">

8389Metastatic recurrence or disease refractory to standard treatment</h4>

8390<p id="_696" tabindex="-1">

8391Treatment options for metastatic recurrent neuroblastoma initially classified as low risk include the following:</p>

8392<div class="pdq-content-list">

8393<ol id="_727">

8394<li>

8395Observation.</li>

8396<li>

8397Chemotherapy (based on age of patient, tumor biology, and prior treatment; treatment may include intermediate-risk or high-risk therapies, as used at initial diagnosis).</li>

8398<li>

8399Surgery followed by chemotherapy.</li>

8400</ol>

8401</div>

8402<p id="_127" tabindex="-1">

8403Metastatic recurrent or progressive neuroblastoma in an infant initially

8404categorized as low risk and younger than 1 year at recurrence may be

8405treated according to tumor biology, as defined in the previous COG trials (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003119">

8406COG-P9641</a>

8407 and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003093">

8408COG-A3961</a>

8409):

8410</p>

8411<div class="pdq-content-list">

8412<ol id="_182">

8413<li>

8414If the biology is completely favorable, metastasis is in a 4S pattern,

8415and the recurrence or progression is within 3 months of diagnosis, the patient

8416is observed symptomatically.

8417</li>

8418<li>

8419 If the metastatic progression or recurrence occurs more than 3 months after diagnosis or not in a 4S pattern,

8420then the primary tumor is resected, if possible, and chemotherapy is given.

8421<p id="_920" tabindex="-1">

8422Chemotherapy may consist of moderate doses of carboplatin, cyclophosphamide,

8423doxorubicin, and etoposide. The cumulative dose of each agent is kept low to minimize long-term effects, as used in previous COG trials (COG-P9641 and COG-A3961).

8424</p>

8425</li>

8426</ol>

8427</div>

8428<p id="_132" tabindex="-1">

8429Any child initially categorized as low risk who is older than 18 months at the

8430time of metastatic recurrent or progressive disease and whose recurrence is not in the stage 4S pattern usually has a poor

8431prognosis and is treated as follows:</p>

8432<div class="pdq-content-list">

8433<ol id="_698">

8434<li>

8435High-risk therapy. </li>

8436</ol>

8437</div>

8438<p id="_1140" tabindex="-1">

8439Patients with metastatic recurrent neuroblastoma are treated like patients with newly diagnosed high-risk neuroblastoma. For more information, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_707">

8440Treatment Options for High-Risk Neuroblastoma</a>

8441 section.</p>

8442</section>

8443</section>

8444<section id="_133">

8445<h3 id="_133_toc">

8446Recurrent Neuroblastoma in Patients Initially Classified as Intermediate Risk</h3>

8447<p id="_2023" tabindex="-1">

8448The COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00499616">

8449ANBL0531 (NCT00499616)</a>

8450 study treated patients with newly diagnosed intermediate-risk neuroblastoma with chemotherapy consisting of carboplatin, etoposide, cyclophosphamide, and doxorubicin. Retrieval therapy was included in the protocol for patients who developed progressive nonmetastatic disease within 3 years of study enrollment. Up to six cycles of cyclophosphamide and topotecan could be given to patients. Of 29 patients who received cyclophosphamide and topotecan, 18 remained event free, 9 experienced relapse, and 2 died. Twenty patients who experienced an inadequate initial response to eight cycles of chemotherapy were treated with cyclophosphamide and topotecan. Of those 20 patients, 9 patients achieved a very good partial response or better; however, 6 patients developed progressive disease or experienced relapse, and 1 patient died. This suggests that more aggressive therapy is needed for patients who do not achieve the defined treatment end point after eight cycles of chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.19">

845119</a>

8452]</p>

8453<p id="_804" tabindex="-1">

8454The previous COG study for intermediate-risk neuroblastoma (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003093">

8455COG-A3961</a>

8456) enrolled 479 patients, 42 of whom developed disease progression. The recurrence rate was 10% for those with favorable biology and 17% for those with unfavorable biology. Thirty patients had locoregional recurrences, 11 had metastatic recurrences, and 1 had both types of recurrent disease. Six of the 42 patients died of disease, while 36 patients responded to therapy. Thus, most patients with intermediate-risk neuroblastoma and disease progression may be salvaged.[<a href="#cit/section_10.16">

845716</a>

8458] It is not feasible to compare these results with the results of the other COG intermediate-risk study (ANBL0531) because of differences between the classification of patients for eligibility in the two studies.[<a href="#cit/section_10.19">

845919</a>

8460]</p>

8461<section id="_173">

8462<h4 id="_173_toc">

8463Locoregional recurrence</h4>

8464<p id="_699" tabindex="-1">

8465Treatment options for locoregional recurrent neuroblastoma initially classified as intermediate risk include the following:</p>

8466<div class="pdq-content-list">

8467<ol id="_728">

8468<li>

8469Surgery (complete resection).</li>

8470<li>

8471Surgery (incomplete resection) followed by chemotherapy.</li>

8472<li>

8473Radiation therapy. Radiation therapy is considered only for patients with disease progression after chemotherapy and second-look surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_10.16">

847416</a>

8475]</li>

8476</ol>

8477</div>

8478<p id="_135" tabindex="-1">

8479Locoregional recurrence of neuroblastoma with favorable biology that occurs

8480more than 3 months after completion of chemotherapy may be treated

8481surgically. If resection is less than near total, then additional chemotherapy may be given. Chemotherapy should be selected on the basis of previous chemotherapy received.[<a href="#cit/section_10.16">

848216</a>

8483]

8484</p>

8485</section>

8486<section id="_174">

8487<h4 id="_174_toc">

8488Metastatic recurrence</h4>

8489<p id="_701" tabindex="-1">

8490Treatment options for metastatic recurrent neuroblastoma initially classified as intermediate risk include the following:</p>

8491<div class="pdq-content-list">

8492<ol id="_729">

8493<li>

8494High-risk therapy.</li>

8495</ol>

8496</div>

8497<p id="_957" tabindex="-1">

8498Patients with metastatic recurrent neuroblastoma are treated like patients with newly diagnosed high-risk neuroblastoma. For more information, see the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_707">

8499Treatment Options for High-Risk Neuroblastoma</a>

8500 section.</p>

8501</section>

8502</section>

8503<section id="_138">

8504<h3 id="_138_toc">

8505Recurrent Neuroblastoma in Patients Initially Classified as High Risk</h3>

8506<p id="_513" tabindex="-1">

8507Any recurrence in patients initially classified as high risk signifies a very poor prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_10.8">

85088</a>

8509] Clinical trials may be considered. Palliative care should also be considered as part of the patient's treatment plan. </p>

8510<p id="_1213" tabindex="-1">

8511An analysis of several trials included 383 patients with neuroblastoma whose tumor recurred or progressed in COG modern-era, early-phase trials. The 1-year progression-free survival (PFS) rate was 21%, and the 4-year PFS rate was 6%. The OS rates were 57% at 1 year and 20% at 4 years. Less than 10% of patients experienced no subsequent recurrence or progression. <em class="gene-name">

8512MYCN</em>

8513 amplification predicted worse PFS and OS rates.[<a href="#cit/section_10.20">

851420</a>

8515] Although the OS after recurrence in children presenting with high-risk neuroblastoma is generally extremely poor, patients with high-risk neuroblastoma at first relapse after complete remission or MRD in whom relapse was a single site of soft tissue mass (a few children also had bone marrow or bone disease at relapse) had a 5-year OS rate of 35% in one single-institution study.[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

851618</a>

8517] </p>

8518<p id="_710" tabindex="-1">

8519Treatment options for recurrent or refractory neuroblastoma in patients initially classified as high risk include the following:</p>

8520<div class="pdq-content-list">

8521<ol id="_711">

8522<li>

8523Chemotherapy combined with immunotherapy.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8524<ul id="_1850">

8525<li>

8526Temozolomide, irinotecan, and dinutuximab.[<a href="#cit/section_10.21">

852721</a>

8528]</li>

8529</ul>

8530</div>

8531</li>

8532<li>

8533131I-MIBG. 131I-MIBG alone, in combination with other therapy, or followed by stem cell rescue.</li>

8534<li>

8535Novel therapies.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8536<ul id="_2522">

8537<li>

8538ALK inhibitors for patients with <em class="gene-name">

8539ALK</em>

8540 mutations. In a series of 20 patients with <em class="gene-name">

8541ALK</em>

8542 aberrations treated with crizotinib, the response rate was 15%. Two patients had partial responses, and one patient had a complete response. All three patients had a somatic <em class="gene-name">

8543ALK</em>

8544 Arg1275Gln mutation.[<a href="#cit/section_10.22">

854522</a>

8546][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8547Level of evidence C3</a>

8548] Lorlatinib has shown activity in patients with <em class="gene-name">

8549ALK</em>

8550-aberrant, relapsed neuroblastoma. The response rates were 13% in patients younger than 18 years and 47% in patients aged 18 years or older.[<a href="#cit/section_10.23">

855123</a>

8552] Additional patients in each cohort had minor responses, resulting in modified response rates of 30% and 67%, respectively.</li>

8553<li>

8554WEE1 inhibitors. A phase II trial of adavosertib plus irinotecan reported that 3 of 20 patients with relapsed neuroblastoma had objective responses, which met the primary efficacy end point.[<a href="#cit/section_10.24">

855524</a>

8556]</li>

8557</ul>

8558</div>

8559</li>

8560<li>

8561Chemotherapy (phase I/II studies).<div class="pdq-content-list">

8562<ul id="_921">

8563<li>

8564Topotecan in combination with cyclophosphamide or etoposide.[<a href="#cit/section_10.25">

856525</a>

8566]</li>

8567<li>

8568Temozolomide with irinotecan.</li>

8569</ul>

8570</div>

8571</li>

8572<li>

8573Immunotherapy. Novel anti-GD2 drugs have been evaluated in patients with recurrent or refractory neuroblastoma. Hu14.18 anti-GD2 has been chemically linked with IL-2 and combined with granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF), and a phase II trial of this regimen reported a few durable responses.[<a href="#cit/section_10.26">

857426</a>

8575]</li>

8576</ol>

8577</div>

8578<p id="_1865" tabindex="-1">

8579Chemotherapy combined with immunotherapy produces the best response rate and response duration of treatments for high-risk patients with disease progression.</p>

8580<p id="_1866" tabindex="-1">

8581Evidence (chemotherapy combined with immunotherapy):</p>

8582<div class="pdq-content-list">

8583<ol id="_1867">

8584<li>

8585The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01767194">

8586ANBL1221 (NCT01767194)</a>

8587 trial was the first multicenter trial to evaluate anti-GD2 therapy combined with chemotherapy in a cohort of patients with relapsed or refractory neuroblastoma. Patients in first relapse or progression were randomly assigned to receive either irinotecan/temozolomide/dinutuximab/GM-CSF (I/T/DIN/GM-CSF) or temozolomide/irinotecan/temsirolimus.[<a href="#cit/section_10.21">

858821</a>

8589]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.27">

859027</a>

8591][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8592Level of evidence C3</a>

8593]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8594<ul id="_1878">

8595<li>

8596Of the 17 patients treated with the combination that included dinutuximab, 9 patients (53%) had objective responses, compared with 1 of 18 patients treated with the regimen that contained temsirolimus.</li>

8597<li>

8598In an expansion cohort consisting of 36 additional patients nonrandomly assigned to receive I/T/DIN/GM-CSF, objective responses were seen in 13 patients (36.1%). For all 53 patients enrolled on the study and treated with I/T/DIN/GM-CSF, there were 22 objective responses (41.5%).[<a href="#cit/section_10.27">

859927</a>

8600][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8601Level of evidence C3</a>

8602] This outcome is superior to any other published outcome for patients with refractory or relapsed high-risk neuroblastoma.</li>

8603</ul>

8604</div>

8605</li>

8606<li>

8607In a retrospective cohort study of 146 patients with high-risk neuroblastoma who received chemoimmunotherapy with I/T/DIN/GM-CSF in first relapse, the following results were reported:[<a href="#cit/section_10.28">

860828</a>

8609][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8610Level of evidence C2</a>

8611]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8612<ul id="_2439">

8613<li>

8614A total of 49% of patients had an objective response, similar to the response rate seen in the ANBL1221 trial.</li>

8615<li>

8616Of the patients with stable disease or better at first disease evaluation after chemoimmunotherapy, 22% had an improved response (per International Neuroblastoma Response Criteria) on subsequent evaluation. Only 13% of patients with stable disease at first disease evaluation eventually had an objective response, whereas approximately 40% of patients with initial minimal response or partial response status achieved complete response after subsequent cycles. Patients who received more than six cycles of therapy and had continued stable disease were unlikely to achieve an objective response.</li>

8617<li>

8618The median PFS was 13.1 months from initiation of therapy. The 1-year PFS rate was 50%, and the 2-year PFS rate was 28%. </li>

8619<li>

8620The median duration of response was 15.9 months.</li>

8621<li>

8622The median PFS after discontinuation of all anticancer therapy, including I/T/DIN/GM-CSF, was 10.4 months.</li>

8623</ul>

8624</div>

8625</li>

8626</ol>

8627</div>

8628<p id="_720" tabindex="-1">

8629Evidence (131I-MIBG alone or in combination with other therapies):</p>

8630<div class="pdq-content-list">

8631<ol id="_721">

8632<li>

8633For children with recurrent or refractory neuroblastoma, 131I-MIBG is an effective palliative agent and may be considered alone or in combination with chemotherapy (with stem cell rescue) in a clinical research trial.[<a href="#cit/section_10.29">

863429</a>

8635-<a href="#cit/section_10.34">

863634</a>

8637]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.35">

863835</a>

8639,<a href="#cit/section_10.36">

864036</a>

8641][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8642Level of evidence C1</a>

8643]</li>

8644<li>

8645A North American retrospective study of more than 200 patients treated with 131I-MIBG therapy compared children who had recurrence or progression of disease with children who had stable or persistent disease since diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_10.37">

864637</a>

8647]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8648<ul id="_1192">

8649<li>

8650 The rate of immediate progression after 131I-MIBG therapy was lower, and the OS rate at 2 years was better (65% vs. 39%) in patients with stable, persistent disease.</li>

8651</ul>

8652</div>

8653</li>

8654<li>

8655Tandem consolidation using 131I-MIBG, vincristine, and irinotecan with autologous stem cell transplant (SCT) followed by busulfan/melphalan with autologous SCT was retrospectively reported in eight patients.[<a href="#cit/section_10.36">

865636</a>

8657]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8658<ul id="_2413">

8659<li>

8660This treatment resulted in three complete responses, two partial responses, and one minor response.</li>

8661</ul>

8662</div>

8663</li>

8664<li>

8665 Single autologous SCT with escalating dose 131I-MIBG and carboplatin/etoposide/melphalan was studied in additional patients.[<a href="#cit/section_10.38">

866638</a>

8667]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8668<ul id="_1214">

8669<li>

8670After induction chemotherapy, 27 refractory patients and 15 progressing patients were treated, resulting in four responses. Eight patients with partial response to induction were treated, resulting in three responses.</li>

8671<li>

8672The 12% incidence of sinusoidal obstructive syndrome was dose limiting.</li>

8673</ul>

8674</div>

8675</li>

8676<li>

8677A randomized phase II trial included 105 evaluable patients who were treated with either 131I-MIBG alone, 131I-MIBG with irinotecan and vincristine, or 131I-MIBG with vorinostat.[<a href="#cit/section_10.39">

867839</a>

8679]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8680<ul id="_2079">

8681<li>

8682Patients enrolled in the vorinostat arm had the highest response rate (32%).</li>

8683<li>

8684Patients treated with MIBG alone or with irinotecan/vincristine had response rates of 14%.</li>

8685</ul>

8686</div>

8687</li>

8688</ol>

8689</div>

8690<p id="_1868" tabindex="-1">

8691Evidence (chemotherapy):</p>

8692<div class="pdq-content-list">

8693<ol id="_1869">

8694<li>

8695The combination of irinotecan and temozolomide had a 15% response rate in one study.[<a href="#cit/section_10.40">

869640</a>

8697][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8698Level of evidence B4</a>

8699] </li>

8700<li>

8701A retrospective study reported on 74 patients who received 92 cycles of ifosfamide, carboplatin, and etoposide. The study included 37 patients who received peripheral blood stem cell rescue after responding to this drug combination.[<a href="#cit/section_10.41">

870241</a>

8703]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8704<ul id="_1870">

8705<li>

8706Disease regressions (major and minor responses) were achieved in 14 of 17 patients (82%) with a new relapse, 13 of 26 patients (50%) with refractory neuroblastoma, and 12 of 34 patients (35%) who were treated for progressive disease during chemotherapy (<em>

8707P</em>

8708 = .005). </li>

8709<li>

8710Grade 3 toxicities were rare. </li>

8711</ul>

8712</div>

8713</li>

8714<li>

8715Topotecan in combination with cyclophosphamide alone or with etoposide has been used in patients with recurrent disease who did not receive topotecan initially. The response rates were 32% (18 of 57) for patients who received topotecan and cyclophosphamide and 19% (11 of 59) for patients who received topotecan alone.[<a href="#cit/section_10.25">

871625</a>

8717][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810019&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810019&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8718Level of evidence A2</a>

8719]</li>

8720<li>

8721High-dose carboplatin, irinotecan, and/or temozolomide has been used to treat patients with refractory disease or new relapses (after treatment that included topotecan) occurring off therapy (68% objective response rate). However, this regimen is not used to treat patients whose disease progresses while on therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.42">

872242</a>

8723] </li>

8724</ol>

8725</div>

8726<p id="_1047" tabindex="-1">

8727Allogeneic transplant has a historically low success rate in recurrent or progressive neuroblastoma. In a retrospective registry study, allogeneic SCT after a previous autologous SCT appeared to offer no benefit. Disease recurrence remains the most common cause of treatment failure.[<a href="#cit/section_10.43">

872843</a>

8729] The use of GD2-directed therapy after haploidentical transplant may be a more promising strategy. In one trial of 68 patients with relapsed neuroblastoma, the use of dinutuximab and subcutaneous interleukin-2 after haploidentical transplant was feasible, with a low rate of graft-versus-host disease. The 5-year EFS rate was 43%. Superior outcomes were obtained for patients who had complete or partial responses at the start of dinutuximab therapy. Among patients with disease after transplant, the complete response rate to anti-GD2 immunotherapy was 35%.[<a href="#cit/section_10.44">

873044</a>

8731]</p>

8732<p id="_1131" tabindex="-1">

8733Clinical trials of vaccines designed to induce host antiganglioside antibodies that can replicate the antineoplastic activities of intravenously administered monoclonal antibodies are ongoing. Patients also receive a beta-glucan treatment, which has a broad range of immunostimulatory effects and synergizes with anti-GD2/GD3 monoclonal antibodies. In a phase I study of 15 children with high-risk neuroblastoma, the therapy was tolerated without any dose-limiting toxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_10.45">

873445</a>

8735] Long-term PFS has been reported in patients who achieve a second or later complete or very good partial remission followed by consolidation with anti-GD2 immunotherapy and isotretinoin with or without maintenance therapy. This includes patients who had previously received anti-GD2 immunotherapy and isotretinoin.[<a href="#cit/section_10.46">

873646</a>

8737]

8738</p>

8739</section>

8740<section id="_703">

8741<h3 id="_703_toc">

8742Recurrent Neuroblastoma in the Central Nervous System</h3>

8743<p id="_704" tabindex="-1">

8744Central nervous system (CNS) involvement, although rare at initial presentation, may occur in 3% to 10% of patients with recurrent neuroblastoma.

8745CNS relapses represented 6% of all metastatic relapses in a series of 1,161 first relapses in 1,977 stage 4 patients treated in a trial of patients with high-risk neuroblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_10.47">

874647</a>

8747] Because up-front treatment for newly diagnosed patients does not adequately treat the CNS, the CNS has emerged as a sanctuary site leading to relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_10.47">

874847</a>

8749-<a href="#cit/section_10.49">

875049</a>

8751] </p>

8752<p id="_2396" tabindex="-1">

8753Significant risk factors for CNS relapse identified in the International Society of Paediatric Oncology Europe Neuroblastoma (SIOPEN) trial were patient and disease features at diagnosis. These features included female sex (hazard ratio [HR], 2.0; <em>

8754P</em>

8755 = .016), <em class="gene-name">

8756MYCN</em>

8757 amplification (HR, 2.4; <em>

8758P</em>

8759 = .0008), hepatic disease (HR, 2.5; <em>

8760P</em>

8761 = .01), or more than one metastatic system/compartment involvement (HR, 7.1; <em>

8762P</em>

8763 = .047). Neither high-dose chemotherapy nor immunotherapy was associated with higher risk of recurrence. Investigators noted stable incidence of CNS relapse reported over time.[<a href="#cit/section_10.47">

876447</a>

8765]</p>

8766<p id="_2397" tabindex="-1">

8767CNS relapses are almost always fatal, with a median time to death of 6 months. The 1-year and 3-year postrelapse OS rates were 25% and 7%, respectively, in the SIOPEN trial.[<a href="#cit/section_10.47">

876847</a>

8769] Patients with isolated CNS relapses may be able to achieve long-term survival.[<a href="#cit/section_10.47">

877047</a>

8771]</p>

8772<p id="_1008" tabindex="-1">

8773Treatment options for recurrent neuroblastoma in the CNS include the following:</p>

8774<div class="pdq-content-list">

8775<ol id="_1009">

8776<li>

8777Surgery and radiation therapy.</li>

8778<li>

8779Chemotherapy (including temozolomide-containing regimens) in combination with surgery and radiation therapy.</li>

8780<li>

8781Novel therapeutic approaches.</li>

8782</ol>

8783</div>

8784<p id="_705" tabindex="-1">

8785Current treatment approaches generally include eradicating bulky and microscopic residual disease in the CNS and minimal residual systemic disease that may herald further relapses. Neurosurgical interventions serve to decrease edema, control hemorrhage, and remove bulky tumor before starting therapy. </p>

8786<p id="_1193" tabindex="-1">

8787A single institution had some success while testing intraventricular compartmental radioimmunotherapy using intrathecal radioiodinated anti-GD2 monoclonal antibodies, combined with 18 Gy or 21 Gy of craniospinal irradiation with boosts to gross CNS disease, in patients with recurrent metastatic CNS neuroblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_10.13">

878813</a>

8789] The posttreatment 5-year CNS disease-free survival rate was about 69%, and the 5-year OS rate was about 45%.[<a href="#cit/section_10.50">

879050</a>

8791][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8792Level of evidence C2</a>

8793]</p>

8794<p id="_2437" tabindex="-1">

8795For patients who experience prolonged survival after an initial CNS relapse, some may develop a second relapse after cranial spinal irradiation (CSI). Published data for patients who experience a second CNS relapse are limited. A second CNS relapse portends a poor prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_10.48">

879648</a>

8797]</p>

8798<p id="_2510" tabindex="-1">

8799 In a single-institution study that included 128 patients treated with CSI for first CNS relapse, 40 developed a second CNS relapse at a median of 6.3 months from the initial CSI treatment. Patient outcomes after second CNS relapse are poor, although treatment with radiation therapy at the time of second CNS relapse may be associated with longer OS.[<a href="#cit/section_10.51">

880051</a>

8801][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8802Level of evidence C1</a>

8803]</p>

8804<div class="pdq-content-list">

8805<ul id="_2438">

8806<li>

8807The 1-year survival rate was 32.5%.</li>

8808<li>

8809Patients in this group with initial leptomeningeal involvement were more likely to relapse than those who had exclusively parenchymal lesions (HR, 2.5; 95% CI, 1.3&#8211;4.9; <em>

8810P</em>

8811 = .006). The median time to second CNS relapse was 6.8 months, 51% of which occurred outside the CSI boost field. </li>

8812<li>

8813Most patients (24 of 40) received radiation as part of the multimodality approach for the second CNS relapse. Receipt of radiation therapy at time of second CNS relapse was associated with improved OS (median, 30 vs. 5.1 months; HR, 0.5; log-rank <em>

8814P</em>

8815 &lt; .001). </li>

8816<li>

8817Eight of the 40 patients received compartmental intrathecal radioimmunotherapy (cRIT) with radioiodinated anti-GD2 monoclonal antibodies as part of their treatment. The prolonged median OS from the time of second relapse was 22 months for patients who received cRIT. In comparison, the median OS was 5 months for patients who did not receive cRIT. Five of these patients had previously received cRIT at the time of initial CNS relapse.</li>

8818</ul>

8819</div>

8820</section>

8821<section id="_811">

8822<h3 id="_811_toc">

8823Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation for Recurrent or Refractory Neuroblastoma</h3>

8824<p id="_812" tabindex="-1">

8825Information about National Cancer Institute (NCI)&#8211;supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

8826NCI website</a>

8827. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

8828ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

8829.</p>

8830<p id="_1811" tabindex="-1">

8831The following are examples of national and/or institutional clinical trials that are currently being conducted:</p>

8832<div class="pdq-content-list">

8833<ul id="_813">

8834<li>

8835<strong>

8836<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03794349">

8837ANBL1821 (NCT03794349)</a>

8838</strong>

8839 (Irinotecan Hydrochloride, Temozolomide, and Dinutuximab With or Without Eflornithine [DFMO] in Treating Patients With Relapsed or Refractory Neuroblastoma)<strong>

8840:</strong>

8841 This trial is studying the addition of DFMO to the chemo-immunotherapy backbone, which has shown promising results in patients with recurrent neuroblastoma. DFMO is an irreversible inhibitor of ODC1, which is a downstream transcriptional target of MYCN and a key enzyme in the polyamine synthesis pathway. DFMO depletes essential polyamines necessary for tumor survival. </li>

8842<li>

8843<strong>

8844<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03155620">

8845APEC1621 (NCT03155620)</a>

8846</strong>

8847 (Pediatric MATCH: Targeted Therapy Directed by Genetic Testing in Treating Pediatric Patients with Relapsed or Refractory Advanced Solid Tumors, Non-Hodgkin Lymphomas, or Histiocytic Disorders)<strong>

8848:</strong>

8849 NCI-COG Pediatric Molecular Analysis for Therapeutic Choice (MATCH), referred to as Pediatric MATCH, will match targeted agents with specific molecular changes identified in a patient's tumor (refractory or recurrent). Children and adolescents aged 1 to 21 years are eligible for the trial.<p id="_1795" tabindex="-1">

8850Patients with tumors that have molecular variants addressed by treatment arms included in the trial will be offered treatment on Pediatric MATCH. Additional information can be obtained on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/nci-supported/pediatric-match" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/nci-supported/pediatric-match">

8851NCI website</a>

8852 and <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03155620" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03155620">

8853ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

8854.</p>

8855

8856</li>

8857<li>

8858<strong>

8859<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02332668">

8860ADVL1621 (NCT02332668)</a>

8861</strong>

8862 (A Phase I/II Study of Pembrolizumab [MK-3475] in Children With Advanced Melanoma or a PD-L1&#8211;Positive Advanced, Relapsed or Refractory Solid Tumor or Lymphoma)<strong>

8863:</strong>

8864 Part 1 of this study will find the maximum tolerated dose, confirm the dose, and find the recommended phase II dose for pembrolizumab therapy. Part 2 of the study will further evaluate the safety and efficacy at the pediatric phase II recommended dose.</li>

8865</ul>

8866</div>

8867<section id="_TrialSearch_811_sid_11">

8868<h4 id="_TrialSearch_811_sid_11_toc">

8869Current Clinical Trials</h4>

8870<p id="_TrialSearch_811_22" tabindex="-1">

8871Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

8872advanced clinical trial search</a>

8873 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

8874General information</a>

8875 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

8876</section>

8877</section>

8896</li>

Nat Genet 47 (8): 864-71, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26121087&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26121087&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8899[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8900</li>

8901<li id="section_10.6">

8902Schramm A, K&#246;ster J, Assenov Y, et al.: Mutational dynamics between primary and relapse neuroblastomas. Nat Genet 47 (8): 872-7, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26121086&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26121086&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8903[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8904</li>

8905<li id="section_10.7">

J Clin Oncol 40 (20): 2224-2234, 2022.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=35353553&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=35353553&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8907[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8908</li>
