9060</li>

9061<li id="section_10.46">

9062Kushner BH, Ostrovnaya I, Cheung IY, et al.: Prolonged progression-free survival after consolidating second or later remissions of neuroblastoma with Anti-GD2 immunotherapy and isotretinoin: a prospective Phase II study. Oncoimmunology 4 (7): e1016704, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26140243&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26140243&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9063[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9064</li>

9065<li id="section_10.47">

9066Berlanga P, Pasqualini C, P&#246;tschger U, et al.: Central nervous system relapse in high-risk stage 4 neuroblastoma: The HR-NBL1/SIOPEN trial experience. Eur J Cancer 144: 1-8, 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33316634&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33316634&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9067[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9068</li>

9069<li id="section_10.48">

9070Kramer K, Kushner B, Heller G, et al.: Neuroblastoma metastatic to the central nervous system. The Memorial Sloan-kettering Cancer Center Experience and A Literature Review. Cancer 91 (8): 1510-9, 2001.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11301399&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11301399&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9071[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9072</li>

9073<li id="section_10.49">

9074Matthay KK, Brisse H, Couanet D, et al.: Central nervous system metastases in neuroblastoma: radiologic, clinical, and biologic features in 23 patients. Cancer 98 (1): 155-65, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12833468&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12833468&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9075[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9076</li>

9077<li id="section_10.50">

9078Luo LY, Kramer K, Cheung NV, et al.: Reduced-dose craniospinal irradiation for central nervous system relapsed neuroblastoma. Pediatr Blood Cancer 67 (9): e28364, 2020.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=32608559&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=32608559&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9079[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9080</li>

9081<li id="section_10.51">

9082Tringale KR, Wolden SL, Casey DL, et al.: Clinical outcomes of pediatric patients receiving multimodality treatment of second central nervous system relapse of neuroblastoma. Pediatr Blood Cancer 70 (2): e30075, 2023.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=36349892&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=36349892&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9083[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9084</li>

9085</ol>

9086</div>

9087

9088 </section>

9089

9090

9091

9092 <section id="_243">

9093

9094 <h2>

9095Changes to This Summary (08/22/2023)</h2>

9096

9097 <div id="_section_243" class="pdq-sections">

9098<p id="_251" tabindex="-1">

9099The PDQ cancer information summaries are reviewed regularly and updated as

9100new information becomes available. This section describes the latest

9101changes made to this summary as of the date above.</p>

9102<p id="_2533" tabindex="-1">

9103<strong>

9104<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1">

9105General Information About Neuroblastoma</a>

9106</strong>

9107</p>

9108<p id="_2534" tabindex="-1">

9109Revised <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1935">

9110text</a>

9111 to state that quantitative, normalized assessment of urinary catecholamines, such as urine vanillylmandelic acid and homovanillic acid, by gas chromatography and mass spectroscopy can be a random urine collection normalized for urine creatinine, because this approach appears to have similar sensitivity to a 24-hour collection (cited Matser et al. as reference 32).</p>

9112<p id="_2535" tabindex="-1">

9113Revised <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_295">

9114text</a>

9115 to state that some neuroblastomas cannot be differentiated morphologically, via conventional light microscopy with hematoxylin and eosin staining alone, from other small round blue cell tumors of childhood, such as lymphomas, Ewing sarcoma, and rhabdomyosarcomas.</p>

9116<p id="_2536" tabindex="-1">

9117Added <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_2475">

9118text</a>

9119 to state that an analysis of North American patients who went on to receive tandem transplants showed that patients with Curie scores greater than 0 at the end of induction therapy had inferior event-free survival (EFS) rates (cited Streby et al. as reference 106).</p>

9120<p id="_2526" tabindex="-1">

9121<strong>

9122<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1937">

9123Genomic and Biological Features of Neuroblastoma</a>

9124</strong>

9125</p>

9126<p id="_2529" tabindex="-1">

9127Added <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1937">

9128text</a>

9129 to state that an analysis of 133 patients with International Neuroblastoma Staging System stage 3 tumors without <em class="gene-name">

9130MYCN</em>

9131 amplification demonstrated that segmental chromosomal aberrations were associated with inferior EFS, and 11q loss was independently associated with worse overall survival (OS) (cited Pinto et al. as reference 10).</p>

9132<p id="_2530" tabindex="-1">

9133Added <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1937">

9134text</a>

9135 to state that a fourth study evaluated the frequency of <em class="gene-name">

9136ALK</em>

9137 alterations at diagnosis and relapse. There were significantly higher rates of <em class="gene-name">

9138ALK</em>

9139 mutations at relapse than at diagnosis. The rate of <em class="gene-name">

9140ALK</em>

9141 amplifications did not differ between diagnosis and relapse (cited Rosswog et al. as reference 36).</p>

9142<p id="_2531" tabindex="-1">

9143Added <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1937">

9144text</a>

9145 to state that in one analysis of serial circulating tumor DNA samples from patients treated with lorlatinib, <em class="gene-name">

9146ALK</em>

9147 variant allele frequency tracked with disease burden in most but not all patients. In subsets of patients who progressed while taking lorlatinib, second compound mutations in <em class="gene-name">

9148ALK</em>

9149 or mutations in other genes, including RAS pathway genes, were reported (cited Berko et al. as reference 38).</p>

9150<p id="_2532" tabindex="-1">

9151Revised <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1937">

9152text</a>

9153 to state that compared with newly diagnosed cases, the proportion of neuroblastoma cases with alternative lengthening of telomeres (ALT)&#8211;positive tumors was higher in a cohort of patients who relapsed (10% vs. 48%, respectively). This finding may reflect the relatively indolent course of tumors with ALT activation after relapse, compared with the clinical course of other tumors after relapse. Over time, the proportion of patients with relapsed ALT-positive neuroblastomas appears larger than that of patients with another tumor type who relapsed.</p>

9154<p id="_2538" tabindex="-1">

9155<strong>

9156<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_30">

9157Treatment Option Overview for Neuroblastoma</a>

9158</strong>

9159</p>

9160<p id="_2539" tabindex="-1">

9161The <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_604">

9162Surgery</a>

9163 subsection was extensively revised.</p>

9164<p id="_2540" tabindex="-1">

9165<strong>

9166<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_230">

9167Treatment of Non&#8211;High-Risk Neuroblastoma</a>

9168</strong>

9169</p>

9170<p id="_2541" tabindex="-1">

9171Added <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_646">

9172text</a>

9173 about a retrospective analysis from the Children's Oncology Group (COG) that evaluated patients aged 12 to 18 months with metastatic disease and favorable biological features (cited Bender et al. as reference 12).</p>

9174<p id="_2527" tabindex="-1">

9175<strong>

9176<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_214">

9177Treatment of High-Risk Neuroblastoma</a>

9178</strong>

9179</p>

9180<p id="_2537" tabindex="-1">

9181Added Seemann et al. as <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_2495">

9182reference 20</a>

9183.</p>

9184<p id="_2542" tabindex="-1">

9185Added <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_2507">

9186text</a>

9187 to state that a GD2/GD3 ganglioside vaccine is another approach that has been studied for patients in first remission after completion of standard therapy. In a randomized trial that mainly included patients in first remission, early introduction of beta-glucan along with a GD2/GD3 vaccine increased GD2/GD3 antibody titers without increasing toxicity. Progression-free survival (PFS) rates were similar for patients in both randomized treatment arms. However, patients with higher titers had more favorable PFS rates, regardless of the treatment arm (cited Cheung et al. as reference 56 and level of evidence B1).</p>

9188<p id="_2528" tabindex="-1">

9189<strong>

9190<a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_706">

9191Treatment of Recurrent Neuroblastoma</a>

9192</strong>

9193</p>

9194<p id="_2543" tabindex="-1">

9195Added <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_2521">

9196text</a>

9197 to state that sequencing of recurrent and refractory neuroblastoma tumors from pediatric and young adult patients enrolled in the National Cancer Institute&#8211;COG Pediatric MATCH trial revealed genomic alterations that were considered actionable for treatment in MATCH study arms in 27 of 60 tumors. Hotspot mutations in <em class="gene-name">

9198ALK</em>

9199 were most frequent, reported in 19 of 60 tumors. MAPK pathway mutations were detected in 4 of 60 tumors, and <em class="gene-name">

9200FGFR1</em>

9201 mutations were detected in 3 of 60 tumors (cited Parsons et al. as reference 7).</p>

9202<p id="_2544" tabindex="-1">

9203Added <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_2522">

9204text</a>

9205 to state that lorlatinib has shown activity in patients with <em class="gene-name">

9206ALK</em>

9207-aberrant, relapsed neuroblastoma. The response rates were 13% in patients younger than 18 years and 47% in patients aged 18 years or older. Additional patients in each cohort had minor responses, resulting in modified response rates of 30% and 67%, respectively

9208(cited Goldsmith et al. as reference 23).</p>

9209<p id="_2545" tabindex="-1">

9210Added <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_2522">

9211WEE1 inhibitors</a>

9212 as treatment options for recurrent and refractory neuroblastoma in patients initially classified as high risk. Also added text to state that a phase II trial of adavosertib plus irinotecan reported that 3 of 20 patients with relapsed neuroblastoma had objective responses, which met the primary efficacy end point (cited Cole et al. as reference 24).</p>

9213<p id="_2546" tabindex="-1">

9214Added <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_1047">

9215text</a>

9216 to state that the use of GD2-directed therapy after haploidentical transplant may be a more promising strategy. In one trial of 68 patients with relapsed neuroblastoma, the use of dinutuximab and subcutaneous interleukin-2 after haploidentical transplant was feasible, with a low rate of graft-versus-host disease. The 5-year EFS rate was 43%. Superior outcomes were obtained for patients who had complete or partial responses at the start of dinutuximab therapy. Among patients with disease after transplant, the complete response rate to anti-GD2 immunotherapy was 35% (cited Flaadt et al. as reference 44).</p>

9217<p id="_disclaimerHP_3" tabindex="-1">

9218This summary is written and maintained by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment">

9219PDQ Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board</a>

9220, which is

9221editorially independent of NCI. The summary reflects an independent review of

9222the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or NIH. More

9223information about summary policies and the role of the PDQ Editorial Boards in

9224maintaining the PDQ summaries can be found on the <a href="/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq#_AboutThis_1">

9225About This PDQ Summary</a>

9226 and <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq">

9227PDQ&#174; Cancer Information for Health Professionals</a>

9228 pages.

9229</p>

9230</div>

9231

9232 </section>

9233

9234

9235

9236 <section id="_AboutThis_1">

9237

9238 <h2>

9239About This PDQ Summary</h2>

9240

9241 <div id="_section_AboutThis_1" class="pdq-sections">

9242<section id="_AboutThis_2">

9243<h3 id="_AboutThis_2_toc">

9244Purpose of This Summary</h3>

9245<p id="_AboutThis_3" tabindex="-1">

9246This PDQ cancer information summary for health professionals provides comprehensive, peer-reviewed, evidence-based information about the treatment of neuroblastoma. It is intended as a resource to inform and assist clinicians in the care of their patients. It does not provide formal guidelines or recommendations for making health care decisions.</p>

9247</section>

9248<section id="_AboutThis_4">

9249<h3 id="_AboutThis_4_toc">

9250Reviewers and Updates</h3>

9251<p id="_AboutThis_5" tabindex="-1">

9252This summary is reviewed regularly and updated as necessary by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment">

9253PDQ Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board</a>

9254, which is editorially independent of the National Cancer Institute (NCI). The summary reflects an independent review of the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or the National Institutes of Health (NIH).</p>

9255<p id="_AboutThis_22" tabindex="-1">

9256 Board members review recently published articles each month to determine whether an article should:</p>

9257<div class="pdq-content-list">

9258<ul id="_AboutThis_6">

9259<li>

9260be discussed at a meeting,</li>

9261<li>

9262be cited with text, or</li>

9263<li>

9264replace or update an existing article that is already cited.</li>

9265</ul>

9266</div>

9267<p id="_AboutThis_7" tabindex="-1">

9268Changes to the summaries are made through a consensus process in which Board members evaluate the strength of the evidence in the published articles and determine how the article should be included in the summary.</p>

9269<p id="" tabindex="-1">

9270The lead reviewers for Neuroblastoma Treatment are:</p>

9271<div class="pdq-content-list">

9272<ul id="">

9273<li>

9274Steven DuBois, MD, MS (Dana Farber Cancer Institute)</li>

9275<li>

9276Andrea A. Hayes-Dixon, MD, FACS, FAAP (Howard University)</li>

9277<li>

9278Karen J. Marcus, MD, FACR (Dana-Farber Cancer Institute/Boston Children's Hospital)</li>

9279<li>

9280Nita Louise Seibel, MD (National Cancer Institute)</li>

9281<li>

9282Stephen J. Shochat, MD (St. Jude Children's Research Hospital)</li>

9283<li>

9284Malcolm A. Smith, MD, PhD (National Cancer Institute)</li>

9285</ul>

9286</div>

9287<p id="_AboutThis_9" tabindex="-1">

9288Any comments or questions about the summary content should be submitted to Cancer.gov through the NCI website's <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

9289Email Us</a>

9290. Do not contact the individual Board Members with questions or comments about the summaries. Board members will not respond to individual inquiries.</p>

9291</section>

9292<section id="_AboutThis_10">

9293<h3 id="_AboutThis_10_toc">

9294Levels of Evidence</h3>

9295<p id="_AboutThis_11" tabindex="-1">

9296Some of the reference citations in this summary are accompanied by a level-of-evidence designation. These designations are intended to help readers assess the strength of the evidence supporting the use of specific interventions or approaches. The PDQ Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board uses a <a href="/publications/pdq/levels-evidence/treatment">

9297formal evidence ranking system</a>

9298 in developing its level-of-evidence designations.</p>

9299</section>

9300<section id="_AboutThis_12">

9301<h3 id="_AboutThis_12_toc">

9302Permission to Use This Summary</h3>

9303<p id="_AboutThis_13" tabindex="-1">

9304PDQ is a registered trademark. Although the content of PDQ documents can be used freely as text, it cannot be identified as an NCI PDQ cancer information summary unless it is presented in its entirety and is regularly updated. However, an author would be permitted to write a sentence such as &#8220;NCI&#8217;s PDQ cancer information summary about breast cancer prevention states the risks succinctly: [include excerpt from the summary].&#8221;</p>

9305<p id="_AboutThis_14" tabindex="-1">

9306The preferred citation for this PDQ summary is:</p>

9307<p id="_AboutThis_15" tabindex="-1">

9308PDQ&#174; Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board. PDQ Neuroblastoma Treatment. Bethesda, MD: National Cancer Institute. Updated &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. Available at: <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq">

9309https://www.cancer.gov/types/neuroblastoma/hp/neuroblastoma-treatment-pdq</a>

9310. Accessed &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. [PMID: 26389190]</p>

9311<p id="_AboutThis_16" tabindex="-1">

9312Images in this summary are used with permission of the author(s), artist, and/or publisher for use within the PDQ summaries only. Permission to use images outside the context of PDQ information must be obtained from the owner(s) and cannot be granted by the National Cancer Institute. Information about using the illustrations in this summary, along with many other cancer-related images, is available in <a href="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/" title="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/">

9313Visuals Online</a>

9314, a collection of over 2,000 scientific images.

9315

9316</p>

9317</section>

9318<section id="_AboutThis_17">

9319<h3 id="_AboutThis_17_toc">

9320Disclaimer</h3>

9321<p id="_AboutThis_18" tabindex="-1">

9322Based on the strength of the available evidence, treatment options may be described as either &#8220;standard&#8221; or &#8220;under clinical evaluation.&#8221; These classifications should not be used as a basis for insurance reimbursement determinations. More information on insurance coverage is available on Cancer.gov on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care">

9323Managing Cancer Care</a>

9324 page.</p>

9325</section>

9326<section id="_AboutThis_20">

9327<h3 id="_AboutThis_20_toc">

9328Contact Us</h3>

9329<p id="_AboutThis_21" tabindex="-1">

9330More information about contacting us or receiving help with the Cancer.gov website can be found on our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact">

9331Contact Us for Help</a>

9332 page. Questions can also be submitted to Cancer.gov through the website&#8217;s <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

9333Email Us</a>

9334.</p>
